questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with an adnexal mass. Investigations show: 

 

  • CA-125: Slightly raised
  • CA19-9: Normal
  • LDH: Elevated

 

The resected tumor shows the gross and microscopic findings below.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysgerminoma

 

  • It is the most common malignant tumor of the ovary.
  • It is bilateral in 15–20% cases. 
  • It expresses OCT-3/4 & NANO-G, with activating mutations in the Kit gene. 
  • Histopathology:
    • Homogeneous, gray-white, lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. 
    • Cells are large and round to polyhedral and has a distinct cell membrane; a clear or watery-appearing cytoplasm; and a large, central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli. 
  • Clinical Features: 
    • Usually affects young women.
    • Presents with abdominal lump, or with metastatic symptoms. 
    • Most commonly spreads through lymphatics. 
  • Diagnosis: 
    • Secretes LDH & PLAP (Placental alkaline phosphatase), rarely secretes beta hCG 
  • Treatment:
    • Early dysgerminoma (Stage IA): Unilateral oophorectomy
    • Rest cases: Unilateral oophorectomy followed by chemotherapy 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma:

 

  • Surface epithelial tumor
  • Usually occurs in older postmenopausal women
  • CA-125 is often markedly elevated
  • Gross: Cystic with papillary projections, not homogeneous or solid
  • Histology: Papillary architecture with psammoma bodies (not seen here)

 

Option C. Teratoma:

 

  • Mature teratoma (dermoid cyst) is benign, common in young women
  • Gross: Heterogeneous with hair, teeth, sebaceous material
  • Histology: Tissues from all 3 germ layers
  • Immature teratomas have primitive neuroectoderm — not seen here
  • Tumor markers: May show AFP elevation in immature types

 

Option D. Choriocarcinoma:

 

  • Aggressive tumor of gestational or non-gestational origin
  • β-hCG is markedly elevated
  • Gross: Hemorrhagic and necrotic
  • Microscopy: Sheets of cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts — not present here
  • LDH not a marker

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. It is characterized by elevated LDH, occurs in young females, and presents as a solid, lobulated ovarian mass with classic histology (clear cells, central nuclei, fibrous septa with lymphocytes).
  • Tumor markers and histopathology are key to differentiation from epithelial and other germ cell tumors.

questions.text: A 16 French size of Foley's catheter refers to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Outer diameter of 5.3 mm

 

  • French is a unit of measurement used for the outer diameter of a Foley catheter. It is a common way to denote the size of the catheter, especially in medical and healthcare settings.
  • The French scale is based on a 3:1 ratio, where one French unit (Fr) is approximately equal to 0.33 millimeters in outer diameter. For example, a Foley catheter with a size of 16 Fr has an outer diameter of approximately 5.3 millimeters.
  • Therefore, the diameter of a catheter in millimeters can be determined by dividing the French size by 3.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A 16 French size of Foley’s catheter refers to the outer diameter of the catheter, which is 5.3mm.

questions.text: Secretin decreases which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastric secretion

 

  • Secretin is a hormone secreted by S cells of the duodenal mucosa in response to acidic chyme entering the small intestine from the stomach (pH < 4.5). It plays a key role in neutralizing gastric acid and coordinating the digestive process in the duodenum.
  • Key actions of Secretin:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CCK secretion: Incorrect. Secretin potentiates CCK effects, does not decrease its secretion.

 

Option B. Pancreatic secretion: Incorrect. Secretin stimulates (not inhibits) alkaline pancreatic secretion.

 

Option D. Tone of pyloric sphincter: Incorrect. Secretin increases the tone (not decreases), thus delaying gastric emptying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secretin plays a crucial role in buffering gastric acid in the duodenum by promoting bicarbonate-rich pancreatic and biliary secretions and inhibiting gastric acid production.
  • It helps maintain an optimal pH for enzyme function and intestinal protection.

questions.text: Emergency responders document multiple skin discolorations on a patient brought in after being discovered in an abandoned building. The distribution of the lesions raises concerns about possible fabrication of injuries. For medicolegal purposes, it is important to distinguish genuine ecchymosis from artificially applied injuries. Which of the following would be the most reliable clinical clue to help make this distinction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Color changes over time

 

  • The color changes over time seen in a true bruise (ecchymosis) are due to hemoglobin degradation and are a reliable feature distinguishing genuine bruises from artificial ones. 
  • A real bruise undergoes predictable transitions: red/purple (within hours), blue (1–3 days), green (4–6 days), yellow (7–10 days), and brown (by 10–14 days). 
  • This dynamic evolution of color reflects the progressive breakdown of hemoglobin into biliverdin and bilirubin and is not seen in artificial bruises created by dyes, irritants, or chemicals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Victim’s medical history: While relevant to a patient’s bleeding tendency (e.g., coagulopathies), it is not specific for distinguishing artificial from true bruises and does not provide direct evidence of injury authenticity.

 

Option C. Presence of underlying bone fractures: Though bone fractures can accompany blunt force trauma, their presence or absence doesn’t differentiate between genuine ecchymosis and artificial bruising. Many true bruises occur without associated bone injury.

 

Option D. Size of the bruise: Size may vary based on force and vascular fragility, but it lacks diagnostic specificity. Both artificial and true bruises can be small or large depending on how they are inflicted or simulated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Color changes over time are a hallmark of true bruises (ecchymosis) and help differentiate them from artificial lesions, which do not follow a sequential pattern of hemoglobin breakdown.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents for evaluation after developing multiple autoimmune manifestations including chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, autoimmune adrenalitis, and hypoparathyroidism. Genetic testing is initiated to determine the molecular basis of the immune dysregulation. Which of the following genes is most directly involved in ensuring central tolerance by allowing the immune system to recognize self-antigens presented in the thymus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AIRE

 

  • The Autoimmune Regulator (AIRE) gene plays a central role in thymic education by enabling medullary thymic epithelial cells to express peripheral tissue antigens. 
  • This process allows developing T-cells in the thymus to be exposed to self-antigens. If T-cells react strongly to these self-antigens, they undergo negative selection, preventing autoimmunity. 
  • Defects in the AIRE gene lead to a failure in self-tolerance and result in the autoimmune condition known as Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1 (APS-1), characterized by autoimmune destruction of multiple endocrine glands and chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.
  • This function of identifying and responding to molecules of the Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) in the thymus — as described — is precisely mediated by AIRE, which ensures that self-reactive T cells are eliminated before they can enter the circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NOTCH1: Incorrect. While NOTCH1 is involved in T-cell lineage commitment in the thymus, it does not play a role in MHC-mediated self-recognition or central tolerance. It is essential early in thymocyte differentiation but not in self-antigen recognition.

 

Option C. Rag 1/2: Incorrect. The Recombination Activating Genes (Rag 1 and 2) are responsible for V(D)J recombination, which is necessary for creating the diverse antigen receptor repertoire on T and B lymphocytes. However, they do not participate in the recognition of self-MHC or self-antigens presented in the thymus.

 

Option D. E2A: Incorrect. E2A encodes a transcription factor that helps regulate early B-cell and T-cell development, but it does not contribute to the negative selection or peripheral antigen expression needed for central immune tolerance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The AIRE gene is responsible for expressing peripheral tissue antigens in the thymus, enabling central tolerance by eliminating self-reactive T cells. 
  • Mutations in AIRE impair this process and can lead to widespread autoimmune diseases such as Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1 (APS-1).

questions.text:
Which amongst the following is a true statement regarding post term pregnancy? 

 

  1. This includes all pregnancies born after 280 days of pregnancy
  2. Recognized post term complications include oligohydramnios and fetal macrosomia
  3. Amniocentesis should be routinely done to confirm fetal lung maturity prior to induction of labor
  4. Initiation of fetal surveillance is recommended after 41 weeks of gestation
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 4

 

Statement 2. Recognized post term complications include oligohydramnios and fetal macrosomia: Recognized post term complications include oligohydramnios and fetal macrosomia. 

 

Statement 4. Initiation of fetal surveillance is recommended after 41 weeks of gestation: Initiation of fetal surveillance is recommended after 41 weeks of gestations

 

 

 

Incorrect statements:

 

Statement 1. This includes all pregnancies born after 280 days of pregnancy: Post term pregnancy is defined as pregnancy whose duration is > 294 days (> 42 weeks)

 

Statement 3. Amniocentesis should be routinely done to confirm fetal lung maturity prior to induction of labor: Amniocentesis for fetal lung maturity is not recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Complications of a post term pregnancy (> 42 weeks) include:

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with progressive memory loss and confusion for 18 months. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes. MMSE score is 22/30. CT brain shows diffuse cortical atrophy and CSF analysis shows low Aβ42 and elevated tau. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alzheimer’s disease

 

  • Progressive memory loss and low MMSE suggest a neurodegenerative dementia.
  • Low CSF Aβ42 and high tau are diagnostic biomarkers for AD.
  • Hypertension and diabetes increase AD risk but are not primary causes.
  • AD is the most common dementia in older adults.
  • CT brain usually reveals cortical atrophy but hippocampal atrophy on MRI is characteristic of Alzheimer’s disease (AD).
  • Clinical diagnosis is supported by imaging and CSF findings.
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil) are used for symptomatic relief.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vascular dementia: Vascular dementia shows stepwise decline and multifocal infarcts, not diffuse cortical atrophy.

 

Option C. Frontotemporal dementia: FTD presents with behavioral changes or language deficits, not memory loss.

 

Option D. Lewy body dementia: Lewy body dementia includes visual hallucinations and parkinsonism, absent here

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alzheimer’s disease is diagnosed by memory impairment, cortical (especially medial temporal/hippocampal) atrophy, and specific CSF biomarkers.

questions.text: A microbiology lab is working up a case of suspected fungal infection from an immunocompromised patient with oral thrush. A freshly collected specimen is inoculated into serum and incubated at 37°C for 2–3 hours. On microscopic examination, germ tube formation is observed as shown in the image below. This classic finding is diagnostic of which of the following fungal organisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida albicans

 

  • The Reynolds-Braude phenomenon refers to the formation of germ tubes when Candida albicans and Candida Dubliniensis is incubated in human or sheep serum at 37°C for 2–3 hours.
  • Germ tubes are tube-like outgrowths from yeast cells and are not constricted at the base, distinguishing them from pseudohyphae.
  • This is a rapid diagnostic test used to identify Candida albicans from other Candida species in clinical microbiology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candida psittaci: No such species; likely a distractor or confusion with Chlamydia psittaci. Not relevant to fungal germ tube testing.

 

Option C. Histoplasma: A dimorphic fungus that does not produce germ tubes; detected via intracellular yeast in macrophages.

 

Option D. Cryptococcus: Identified by its polysaccharide capsule (India ink or mucicarmine stain); does not form germ tubes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Reynolds-Braude phenomenon, or germ tube test, is a classic diagnostic feature of Candida albicans and helps differentiate it from other non-albicans Candida species.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with long-standing heart failure and atrial fibrillation is started on digoxin for rate control. Which of the following is not a recognized adverse effect of digitalis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mobitz type II heart block

 

  • Digoxin can cause any arrhythmia except Mobitz type II heart block and Atrial flutter 
  • Digoxin enhances vagal tone and inhibits the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase, leading to slowed AV conduction. 
  • Common ECG changes and adverse effects include:
    • Bradycardia
    • PR prolongation
    • Mobitz type I AV block (Wenckebach)
    • Visual disturbances, especially yellow vision (xanthopsia)
    • Ventricular ectopy (PVCs, bidirectional VT) at toxic levels
  • However, Mobitz type II AV block is typically a result of infranodal conduction disease (e.g., His-Purkinje system damage), not associated with digoxin. 
  • It is more dangerous and often requires pacemaker placement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mobitz type I heart block: Seen with digoxin due to vagal enhancement

 

Option C. Yellow vision: Classic manifestation of digoxin toxicity

 

Option D. Bradycardia: Common due to AV node suppression and vagotonic effects

 

Educational Objective:

 

Digoxin toxicity can cause brady arrhythmias, visual changes, GI upset, and characteristic ECG abnormalities (e.g., PR prolongation, scooped ST segments). However, Mobitz type II AV block is not typical and suggests another etiology.

choices.text: Start oral contraceptive pills and metformin
Initiate clomiphene citrate and lifestyle modification
Begin letrozole and weight loss counseling

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with irregular menses, hirsutism, and weight gain for 2 years. BMI is 30 kg/m², and BP is 140/90 mmHg. Serum testosterone is 80 ng/dL (normal 15-70), and fasting glucose is 110 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start oral contraceptive pills and metformin

 

  • Clinical features and lab findings meet Rotterdam criteria for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
  • Elevated testosterone confirms hyperandrogenism.
  • OCPs regulate menses and reduce androgen levels.
  • Metformin improves insulin resistance, common in PCOS, and aids weight loss.
  • Impaired fasting glucose suggests prediabetes, warranting metformin.
  • Weight loss is critical but requires pharmacologic support in PCOS.
  • Spironolactone is added for refractory hirsutism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Initiate clomiphene citrate and lifestyle modification: Clomiphene is for ovulation induction in infertility, not initial PCOS management.

 

Option C. Prescribe spironolactone and finasteride: Spironolactone and finasteride target hirsutism but not menstrual irregularity or insulin resistance.

 

Option D. Begin letrozole and weight loss counseling: Letrozole is used for ovulation induction, not general PCOS management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCPs and metformin address the core features of PCOS, including hyperandrogenism and insulin resistance.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a known diagnosis of bipolar disorder presents to the outpatient clinic. He acknowledges that he has bipolar disorder and understands his diagnosis completely. However, he has been very noncompliant with his medications, taking them only intermittently. He continues to use recreational drugs on and off despite having experienced multiple relapses triggered by drug use. He is reluctant to see his psychiatrist regularly and often misses appointments. Based on this presentation, what grade of insight does this patient have?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grade 4 - Intellectual insight

 

  • The patient demonstrates intellectual insight (Grade 4), which is characterized by awareness of illness without any accompanying changes in behavior. 
  • This patient clearly acknowledges and understands that he has bipolar disorder, showing awareness of his illness. However, this awareness has not translated into behavioral changes - he remains noncompliant with medications, continues substance use despite knowing it triggers relapses, and avoids regular psychiatric follow-up. 
  • This disconnect between knowledge and action is the hallmark of intellectual insight.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Grade 1 - Absent insight: This would apply if the patient completely denied having any problem or illness (e.g., "I don't have any problem"). This patient clearly acknowledges his bipolar disorder diagnosis.

 

Option B. Grade 2 - Partial insight: This involves some awareness of being sick but denying it at the same time (e.g., "At times, I hear some voices, but there is no illness"). This patient fully accepts his diagnosis without denial.

 

Option D. Grade 5 - Emotional insight: This represents the highest level of insight where awareness of illness is accompanied by appropriate behavioral changes (e.g., "I have schizophrenia, and I want to take regular medications to prevent any relapses"). This patient lacks the behavioral changes despite awareness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intellectual insight (Grade 4) represents a critical gap between understanding one's illness and implementing necessary behavioral changes, highlighting why assessment of insight must consider both cognitive awareness and actual behavior.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man reports chest discomfort and shortness of breath. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest reveals an anterior mediastinal mass. The Hounsfield Unit (HU) measurement of the lesion is −70 HU. Based on the radiologic findings and attenuation value, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Teratoma

 

  • On CT imaging, a Hounsfield Unit (HU) of −70 strongly indicates the presence of fat, as fat typically shows HU values between −100 to −50. 
  • Among anterior mediastinal masses, teratomas are germ cell tumors that frequently contain a mix of fat, fluid, soft tissue, and sometimes calcifications or teeth, making their HU highly variable — often including negative HU values due to fat. 
  • Key identifying clues in this case:
    • Anterior mediastinal location
    • Fat attenuation (−70 HU) — strongly supportive of a mature teratoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thymoma: Incorrect. Thymomas are the most common primary tumors of the anterior mediastinum, but they typically appear as solid soft tissue masses and do not contain fat, making −70 HU very unlikely.

 

Option B. Neurogenic tumor: Incorrect. These are typically located in the posterior mediastinum, not anterior, and do not contain fat. They usually demonstrate soft tissue HU.

 

Option D. Bronchogenic cyst: Incorrect. These are fluid-filled cysts, typically located in the middle mediastinum, with HU values closer to 0–20 HU, consistent with fluid, not fat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fat-containing anterior mediastinal mass with a Hounsfield Unit near −70 is most suggestive of a mature teratoma.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man with a ruptured spleen following blunt abdominal trauma is taken for emergency laparotomy. On arrival in the OR, his vital signs are:

 

  • Blood pressure: 80/50 mmHg
  • Heart rate: 125/min

 

He appears pale and diaphoretic. A rapid-acting induction agent is needed. Which of the following is the most appropriate induction agent for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ketamine

 

  • This patient is hypotensive and tachycardic, indicating hypovolemic shock from internal bleeding. 
  • The ideal anesthetic induction agent in this setting should:
    • Preserve or increase sympathetic tone
    • Maintain blood pressure and cardiac output
    • Have minimal respiratory depression
  • Ketamine is the agent of choice because it:
    • Is a NMDA receptor antagonist
    • Stimulates the sympathetic nervous system, increasing heart rate, blood pressure, and cardiac output
    • Maintains spontaneous respiration and airway reflexes
  • These properties make ketamine the preferred induction agent in hypotensive trauma patients.
  • Ketamine 
    • K – Drug of choice for kids
    • E – Emergence reaction 
    • T – Thalamocortical junction 
    • A – Analgesic 
    • M – Can be given in full stomach 
    • I – Increase blood pressure
    • N – NMDA blocker 
    • E – Excellent bronchodilator  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium Thiopentone: Causes vasodilation and myocardial depression, leading to further hypotension. Not suitable in hypovolemic shock.

 

Option B. Fentanyl: Potent opioid that can cause bradycardia and hypotension, especially when used for induction in unstable patients.

 

Option D. Halothane: A volatile anesthetic associated with myocardial depression and arrhythmias, and it lowers systemic vascular resistance, worsening hypotension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with hypovolemia and hypotension, ketamine is the induction agent of choice because of its sympathomimetic properties, which help maintain cardiovascular stability during anesthesia.

questions.text: A patient presents with scoliosis. X-ray is shown below. Identify the likely cause:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital 

 

  • This type of scoliosis occurs due to a malformation of one or more vertebrae during fetal development. This bone abnormality is present at birth, although the curve may not be noticeable until later in childhood.
  • The hallmark of congenital scoliosis on X-ray is the presence of vertebral anomalies. These can include: 
    • Hemivertebrae: A wedge-shaped vertebra that is only partially formed, leading to a sharp, angular curve. This is a very common cause of congenital scoliosis.
    • Congenital bars (unsegmented bar): A failure of segmentation of two or more vertebrae on one side, leading to a stiff, unyielding bar of bone that pulls the spine into a curve as growth occurs on the opposite side.
    • Block vertebrae: Two or more vertebrae that are fused together. While they can contribute to scoliosis, they are often less severe than hemivertebrae or unsegmented bars.
    • Wedge vertebrae: Vertebrae that are malformed in a wedge shape but are more fully formed than a hemivertebra.
  • If the X-ray you are seeing clearly shows abnormal vertebral shapes, fusions, or partially formed vertebrae, then congenital scoliosis is the most likely diagnosis. Congenital curves tend to be sharper and shorter than idiopathic curves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Idiopathic:

 

  • This is the most common type of scoliosis, accounting for about 80% of cases. "Idiopathic" means the cause is unknown. It typically appears during adolescence (adolescent idiopathic scoliosis, AIS) but can also occur in infantile (0-3 years) and juvenile (3-10 years) periods.
  • The vertebrae themselves generally appear normally formed.
    • The curve is often C-shaped or S-shaped.
    • There is typically no underlying bony anomaly visible on the X-ray. The diagnosis is made by ruling out other causes.
    • Associated findings might include vertebral rotation and rib humping.
  • If the X-ray shows vertebral malformations, then idiopathic scoliosis is less likely, as it's a diagnosis of exclusion when no other cause is found.

 

Option C. Neuromuscular:

 

  • This type of scoliosis results from abnormal muscle or nerve control over the spine, leading to weakened muscles that cannot support the spine properly, or muscle imbalances. It is associated with conditions like cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy, spinal muscular atrophy, or spina bifida.
  • Typical X-ray Findings: 
    • Often long, C-shaped curves that extend from the sacrum to the cervical spine.
    • Can be severe and progressive.
    • The vertebrae themselves are usually structurally normal.
    • Often associated with pelvic obliquity (pelvis is tilted).
    • The X-ray might show evidence of the underlying neurological condition (e.g., spina bifida defect).
  • If the primary finding is a vertebral anomaly, then neuromuscular scoliosis is less likely to be the direct cause, although a patient could theoretically have both.

 

Option D. Neurofibromatosis:

 

  • Neurofibromatosis (NF) is a genetic disorder that affects the growth of cells in the nervous system, causing tumors (neurofibromas) to grow on nerves. Scoliosis is a common musculoskeletal manifestation of NF, particularly NF1.
  • Typical X-ray Findings: 
  • Can present as either dystrophic or non-dystrophic curves.
  • Dystrophic curves are highly characteristic of NF and involve vertebral anomalies and rib changes. These can include: 
    • Vertebral scalloping (erosion of the vertebral body).
    • Ribbon ribs (thin, elongated ribs).
    • Dural ectasia (enlargement of the spinal canal due to CSF accumulation).
    • Vertebral dysplasia or rotation.
    • Sharp, angular curves.
  • Non-dystrophic curves in NF look similar to idiopathic scoliosis (normally formed vertebrae).
  • If the X-ray shows severe, sharp, angular curves with associated vertebral and rib anomalies, it could be neurofibromatosis.
  • However, if the primary anomaly is a specific vertebral malformation like a hemivertebra without other typical NF stigmata (like ribbon ribs or severe scalloping), congenital scoliosis might be the more precise diagnosis.
  • If the X-ray specifically shows signs of vertebral erosion or peculiar rib anomalies, then Neurofibromatosis would be a strong contender.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital curves tend to be sharper and shorter than idiopathic curves.

questions.text: GNP minus capital we consume is known as:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) NNP

 

  • GNP (Gross National Product) refers to the total market value of all final goods and services produced by the residents of a country in a given time period, including income from abroad.
  • When you subtract the capital consumed (i.e., depreciation) from GNP, the result is Net National Product (NNP).
  • Capital consumption refers to the wear and tear or depreciation of fixed assets like machinery, buildings, etc.

 

So:

 

GNP – Depreciation = NNP

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GDP (Gross Domestic Product): It is total income generated within a country. Refers to the total value of goods and services produced within the borders of a country, regardless of who owns the resources. It does not account for depreciation and is not derived by subtracting capital consumption from GNP.

 

Option B. NDP (Net Domestic Product): This is GDP minus depreciation, not GNP. It reflects the net output of the domestic economy, excluding wear and tear on capital goods.

 

NDP = GDP - Depreciation

 

Option C. GNP (Gross National Product): This is the starting point in the formula and not the result. GNP includes income from abroad but does not subtract depreciation. GDP + income from abroad

 

GNP = GDP + income from abroad

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Net National Product (NNP) is derived by subtracting depreciation (capital consumption) from Gross National Product (GNP).
    NNP = GNP – Depreciation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with edema, hypertension, and hematuria for 2 months. He has a history of diabetes and smoking. Serum creatinine is 2.8 mg/dL, and urine protein is 3.5 g/day. Renal biopsy and immunofluorescence is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ANCA related nephritis

 

  • Hematuria, proteinuria, and crescents in biopsy with a negative immunofluorescence suggest RPGN with pauci-immune GN.
  • Pauci-immune GN is often ANCA-associated (e.g., GPA, MPA).
  • Hypertension and edema reflect glomerular injury and fluid retention.
  • Diabetes may contribute but is not the primary cause.
  • Immunosuppression (steroids, cyclophosphamide) is required urgently.
  • Renal biopsy is diagnostic in RPGN.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic nephropathy: Diabetic nephropathy shows nodular sclerosis, not crescents.

 

Option B. IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy presents with mesangial deposits (granular IgA+) in immunofluorescence.

 

Option C. Anti-GBM disease: Anti-GBM disease usually produces a smooth/linear (IgG+) immunofluorescence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis is a common cause of RPGN and requires urgent immunosuppression.

questions.text:
Match the Following: Supraglottic Airway Devices

 

Column A (Devices)

  1. LMA Supreme
  2. LMA Proseal
  3. LMA Fastrach
  4. Ambu AURA40

 

Column B (Features)

  1. First-generation device
  2. Special LMA 
  3. Single-use second-generation device
  4. Multiple-use second-generation device
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

  • LMA Supreme → Single-use second-generation device
  • LMA Proseal → Multiple-use second-generation device
  • LMA Fastrach → Special LMA designed for intubation
  • Ambu AURA40 → First-generation device

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • LMA Supreme → Single-use second-generation device
  • LMA Proseal → Multiple-use second-generation device
  • LMA Fastrach → Special LMA designed for intubation
  • Ambu AURA40 → First-generation device

choices.text: 2nd MC primary malignant hepatic tumor
Arises from intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
Risk factors include infestation by liver flukes, primary sclerosing cholangitis, hepatolithiasis and fibropolycystic liver disease.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with progressive jaundice, pruritus, and dark-colored urine for the past 3 weeks. He denies alcohol use or viral hepatitis. Physical exam reveals scleral icterus and hepatomegaly. Imaging shows a mass at the hepatic duct bifurcation causing biliary obstruction. Biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma of the biliary tract as shown in the image below. Which of the following is incorrect about this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Very good prognosis     

 

  • Cholangiocarcinoma is the second most common primary malignant tumor of the liver after HCC and its Prognosis is extremely poor.
  • Klatskin tumor, is a malignancy of the bile ducts occurring at the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts (hilar region).
  • Cholangiocarcinomas are typical mucin-producing adenocarcinomas inciting desmoplasia. 
  • Cholangiocarcinoma unfortunately carries a poor prognosis, especially when diagnosed at a late stage. Even with surgical resection, long-term survival is limited. The 5-year survival is low, particularly for unresectable cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2nd MC primary malignant hepatic tumor: This is a correct statement. Cholangiocarcinoma is indeed the second most common primary malignancy of the liver, following hepatocellular carcinoma. This makes the statement factually accurate and not the incorrect choice.

 

Option B. Arises from intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts: Correct. Cholangiocarcinoma may originate from the intrahepatic bile ducts, perihilar ducts (Klatskin tumors), or distal extrahepatic ducts, making this statement true and not the answer.

 

Option C. Risk factors include infestation by liver flukes, primary sclerosing cholangitis, hepatolithiasis and fibropolycystic liver disease. Accurate. Several risk factors are well-documented, including Opisthorchis viverrini and Clonorchis sinensis (liver flukes), primary sclerosing cholangitis, intrahepatic stones (hepatolithiasis), and congenital fibropolycystic liver disease such as Caroli disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cholangiocarcinoma, though the second most common primary hepatic malignancy, typically carries a poor prognosis due to late diagnosis and aggressive local spread, making early recognition and intervention critical.

questions.text: A patient has a blood pressure reading of 130/85 mmHg. What is the approximate mean arterial pressure (MAP)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 100 mmHg

 

  • Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) is the average pressure in the arteries during one cardiac cycle. 
  • It is not a simple average, because the heart spends more time in diastole than in systole.
  • Formula used is:
    1/3 SBP – 2/3 DBP = 1/3 x 130 + 2/3 x 85 =  43.3 + 56.7 = 100 mm Hg
    OR 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MAP reflects the perfusion pressure experienced by organs. 
  • It is crucial in assessing organ perfusion, especially in shock or hypotension. 
  • A MAP of ≥65 mmHg is generally considered necessary for adequate tissue perfusion in critically ill patients.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female from Bihar presents with fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance for 6 months. She has a history of delivery complicated by hypotension that required multiple blood transfusions 5 years ago. TSH is 0.1 mIU/L, free T4 0.6 ng/dL, and prolactin is low. The thyroid ultrasound reveals a small, hypoechoic gland. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sheehan’s syndrome

 

  • Postpartum hemorrhage increases risk of pituitary infarction (Sheehan’s syndrome).
  • Low TSH, free T4, and prolactin suggest central hypothyroidism due to pituitary failure.
  • Small, hypoechoic thyroid on ultrasound reflects atrophy from lack of TSH stimulation.
  • Fatigue and cold intolerance are consistent with hypothyroidism.
  • India’s high maternal morbidity makes Sheehan’s syndrome a relevant diagnosis.
  • Hormone replacement (levothyroxine, hydrocortisone) is required.
  • Pituitary MRI may confirm empty sella or infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis: Hashimoto’s thyroiditis causes elevated TSH and positive anti-TPO antibodies, not low prolactin.

 

Option C. Subacute thyroiditis: Subacute thyroiditis is painful and transient, with normal pituitary function.

 

Option D. Thyroid carcinoma: Thyroid carcinoma presents with nodules, not diffuse atrophy or hypopituitarism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan’s syndrome should be suspected in hypothyroidism with a history of postpartum hemorrhage in India.

choices.text: Corneal edema caused by laser energy absorption
Inflammatory debris blocking the trabecular meshwork
Ciliary body inflammation reducing aqueous outflow
Damage to Schlemm’s canal causing impaired drainage

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) undergoes argon laser trabeculoplasty to help reduce intraocular pressure and limit the need for multiple medications. Shortly after the procedure, he develops a sudden rise in intraocular pressure (IOP). Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inflammatory debris blocking the trabecular meshwork

 

  • Laser trabeculoplasty is commonly performed in POAG to improve aqueous outflow via the trabecular meshwork.
  • One recognized early complication is a transient rise in IOP, typically within hours post-procedure.
  • This rise is due to inflammatory cells and pigment dispersion, which clog the trabecular meshwork, temporarily reducing aqueous humor drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corneal edema caused by laser energy absorption: Incorrect.  Corneal edema may occur but does not typically cause IOP elevation this acutely.

 

Option C. Ciliary body inflammation reducing aqueous outflow: Incorrect. Inflammation of the ciliary body usually leads to decreased aqueous production, which would lower IOP, not raise it.

 

Option D. Damage to Schlemm’s canal causing impaired drainage: Incorrect. The laser does not directly target Schlemm’s canal and it's uncommon for trabeculoplasty to structurally damage it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Following laser trabeculoplasty, a transient rise in IOP may occur due to inflammatory debris or pigment blocking the trabecular meshwork. 
  • Pretreatment with IOP-lowering agents and anti-inflammatory drops can help prevent this.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with vaginal spotting and lower abdominal pain. Transvaginal ultrasound shows no intrauterine or extrauterine gestational sac. Her serum β-hCG is 700 mIU/mL. What is the current diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pregnancy of unknown location

 

  • This is the appropriate diagnosis when no gestational sac is visible in either the uterus or extrauterine sites, and the β-hCG level is below the discriminatory zone (typically <1500–2000 mIU/mL for transvaginal ultrasound).
    • At this point, it's not possible to determine if the pregnancy is:
    • A very early intrauterine pregnancy
    • An early ectopic pregnancy
    • Or a complete abortion
  • Serial β-hCG testing every 48 hours is essential:
    • A doubling β-hCG suggests viable IUP.
    • Plateauing or slow rise suggests ectopic.
    • Falling β-hCG suggests failing pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unruptured ectopic pregnancy: While an ectopic is on the differential, there’s no evidence of an extrauterine sac on scan and β-hCG is below the discriminatory zone. Thus, this cannot be the diagnosis at this stage.

 

Option B. Viable early intrauterine pregnancy: A possibility, but cannot be confirmed because no intrauterine sac is seen and β-hCG is below detection threshold for transvaginal US. Still categorized as PUL.

 

Option C. Missed abortion: This diagnosis requires prior documentation of an intrauterine pregnancy with fetal demise. In this case, there is no evidence of an intrauterine sac, so this option is excluded.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregnancy of unknown location (PUL) is diagnosed when no intra- or extrauterine sac is visible and serum β-hCG is below the discriminatory threshold; serial β-hCG and repeat ultrasound are required for clarification.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of chronic constipation and antipsychotics use, presents with severe abdominal pain, distension and obstipation for the past 24 hours. Examination reveals a markedly distended and tympanic abdomen. Imaging shows a bent inner tube sign. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CECT abdomen

 

  • The patient is diagnosed to have sigmoid volvulus. 
  • Although plain X-ray suggests the diagnosis, CECT is valuable to assess bowel viability, rule out ischemia or perforation, and guide urgency of intervention.
  • Especially useful when endoscopic decompression is not immediately available or prior to referral for endoscopy or surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exploratory laparotomy: Too invasive for first-line

 

  • Too invasive for first-line
  • Reserved for cases of bowel gangrene, peritonitis, or failed non-operative decompression.
  • Not indicated in stable patients without signs of systemic toxicity.

 

Option C. USG abdomen: Low diagnostic value in volvulus

 

  • Low diagnostic value in volvulus
  • Poor visualization due to gas-distended bowel loops.
  • Not a reliable tool for colonic pathologies like volvulus.

 

Option D. High-pressure enema: Incorrect for volvulus

 

  • Incorrect for volvulus
  • Enemas are primarily therapeutic in pediatric intussusception, not for colonic volvulus.
  • The gold standard for decompression in volvulus is endoscopic detorsion, not hydrostatic reduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CECT abdomen, as it helps confirm diagnosis and evaluate complications in the absence of endoscopy.
  • While colonoscopic decompression is definitive, it’s not one of the options given, and CECT provides the safest, next best step in this context.

choices.text: The spleen is situated in the upper left quadrant of the abdomen beneath the diaphragm
The long axis of the spleen lies along the 10th rib
A pathologically enlarged spleen extends downward and forward, toward the left iliac fossa
The spleen has a notched anterior border caused by incomplete fusion of its parts during development

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was admitted for a large abdominal swelling. A clinical diagnosis of splenomegaly was made. Which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A pathologically enlarged spleen extends downward and forward, toward the left iliac fossa

 

  • The spleen is located in the left hypochondrium, under the 9th to 11th ribs, posterior to the stomach and anterior to the diaphragm. It extends toward the right iliac fossa
  • Its long axis lies along the 10th rib, extending obliquely downward, forward, and laterally, not medially or strictly downward.
  • While clinically an enlarged spleen may be palpable towards the left iliac fossa, its anatomical axis prevents direct downward extension due to the phrenicocolic ligament and the left colic flexure, which form a support preventing vertical descent.
  • Instead, the spleen enlarges obliquely, displacing medially and downwards — not in a straight vertical or iliac fossa-directed path.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. The spleen is situated in the upper left quadrant of the abdomen beneath the diaphragm: True. The spleen lies beneath the left dome of the diaphragm, in the left hypochondrium.

 

Option B. The long axis of the spleen lies along the 10th rib: True. Anatomically, the long axis runs obliquely along the 10th rib.

 

Option D. The spleen has a notched anterior border caused by incomplete fusion of its parts during development: True. The notch on the anterior border is a remnant of the embryonic lobulated development of the spleen.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The spleen lies in the left upper quadrant, aligned along the 10th rib, and has a notched anterior border due to its embryological origin. 
  • While splenomegaly may clinically appear to extend into the left iliac fossa, the phrenicocolic ligament restricts its downward expansion, making this a misleading but anatomically incorrect statement.

questions.text: Patient presented with Paresthesia and loss of sensation over lower part of deltoid. X-ray showed fracture surgical neck of humerus. Likely nerve to be involved is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Axillary nerve

 

  • Motor Function: Innervates the deltoid muscle and teres minor muscle.
  • Sensory Function: Provides sensation to the skin over the lower part of the deltoid.
  • The axillary nerve wraps around the surgical neck of the humerus in close proximity to the bone. Therefore, a fracture at this site puts the axillary nerve at high risk of injury, either from direct trauma, compression, or stretching. 
  • Damage to the axillary nerve would lead to weakness or paralysis of the deltoid (affecting shoulder abduction) and sensory deficits in the "regimental badge area." 
  • The patient's symptoms of "Paresthesia and loss of sensation over lower part of deltoid" perfectly align with axillary nerve involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Musculocutaneous Nerve:

 

  • Motor Function: Primarily innervates the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm (biceps brachii, brachialis, coracobrachialis).
  • Sensory Function: Provides sensation to the lateral forearm (via the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm).
  • The musculocutaneous nerve is not typically injured in a surgical neck fracture of the humerus, and its sensory distribution is not over the deltoid.

 

Option C. Radial Nerve:

 

  • Motor Function: Innervates the triceps brachii (posterior arm) and all the extensors of the wrist and fingers (posterior forearm), and supinator.
  • Sensory Function: Provides sensation to the posterior arm, posterior forearm, and the dorsum of the hand (thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the ring finger).
  • The radial nerve is most commonly injured in fractures of the mid-shaft of the humerus (spiral groove), not typically the surgical neck. Its sensory distribution is also different.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • Motor Function: Primarily innervates most intrinsic hand muscles (except some thenar muscles) and the medial two lumbricals, flexor carpi ulnaris, and medial half of flexor digitorum profundus.
  • Sensory Function: Provides sensation to the medial 1.5 fingers (little finger and medial half of the ring finger) and the medial aspect of the hand.
  • The ulnar nerve is most vulnerable at the elbow (medial epicondyle, "funny bone") and the wrist. It is not typically involved in a surgical neck fracture of the humerus, and its sensory distribution is in the hand, not the deltoid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the location of the fracture (surgical neck of the humerus) and the specific symptoms (paresthesia and loss of sensation over the lower part of the deltoid), the Axillary nerve is overwhelmingly the most likely nerve to be involved due to its close anatomical relationship to this bone region and its sensory supply to the very area described.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Vigabatrin can cause visual field loss.

 

Reason (R): Vigabatrin inhibits GABA transaminase.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A

 

Assertion (A): “Vigabatrin can cause visual field loss.” — this statement is true. Vigabatrin, an anticonvulsant medication, is known to cause visual field loss, most characteristically bilateral concentric peripheral visual field constriction (“tunnel vision”). This adverse effect is well documented, and regular ophthalmologic monitoring is recommended for patients receiving vigabatrin to detect this toxicity early.

 

Reason (R): “Vigabatrin inhibits GABA transaminase.” — this statement is also true. Vigabatrin works pharmacologically by irreversibly inhibiting GABA transaminase, the enzyme that breaks down gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), thereby increasing GABA levels in the central nervous system. This action is the fundamental reason for its antiepileptic activity.

 

In this context, R is the correct explanation of A because inhibition of GABA transaminase leads to excessive GABA accumulation, which may exert neurotoxic effects on retinal cells, especially the retinal ganglion cells, by disrupting normal neurotransmitter balance in the retina. This neurotoxicity is considered a contributing factor in the development of vigabatrin-associated visual field loss. Thus, while there may be other pathways, the primary pharmacologic action of GABA transaminase inhibition underlies the mechanism that leads to the visual field toxicity observed. Therefore, both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A, supporting option (a) as correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vigabatrin can cause visual field loss because it inhibits GABA transaminase, increasing GABA levels and contributing to retinal neurotoxicity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is being evaluated for suspected secondary syphilis. His VDRL test returns negative, but the clinical suspicion remains high due to symptoms and risk factors. A repeat test on a diluted serum sample returns positive. This discrepancy is most likely explained by which of the following immunological phenomena?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prozone phenomenon

 

  • Marrack's Lattice hypothesis – The amount of antibody should be equal to antigen then maximum amount of precipitation or agglutination will take place 
  • The Prozone phenomenon occurs when there is an excess of antibodies relative to antigen in a serological test.
  • In tests like VDRL or RPR (non-treponemal tests for syphilis), this antibody excess interferes with lattice formation, preventing visible precipitation or agglutination.
  • As a result, the test appears falsely negative despite active disease.
  • Dilution of the sample reduces antibody concentration, restoring the antigen-antibody ratio and yielding a true positive result.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postzone phenomenon: Occurs when there is excess antigen, not antibody, also causing false negatives but in antigen-heavy contexts like rapid tests.

 

Option B. High-dose hook effect: Seen in some immunoassays (e.g., pregnancy or tumor marker tests) where extremely high analyte levels saturate the detection system and prevent signal generation.

 

Option C. Antigenic drift: Refers to gradual mutation of viral antigens, such as in influenza, not related to antibody excess or serologic testing failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Prozone phenomenon refers to a false-negative serological test result due to antibody excess, which prevents visible reaction; dilution of the sample can restore test accuracy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a skin biopsy showing disruption of cell-to-cell adhesion within a specific layer of the epidermis. The biopsy highlights a layer of polygonal cells with desmosomal bridges. Which layer of the epidermis demonstrates the most prominent desmosomes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Layer C

 

  • The Stratum spinosum, also known as the prickle cell layer, contains prominent desmosomes. 
  • These desmosomal connections appear as "spines" under the microscope, giving the layer its characteristic prickly appearance. 
  • This layer is responsible for maintaining cell-to-cell adhesion, which is critical for the skin's structural integrity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Layer D (Stratum basale): This is the deepest layer of the epidermis, where keratinocytes are actively dividing, but desmosomes are not as prominent as in the spinous layer.

 

Option C. Layer A (Stratum corneum): This is the outermost layer composed of keratinized, dead, enucleate cells and does not have desmosomes.

 

Option D. Layer B (Stratum granulosum): This layer contains keratohyaline granules but lacks prominent desmosomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Stratum spinosum is the epidermal layer with the most prominent desmosomes. 
  • These intercellular connections provide mechanical strength and are essential for epidermal integrity. 
  • Desmosomal disruption can result in blistering diseases like pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of a persistent lump in her right breast. She first noticed the lump 3 months ago, and it has progressively increased in size. The lump is now approximately 6 cm x 4 cm. On examination, there is evident skin ulceration over the lump and fixity to P. Major and ribs. Based on the clinical findings, which TNM staging best categorizes the tumor in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T4c

 

  • T4c: Tumor involves both the chest wall and the skin (combination of T4a and T4b). 
  • In this case, fixity to underlying structures and skin ulceration both exist—this matches T4c.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. T4a: Tumor invades chest wall (e.g., ribs, intercostal muscles, or serratus anterior), but not skin.  Fixity to pectoralis major doesn't count as chest wall invasion alone unless it's deeper.

 

Option B. T4b: Tumor involves skin only, presenting with ulceration, satellite nodules, or skin edema (not the same as inflammatory breast cancer). Skin ulceration alone would qualify, without chest wall involvement.

 

Option D. T4d: Tumor presents as inflammatory breast cancer—diffuse erythema and edema (peau d’orange) involving most of the breast, often without a distinct mass. 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following coagulation factors contains γ-carboxyglutamate residues that are decreased in a patient receiving warfarin therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor II (Prothrombin)

 

  • Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant that inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase, preventing the regeneration of active (reduced) vitamin K. This halts the γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues on vitamin K–dependent clotting factors, which is necessary for their calcium binding and function.
  • The affected clotting factors are:
    • Factor II (Prothrombin)
    • Factor VII
    • Factor IX
    • Factor X
    • Also: Protein C and Protein S
  • Prothrombin (Factor II) requires this modification to bind phospholipid surfaces during clot formation. Without γ-carboxylation, it remains inactive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor V: Incorrect. Not vitamin K–dependent. Its function does not rely on γ-carboxyglutamate residues.

 

Option C. Factor XI: Incorrect. Also, not vitamin K–dependent. Synthesized in the liver but does not require γ-carboxylation.

 

Option D. Fibrinogen: Incorrect. This is Factor I, the precursor of fibrin, and is not affected by vitamin K status.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin inhibits vitamin K–dependent γ-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, with prothrombin (Factor II) being one of the key affected proteins.

choices.text: Both values are within permissible WHO limits
Beta activity is unsafe; alpha is within permissible range
Alpha activity exceeds WHO guideline, beta is borderline
Both alpha and beta levels exceed the national limit

questions.text:
A water quality test reveals the following levels:

  • Gross alpha activity: 0.7 Bq/L
  • Gross beta activity: 0.9 Bq/L

Which of the following statements is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alpha activity exceeds WHO guideline, beta is borderline

 

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) provides screening guidelines for radioactivity in drinking water to determine if more detailed analysis is needed. The key values are:
    • Gross Alpha Activity: ≤ 0.5 Bq/L
    • Gross Beta Activity: ≤ 1.0 Bq/L
  • In this case:
    • Gross alpha activity is 0.7 Bq/L, which exceeds the WHO screening level of 0.5 Bq/L, indicating a need for further radionuclide-specific testing.
    • Gross beta activity is 0.9 Bq/L, which is within limits but approaching the cutoff, hence described as borderline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Key Guideline Aspects Recommended Drinking Water Quality: 
    • Colour < 15 true colour units (TCU) [< 5 Hazen units]
    • Turbidity < 1 nephlometric turbidity units (NTU)
    • Hardness < 100–300 mg/litre calcium ion
    • pH: 6.5–8.5
    • Total dissolved solids (TDS) < 500 mg/litre (BIS 2017)
    • Zero pathogenic microorganisms
    • Zero infectious viruses
    • Absence of pathogenic protozoa and infective stages of helminthes
    • Fluoride < 1 ppm (0.5–0.8 ppm: Optimum level)
    • Nitrates < 45 mg/litre
    • Nitrites < 3 mg/litre
    • Gross alpha radiological activity < 0.5 Bq/litre [New Guideline — WHO]
    • Gross beta radiological activity < 1.0 Bq/litre [New Guideline — WHO]

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy from a remote Indian village is brought to the community health center with complaints of brown staining and pitting of the upper front teeth. The history reveals the child has been drinking groundwater from a local well since infancy. Based on this, what is the expected nutrient level in the drinking water from the well?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) > 1.5 ppm

 

  • The child presents with brown staining and pitting of the upper front teeth, classic features of dental fluorosis, which is caused by excessive fluoride intake during tooth development. 
  • Fluorine is first detected in upper central incisors
  • The child is from a remote village and has been consuming groundwater from a local well since infancy—common risk factors for fluoride overexposure in endemic regions.
  • According to public health standards:
    • Fluoride concentration >1.5 ppm in drinking water is known to cause dental fluorosis.
    • The severity of symptoms (brown stains and enamel pitting) supports chronic exposure above the safe upper limit but does not definitively confirm levels as high as 3.0–6.0 ppm or >10 ppm, which are associated with more advanced dental and skeletal fluorosis.
  • Hence, based on the child’s symptoms and environmental exposure, the expected fluoride level in drinking water is greater than 1.5 ppm, making Option B the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.5 – 0.8 ppm: Incorrect. This is the optimal fluoride concentration in drinking water to prevent dental caries without causing fluorosis. It is below the threshold associated with any fluorosis.

 

Option C. 3.0 – 6.0 ppm: Incorrect. Fluoride concentrations in this range are typically associated with moderate to severe fluorosis, including more pronounced discoloration and enamel damage. This level is not required to produce the findings in the current case. Skeletal fluorosis

 

Option D. > 10 ppm: Incorrect. Extremely high fluoride levels above 10 ppm are rare and generally cause severe dental and skeletal fluorosis, which is not evident in this child’s current presentation. Crippling fluorosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dental fluorosis occurs when fluoride levels in drinking water exceed 1.5 ppm, especially during tooth development. 
  • Brown staining and pitting are common signs. This threshold is crucial for community health assessments involving groundwater safety.

choices.text: Ketogenesis occurs in the mitochondria of hepatocytes
Ketogenesis is exaggerated in diabetes mellitus and prolonged starvation. It is termed as Ketosis

questions.text: Ketogenesis is biochemical reaction in which ketone bodies are synthesized in the liver through the degradation of free fatty acids and ketogenic amino acids. Which statement about ketogenesis is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ketone bodies are utilized by hepatocytes

 

“Ketone bodies are utilized by hepatocytes.” This is false, because although hepatocytes synthesize ketone bodies, they do not utilize them. This is because hepatocytes lack the enzyme succinyl-CoA: acetoacetate CoA transferase (thiophorase), which is required for converting ketone bodies back to acetyl-CoA for energy. Therefore, the liver releases ketone bodies into the bloodstream to be used by extrahepatic tissues such as the brain, skeletal muscle, and heart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ketogenesis occurs in the mitochondria of hepatocytes: Correct. The synthesis of ketone bodies takes place in the mitochondrial matrix of liver cells (hepatocytes), utilizing enzymes such as HMG-CoA synthase and HMG-CoA lyase. Mitochondrial localization is essential for the efficient execution of this metabolic pathway.

 

Option C. Ketosis can deplete the alkali reserve: Correct. When ketone body levels rise excessively (as in diabetic ketoacidosis or prolonged fasting), the condition is termed ketosis, and it can deplete bicarbonate (alkali reserve) in the blood, leading to metabolic acidosis. This is a clinically significant consequence of dysregulated ketogenesis.

 

Option D. Ketogenesis is exaggerated in diabetes mellitus and prolonged starvation. It is termed as Ketosis: Correct. In uncontrolled diabetes mellitus (especially type 1), lack of insulin and increased counter-regulatory hormones (like glucagon) stimulate lipolysis and subsequently enhanced ketogenesis, leading to ketosis. Similarly, prolonged starvation creates a state where the body shifts to ketone body production to meet energy demands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocytes cannot utilize ketone bodies due to lack of the enzyme thiophorase; hence, while ketogenesis occurs in liver mitochondria, the synthesized ketone bodies are exported for use by extrahepatic tissues.

choices.text: It is a type of osseomyocutaneous flap
Blood supply is isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected
It is not suitable for head and neck reconstruction

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes this type of flap?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blood supply is isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected.

 

  • The image represents a radial forearm free flap, which is a type of free flap used in reconstructive surgery.
  • In a free flap, the vascular supply is completely detached from its original site and then re-anastomosed using microvascular surgery at the recipient site.
  • Other examples of free flaps include deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap and free fibular flap.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a random flap: Incorrect. A random flap has no specific blood vessel supplying it and relies on dermal-subdermal plexus, unlike a free flap, which has a defined vascular pedicle.

 

Option B. It is a type of osseomyocutaneous flap: Incorrect. This is not a osseo-myocutaneous flap indeed this is a fascio-cutaneous flap 

 

Option D. It is not suitable for head and neck reconstruction: This is incorrect as radial forearm flap is commonly used for head and neck reconstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A free flap, such as the radial forearm free flap, involves isolating, disconnecting, and reattaching the vascular supply using microsurgery, making it essential for complex reconstructive procedures requiring vascularized tissue transfer.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with restricted wrist movements following a fall. Radiographic examination shows no fractures, but joint integrity appears intact. Which type of joint is primarily responsible for the wrist's restricted movement?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ellipsoid joint

 

  • The wrist joint (radiocarpal joint) is an ellipsoid joint, characterized by concave-convex articulation, allowing multi-axial movement with some restrictions, particularly in hyperextension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hinge joint: Allows movement only in one plane (uniaxial), seen in the elbow and interphalangeal joints.

 

Option C. Ball and socket joint: Permits free movement in all axes, such as the shoulder or hip joints.

 

Option D. Plane joint: Permits gliding movements, as seen in intercarpal and intertarsal joints.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The wrist joint is an ellipsoid joint, enabling restricted multi-axial movement due to its convex-concave surfaces.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common method used to know the depth of anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BIS 

 

  • The Bispectral Index (BIS) is an objective, EEG-derived parameter that provides a numerical estimate of the depth of anesthesia, making it the most commonly used monitor for this purpose in modern anesthetic practice.
  • BIS uses a processed EEG signal, incorporating multiple subcomponents like beta ratio, burst suppression ratio, and synchronization measures, to generate a dimensionless value between 0 and 100.
  • A BIS value of 40–60 is typically targeted during general anesthesia to ensure adequate hypnotic depth while minimizing the risk of awareness.
  • Advantages of BIS:
    • Quantitative and continuous monitoring
    • Reduces the risk of intraoperative awareness
    • Helps titrate anesthetic agents more precisely, avoiding over- or underdosing
    • Can aid in faster recovery and reduced drug consumption

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Esophageal contractility: Not a standard or reliable method to assess anesthetic depth. Esophageal activity may decrease under deep anesthesia but is not routinely monitored for this purpose.

 

Option C. Depressed responses: This refers to loss of physiological responses (e.g., movement, reflexes), which is a subjective and indirect measure. While it offers some information, it does not provide real-time or quantitative monitoring like BIS.

 

Option D. Blood pressure (BP): BP can decrease with anesthesia due to vasodilation or myocardial depression, but it's affected by many factors including fluid status, pain, and medications. Thus, it is not a reliable indicator of depth of anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Bispectral Index (BIS) is a reliable, quantitative, and commonly used method to monitor the depth of anesthesia based on processed EEG signals. It helps avoid intraoperative awareness and enables precise titration of anesthetic agents.

questions.text: A rural hospital with no incinerator wants to manage disposal of placenta after deliveries. Which of the following is the best suited mode of disposal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Deep burial

 

  • In healthcare facilities without incinerators, particularly in rural or resource-limited settings, the most suitable and approved method for disposing of anatomical waste such as the placenta is deep burial. 
  • According to biomedical waste management guidelines, deep burial is allowed where there is no access to high-temperature treatment facilities (like incineration or pyrolysis), and placental waste is considered category 1 anatomical waste.
  • The burial must be in a designated, fenced area, at a depth of at least 2 meters, and far from any water sources. The site should be marked and monitored to prevent scavenging and contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasma pyrolysis: Though effective for high-grade biomedical waste, plasma pyrolysis is a high-cost, high-tech method not suitable for rural hospitals without the required infrastructure. It is typically used in urban settings or tertiary care centers with advanced waste management capabilities.

 

Option B. Chemical treatment: This method is appropriate for liquid waste or microbiological waste, but not recommended for large-volume anatomical waste such as placenta. It is ineffective in rendering such tissues safe and does not provide complete degradation.

 

Option D. Dry burning: This refers to open burning, which is not a recommended biomedical waste disposal method, particularly for anatomical waste like placenta. It results in incomplete combustion and significant air pollution, and does not ensure hygienic handling of tissue waste.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In rural healthcare settings lacking incineration facilities, deep burial is the most appropriate method for safe disposal of placenta and other anatomical waste, in accordance with biomedical waste management protocols.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is most commonly used for the inactivation of viruses in the preparation of vaccines?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta propiolactone

 

  • Beta propiolactone (BPL) is a highly effective alkylating agent used for the inactivation of viruses and other pathogens during vaccine production.
  • It acts by modifying nucleic acids, rendering the virus non-infectious while preserving antigenic structure, making it ideal for inactivated (killed) vaccines.
  • It is used in vaccines like rabies and influenza.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethylene oxide: A gaseous sterilizing agent used for medical instruments, not for vaccine preparation due to residual toxicity and lack of specificity.

 

Option B. Formaldehyde: It is a form of gas/liquid (formalin).Commonly used for vaccine inactivation (e.g., in polio and hepatitis A), but it acts more slowly and can alter antigenicity. Replaced here to emphasize BPL's specific and efficient action.

 

Option D. Isopropyl alcohol: Used as a surface disinfectant; does not reliably inactivate all pathogens, especially viruses in vaccines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta propiolactone is a potent inactivating agent used in vaccine production that inactivates viruses by damaging their nucleic acids while preserving antigenic properties.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive dyspnea and dry cough for 6 months. He works as a construction worker and smokes 10 cigarettes daily. HRCT chest is shown below. PFTs show restrictive pattern with DLCO 40% predicted. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Refer for lung biopsy

 

  • HRCT findings of diffuse ground glass opacities suggest ILD.
  • Restrictive PFTs and low DLCO support ILD diagnosis.
  • Construction work increases risk of pneumoconiosis or hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Ground glassing can also be due to CTD related ILD.
  • Lung biopsy (VATS or transbronchial) is needed for definitive diagnosis in ambiguous ILD cases like these.
  • Smoking cessation is essential but not diagnostic.
  • Steroids cannot be started without a definitive diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start empirical antitubercular therapy: TB is unlikely without systemic symptoms or cavitary lesions and empirical ATT is not justified in this case where ILD is the primary diagnosis.

 

Option B. Initiate oral prednisolone and azathioprine: Steroids and azathioprine are used in specific ILDs, not IPF, and require biopsy confirmation.

 

Option D. Prescribe smoking cessation and review: Smoking cessation alone would not establish diagnosis nor would be therapeutic in such cases even though it is essential.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung biopsy is essential for accurate diagnosis in interstitial lung disease with nonspecific HRCT findings.

questions.text: Contraceptive Efficacy is assessed by measuring the number of unplanned pregnancies that occur during a specified period of exposure and use of a contraceptive method. Two methods used include Pearl Index and Life table analysis. Find incorrect match of a contraceptive and Its Pearl index:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oral pills: 1-5/HWY

 

  • The Pearl Index for oral contraceptive pills is typically around 8 pregnancies per 100 woman-years (HWY) with typical use. 
  • Oral pills is 0.1 – 2/HWY
  • The value of 1–5/HWY underestimates the actual failure rate in real-world settings. While perfect use of combined oral contraceptive pills can result in a very low failure rate (as low as 0.3), typical use often leads to higher failure rates due to missed doses or improper use. 
  • Thus, this match is not accurate, making this the correct answer to the question.

 

 

  • New studies shows that subdermal implants have shown sterilization rate of 0.05/HWY

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Male condoms: 2–14/HWY: Correct; This range accurately reflects the failure rate with both perfect and typical use. Condoms are user-dependent; typical use tends toward the higher end of the range due to incorrect or inconsistent usage.

 

Option B. Female condoms: 5–21/HWY. Correct; Female condoms have a higher Pearl Index compared to male condoms, reflecting the more complex insertion process and increased user variability.

 

Option C. Vaginal sponge (nulliparous women): 9–20/HWY: Correct; This value is consistent with data for nulliparous women (those who haven’t given birth). The Pearl Index for parous women is even higher, but 9–20 is appropriate for nulliparous users.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oral contraceptive pills, while highly effective with perfect use, have a higher typical-use failure rate (~8/HWY) than commonly perceived. 
  • When evaluating contraceptive efficacy, the Pearl Index should reflect both typical and perfect use scenarios to avoid underestimation of real-world failure rates.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding monozygotic twin formation are true? 

 

  1. If division occurs after embryonic disc formation, it results in conjoined twins.
  2. If division occurs before 72 hours, it results in diamniotic–dichorionic twins.
  3. If division occurs between 4–8 days, it results in monochorionic–monoamniotic twins.
  4. If division occurs after 8 days, it results in monochorionic–monoamniotic twins
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 4

 

 

Statement 1. If division occurs after embryonic disc formation, it results in conjoined twins: True. If division occurs after the formation of the embryonic disc (i.e., after day 13), incomplete separation leads to conjoined twins.

 

Statement 2. If division occurs before 72 hours, it results in diamniotic–dichorionic twins: True. Division before day 3 (within 72 hours) — i.e., at the morula stage — results in dichorionic–diamniotic twins (2 placentas, 2 amnions).

 

Statement 4. If division occurs after 8 days, it results in monochorionic–monoamniotic twins: True. Division after 8 days but before 13 days results in monochorionic–monoamniotic twins (shared placenta and shared amniotic sac).

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 3. If division occurs between 4–8 days, it results in monochorionic–monoamniotic twins: False. Division between 4–8 days leads to monochorionic–diamniotic twins (shared placenta, two amniotic sacs), not monoamniotic.

 

Summary of Monozygotic Twinning Timing:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The timing of embryonic division determines the type of placentation and amniotic sac configuration in monozygotic twinning.
  • Early division (≤3 days) leads to dichorionic-diamniotic twins, intermediate division (4–7 days) to monochorionic-diamniotic, late division (8–12 days) to monochorionic-monoamniotic, and very late division (>13 days) to conjoined twins.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with newly diagnosed pulmonary tuberculosis is started on first-line multidrug therapy as per standard guidelines. Two weeks later, he returns complaining of visual disturbances. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethambutol

 

  • Ethambutol is a first-line antitubercular drug that is classically associated with optic neuritis, presenting as painless loss of central vision, impaired visual acuity, and disturbances in color vision (especially red-green color discrimination). 
  • This complication is dose-related and usually reversible if the drug is discontinued early, but if ignored, it may progress to permanent optic nerve damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyrazinamide: This drug is associated with hyperuricemia leading to gout flares and can cause hepatotoxicity but is not linked to optic nerve toxicity or color vision disturbances.

 

Option B. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is known for peripheral neuropathy due to pyridoxine deficiency, and also can cause hepatotoxicity, but it does not typically cause optic neuritis or color blindness.

 

Option D. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is well-known for hepatotoxicity and causing orange discoloration of body fluids (urine, sweat, tears), but it does not damage the optic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol, a key first-line antitubercular drug, can cause dose-dependent optic neuritis with central vision loss and red-green dyschromatopsia, which must be monitored during tuberculosis therapy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male presents with worsening hoarseness for 3 months and stridor for 2 weeks. On laryngoscopic examination, the image shows multiple lesions involving the vocal cords. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory papillomatosis

 

  • The clinical presentation and the laryngoscopic image are classical of Recurrent Respiratory Papillomatosis (RRP) — also known as Juvenile-onset laryngeal papillomatosis.

 

Key Features Supporting the Diagnosis:

 

Age and History:

 

  • Most common benign laryngeal tumor in children, typically presenting before 5 years of age.
  • Presents with progressive hoarseness, dysphonia, and eventual stridor due to airway compromise — exactly as seen in this child.

 

Laryngoscopic Image:

 

  • Shows multiple papillomatous growths on the vocal cords, consistent with sessile/pedunculated papillomas that are often bilateral and involve the anterior commissure.

 

Etiology:

 

  • Caused by HPV-6 and HPV-11.
  • HPV-11 is associated with a more aggressive course and greater malignant potential.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Hoarse cry/voice, stridor, respiratory distress.
  • Lesions may bleed on touch and recur frequently.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Endoscopic surgical removal (e.g., CO₂ laser or microdebrider) is the mainstay.
  • Adjuvant therapies (e.g., intralesional cidofovir, interferon alpha-2a) used in aggressive or recurrent cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal nodule: Typically, bilateral, small nodules at the junction of the anterior and middle thirds of the vocal cords. Presents with hoarseness but not stridor and not multiple papillomatous growths.

 

Option B. Acute epiglottitis: Rapid onset with high fever, drooling, dysphagia, muffled voice, and toxic appearance. Not chronic, and not associated with vocal cord lesions.

 

Option D. Carcinoma larynx: Rare in a 5-year-old. More typical in elderly patients with risk factors like smoking/alcohol. Lesions are usually solitary and ulcerative, not multiple papillomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Juvenile respiratory papillomatosis is the most common benign laryngeal tumor in children and presents with progressive hoarseness and stridor. 
  • It is caused by HPV-6/11, appears as multiple papillomas, and requires repeated endoscopic surgical excisions due to frequent recurrences.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations (Nutrient for a physiological group) is an Incorrect match for RDA?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin C (adult woman) – 80 mg/day

 

  • According to the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) 2020 and international RDA guidelines:
    • The Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) of Vitamin C for an adult woman is approximately 65 mg/day, not 80 mg/day. 
    • While slight variation may occur based on national standards, 80 mg/day exceeds the standard RDA for this group under most nutritional guidelines unless specific increased needs exist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron (pregnant woman) – 40 mg/day: During pregnancy, iron requirements increase significantly to meet the demands of the growing fetus and increased blood volume. 40 mg/day is an accurate RDA for pregnant women.

 

Option B. Calcium (adult man) – 1000 mg/day: Adult men require about 1000 mg/day of calcium for bone health and metabolic functions.

 

Option C. Iodine (lactating woman) – 280 mcg/day: Lactating women have increased iodine requirements due to transfer of iodine through breast milk to the infant. 280 mcg/day is an accurate and recommended value.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) values vary based on nutrient type and physiological condition. 
  • The RDA for Vitamin C in adult women is approximately 65 mg/day, making the value of 80 mg/day an incorrect match for this group.

questions.text: A man weighing 70 kg has a hematocrit of 45%. What would be his approximate plasma volume?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3080 ml

 

  •  Average blood volume account for 8% of body weight.
  •  So, here for 70 Kg man, Blood volume is 5.6 Litres (70 x 8/100).
  •  Blood Volume = Plasma volume/1 – Hematocrit.
  •  So, Plasma volume = Blood volume x (1 – Hematocrit).
  • Here, Plasma volume = 5.6 x (1 – 0.45) = 3080 ml.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Plasma volume can be estimated using the relationship between total blood volume and hematocrit.
  • In an average adult, blood volume is approximately 8% of body weight.
