  • Once total blood volume is calculated, plasma volume is derived by subtracting the cellular component, which is estimated using the hematocrit (the fraction of blood volume occupied by red blood cells).
  • The formula used is:
    Plasma Volume = Blood Volume × (1−Hematocrit)

questions.text: A 70-year-old retired teacher is evaluated after routine blood tests revealed a high total protein level. He feels well and reports no fatigue, weight loss, or bone pain. Laboratory tests show creatinine 1.0 mg/dL, calcium 9.8 mg/dL, albumin 4.1 g/dL, and hemoglobin 12.8 g/dL. Protein electrophoresis is shown below and a bone marrow biopsy showing 15% clonal plasma cells. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perform a PET-CT scan Explanation

 

  • This patient has features of smoldering multiple myeloma (SMM):
    • Clonal plasma cells >10%
    • No end-organ damage (normal calcium, kidney function, hemoglobin)
  • PET-CT is used to:
    • Detect occult bone lesions
    • Differentiate SMM from active multiple myeloma
  • Patients with SMM should be monitored closely for progression, and imaging is essential before initiating therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Begin dexamethasone alone: Indicated only in symptomatic or progressing myeloma, but along with other drugs with lenalidomide.

 

Option B. Lenalidomide, dexamethasone & bortezomib: Used in active MM or clinical trials for high-risk SMM, not standard initial step.

 

Option D. Annual labs and monitoring only: Appropriate in MGUS or low-risk SMM, but not without advanced imaging in borderline cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with suspected smoldering myeloma, advanced imaging (e.g., PET-CT or MRI) is essential to rule out active disease before deciding on observation versus treatment.

questions.text: A 25-year-old G2P1 woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents with regular uterine contractions and is diagnosed with preterm labor. She is 2 cm dilated and 80% effaced. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to tocolysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suspected placental abruption

 

  • Tocolysis refers to the pharmacologic suppression of uterine contractions to delay preterm delivery, typically to allow time for corticosteroid administration and neonatal transfer.
  • However, tocolytic therapy is contraindicated in certain maternal or fetal conditions where delaying delivery increases risk.
  • Placental abruption is a condition where the placenta separates prematurely from the uterine wall.
  • Suspected abruption presents with:
    • Vaginal bleeding
    • Uterine tenderness or rigidity
    • Fetal distress
  • In such cases, immediate delivery may be necessary, and tocolysis is contraindicated because:
    • It may worsen maternal hemorrhage
    • It may delay urgent delivery, risking fetal hypoxia or death
  • Hence, suspected placental abruption is an absolute contraindication to tocolysis.
  • Absolute Contraindications to Tocolysis:
    • Suspected placental abruption
    • Intrauterine fetal demise
    • Lethal fetal anomaly
    • Chorioamnionitis
    • Severe preeclampsia/eclampsia
    • Significant vaginal bleeding
    • Fetal distress
    • Gestational age >34 weeks

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Previous cesarean section: Not an absolute contraindication. Prior C-section (especially with a low transverse incision) is not a contraindication to tocolysis. However, if there is uterine scar tenderness or concern for rupture, caution is warranted.

 

Option C. Recent laparotomy: Relative contraindication. May raise concern about uterine integrity, but not an absolute bar to tocolysis unless uterine rupture or instability is suspected.

 

Option D. Uterine fibroids: Relative contraindication. Fibroids may increase uterine irritability or obstruct delivery, but not a contraindication to tocolytics unless associated with complications like degeneration or rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tocolytics should be avoided in cases of suspected placental abruption, as delaying delivery may worsen maternal hemorrhage and fetal compromise. 
  • Always weigh maternal and fetal risks before initiating tocolysis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 2, presents at 28 weeks of gestation for a routine antenatal visit. Ultrasound reveals features of fetal hydrops, including skin edema, pleural effusion, and ascites. There is no evidence of fetal anemia or a history of alloimmunization. Which of the following is the least likely cause of the fetal condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gestational Diabetes Mellitus

 

  • GDM is not a recognized cause of fetal hydrops.
  • While GDM can lead to complications such as macrosomia, polyhydramnios, and neonatal hypoglycemia, it does not typically result in the pathophysiologic cascade that leads to hydrops fetalis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal cystic adenomatoid malformation: This is a congenital pulmonary airway malformation that can cause compression of fetal vasculature, leading to hydrops by impairing venous return and lymphatic drainage.

 

Option C. Parvovirus B19 infection: This virus infects fetal erythroid precursors, leading to profound anemia and high-output cardiac failure, which are well-known causes of non-immune hydrops.

 

Option D. Rh allo-immunization: This is the classical cause of immune hydrops. It leads to hemolysis of fetal red blood cells, resulting in severe anemia and eventually fetal hydrops if untreated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-immune hydrops has many causes, but gestational diabetes is not one of them.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman undergoing chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel develops severe nausea and vomiting starting 48 hours after chemotherapy, despite receiving ondansetron and dexamethasone on day 1. She has no symptoms of dehydration. Which of the following agents is most appropriate to add to her next chemotherapy cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aprepitant

 

  • This patient is experiencing delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), which typically begins more than 24 hours after chemotherapy. 
  • Delayed CINV is not effectively controlled by 5-HT₃ receptor antagonists alone, and ondansetron, despite its use for acute emesis, does not provide sufficient coverage for delayed symptoms.
  • Aprepitant, a neurokinin-1 (NK₁) receptor antagonist, is specifically indicated for delayed-phase CINV, especially when used in combination with 5-HT₃ antagonists and corticosteroids (triple therapy). 
  • It works by blocking substance P from binding NK₁ receptors in the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoclopramide: Primarily a D₂ receptor blocker with limited efficacy in delayed CINV, used more often for gastroparesis or mild emesis.

 

Option C. Diphenhydramine: An H₁ antihistamine used for motion sickness or vestibular-related nausea; not effective in chemotherapy-induced emesis.

 

Option D. Dronabinol: A cannabinoid used as second-line therapy for refractory CINV; not first-line for delayed-phase vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aprepitant, a neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist, is the most appropriate agent to add to antiemetic regimens for patients experiencing delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting that is not controlled by 5-HT₃ antagonists alone.

 

Note:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding CSF findings in meningitis are true?
 

  1. Tubercular meningitis typically has high protein, low glucose, and lymphocytic predominance.
  2. Viral meningitis has low glucose and neutrophilic predominance.
  3. Bacterial meningitis has low glucose, high protein, and neutrophilic predominance.
  4. CSF pressure is typically increased in bacterial, tubercular, and brain abscess cases.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 4

 

Statement 1. Tubercular meningitis typically has high protein, low glucose, and lymphocytic predominance: True. TBM has high protein, low glucose, and lymphocytic predominance.

 

Statement 3. Bacterial meningitis has low glucose, high protein, and neutrophilic predominance: True. Bacterial meningitis has low glucose, high protein, and neutrophilic predominance.

 

Statement 4. CSF pressure is typically increased in bacterial, tubercular, and brain abscess cases: True. CSF pressure is usually increased in bacterial meningitis, TBM, and brain abscess.


Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. Viral meningitis has low glucose and neutrophilic predominance: False. Viral meningitis has normal/high glucose and lymphocytic predominance, not neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A teenage female is undergoing workup for primary amenorrhea. Physical examination is normal, and secondary sexual characteristics are present. The clinician suspects a congenital anomaly of the uterus and plans to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is considered the gold standard diagnostic test for confirming a congenital uterine malformation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laparoscopy with hysteroscopy

 

  • The gold standard for evaluating congenital uterine anomalies is a combined laparoscopy with hysteroscopy as it is both diagnostic and therapeutic.
  • Hysteroscopy allows direct visualization of the endometrial cavity, helping evaluate anomalies like septate uterus or absent uterine cavity.
  • Laparoscopy enables assessment of external uterine contour and differentiation between anomalies like bicornuate and septate uterus, which is crucial for diagnosis and treatment planning.
  • Together, this combined approach offers the highest diagnostic accuracy in delineating both the internal and external morphology of the uterus, especially in complex anomalies.


Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI: Incorrect. While MRI is a non-invasive and highly sensitive imaging modality for uterine anatomy, it is not considered the gold standard. MRI is useful when laparoscopy is contraindicated or not feasible.

 

Option B. CT scan: Incorrect. CT is not preferred for soft tissue evaluation of the uterus due to inferior resolution compared to MRI and ultrasonography. It also involves radiation exposure, which is undesirable in young females.

 

Option D. 3D ultrasonography: Incorrect. 3D USG is an excellent non-invasive tool and highly accurate for uterine cavity evaluation, but it cannot reliably assess the external uterine contour, making it inferior to laparoscopy with hysteroscopy for gold standard classification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gold standard investigation for diagnosing congenital uterine anomalies, especially in the setting of primary amenorrhea, is combined laparoscopy with hysteroscopy, as it provides direct visualization of both the internal endometrial cavity and external uterine morphology.

choices.text: Buerger’s disease: Seen in young smokers
Superficial femoral arterial block: Calf claudication
Rest pain: Relieved by leg elevation

questions.text: Identify the mismatched finding in peripheral vascular occlusive disease.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rest pain: Relieved by leg elevation

 

  • In severe peripheral arterial disease, rest pain is actually worsened by leg elevation (due to reduced perfusion). 
  • Patients often hang their legs down to use gravity for improved blood flow—this is known as dependent rubor.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Buerger’s disease: Seen in young smokers: Buerger’s disease (Thromboangiitis obliterans) typically affects young male smokers. It’s a non-atherosclerotic, inflammatory disease of small and medium-sized arteries and veins, often in the limbs.

 

Option B. Aortoiliac block: Leriche’s syndrome: Leriche’s syndrome is a classic presentation of aortoiliac occlusive disease. It involves the triad of buttock claudication, impotence, and diminished femoral pulses.

 

Option C. Superficial femoral arterial block: Calf claudication: Blockage in the superficial femoral artery commonly causes calf pain during exertion, as it's the main artery supplying the lower limb muscles

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Rest pain in PAD improves with dependency, not elevation, distinguishing it from venous issues where elevation helps.
  • Each arterial block has a hallmark symptom pattern, like Leriche’s syndrome or calf claudication from femoral artery involvement.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male diagnosed with squint presented to the ophthalmology department. On examination, the muscle (marked in the CT scan with black arrows) was found to be affected. At which of the following levels does the nerve supply to the marked muscle originate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red nucleus

 

Muscle Identified: Medial Rectus

 

  • The medial rectus muscle is one of the extraocular muscles, responsible for adduction of the eye (moving the eye medially).
  • In the CT image provided, the medial rectus is marked, indicating it is the affected muscle in this clinical case of squint (strabismus).

 

Nerve Supply of Medial Rectus:

 

  • The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) supplies:
    • Superior rectus
    • Inferior rectus
    • Medial rectus
    • Inferior oblique
    • Levator palpebrae superioris

 

Anatomical Origin of the Oculomotor Nucleus:

 

  • The oculomotor nucleus is located in the midbrain, at the level of the superior colliculus.
  • It lies ventral to the periaqueductal gray matter and is situated adjacent to the red nucleus.
  • Therefore, the correct anatomical level of origin of the nerve supplying the medial rectus is at the level of the red nucleus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subthalamic nuclei: Located in the diencephalon, associated with basal ganglia circuitry, not extraocular muscle innervation.

 

Option C. Decussation of pyramidal tract: Occurs in the medulla, where corticospinal fibers cross. Irrelevant to cranial nerve nuclei.

 

Option D. Olivary nucleus: Located in the medulla, involved in motor learning and coordination, not ocular movement control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The medial rectus muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve, whose nucleus lies in the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus, near the red nucleus. 
  • Lesions here can present with ophthalmoplegia and squint.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male from Bihar presents with focal seizures followed by GTCS. EEG shows focal temporal lobe epileptiform discharges. MRI brain is shown below. What is the most appropriate management after adding corticosteroids?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start levetiracetam and albendazole

 

  • MRI reveals multiple well-defined sub-centimetre hyperintense lesions in both cerebral and cerebellar hemispheres, including the bilateral ganglio-thalamic region. Internal eccentric scolex noted. No evidence of mass effect.
  • Seizures are the most common initial presentation of NCC. They are usually focal often with secondary generalization.
  • Levetiracetam is preferred for seizures in NCC due to efficacy and safety. Other options include carbamazepine (or phenytoin.
  • Albendazole treats active cysticerci, reducing seizure recurrence.
  • Steroids are used with antiparasitics to reduce inflammation.
  • NCC is highly prevalent in developing countries due to poor sanitation and pork consumption.
  • Surgical evaluation is rarely needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Initiate phenytoin and praziquantel: Phenytoin has more side effects, and praziquantel alone is less effective for NCC.

 

Option C. Prescribe valproate and corticosteroids: Valproate is more toxic and a broad spectrum drug in such scenarios are not recommended. Corticosteroid is already given, so not to give again.

 

Option D. Begin carbamazepine and surgical evaluation: Carbamazepine is an option, but surgery is not indicated for calcified NCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurocysticercosis in endemic areas requires antiepileptics and antiparasitic therapy for optimal seizure control.

choices.text: Melioidosis is a Category B threat due to its low human-to-human transmissibility and potential environmental persistence
Nipah virus is Category C due to its emerging status and potential for genetic engineering
Clostridium perfringens is Category A due to its alpha-toxin and gastrointestinal outbreaks
Ricin toxin is Category B due to its potential for use as an aerosolizable toxin

questions.text: Which of the following statements about bioterrorism agent classification contains an error?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clostridium perfringens is Category A due to its alpha-toxin and gastrointestinal outbreaks

 

  • The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) classifies biological agents into Category A, B, or C based on their risk to national security, including ease of dissemination, mortality, and public panic potential.
    • Category A: High-priority agents. It has 6 agents (e.g., anthrax, botulism, plague, smallpox, tularemia, viral hemorrhagic fevers). These pose the highest threat due to easy transmission and high mortality.
    • Category B: Moderately easy to disseminate, lower mortality, moderate public health impact (e.g., melioidosis, ricin toxin, Q fever, brucellosis). It has multiple agents
    • Category C: Emerging pathogens that could be engineered for future mass dissemination (e.g., Nipah virus, hantavirus, tick-borne encephalitis).
  • Clostridium perfringens, although capable of producing alpha-toxin and causing gas gangrene or food poisoning, is classified under Category B, not Category A. 
  • Its limited potential for mass casualty and low person-to-person transmission make it a lower-priority threat.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melioidosis is a Category B threat due to its low human-to-human transmissibility and potential environmental persistence: Correct. Burkholderia pseudomallei is classified under Category B, consistent with its environmental resilience and bioterrorism potential.

 

Option B. Nipah virus is Category C due to its emerging status and potential for genetic engineering: Correct. Nipah virus has high fatality, zoonotic transmission, and potential for future weaponization, placing it in Category C.

 

Option D. Ricin toxin is Category B due to its potential for use as an aerosolizable toxin: Correct. Ricin, a potent plant-derived toxin from Ricinus communis, is a Category B agent due to feasibility of aerosol delivery and moderate public health threat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clostridium perfringens is classified as a Category B bioterrorism agent, not Category A. 
  • Category A agents pose the highest risk and include organisms like Bacillus anthracis, Variola virus, and Yersinia pestis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old individual reports gradually progressive skin tightening over the hands and face, along with difficulty climbing stairs and muscle fatigue. Episodes of fingertip discoloration in response to cold are also noted. Laboratory results reveal elevated creatine kinase levels. Muscle biopsy demonstrates perifascicular muscle fiber inflammation and infiltration. Which of the following antibodies is most likely responsible for these overlapping clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-PM-Scl antibodies

 

  • The patient presents with features suggestive of both systemic sclerosis and polymyositis, including:
    • Skin tightening
    • Raynaud phenomenon
    • Proximal muscle weakness
    • Elevated creatine kinase
    • Perifascicular inflammation on muscle biopsy
  • These are hallmark signs of scleromyositis, an overlap syndrome.
    Anti-PM-Scl antibodies are the most characteristic marker of this overlap condition. 
  • This autoantibody is often linked to:
    • Systemic sclerosis–polymyositis overlap
    • Positive ANA
    • Milder cutaneous and systemic involvement
    • Better prognosis compared to anti-Scl-70 positive cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-Mi-2 antibodies: Associated with classic dermatomyositis, typically involving skin rashes like heliotrope rash or Gottron papules. No overlap with systemic sclerosis.

 

Option B. Anti-RNP antibodies: Seen in Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD), which may have features of SLE, PM, and SSc. But in this case, absence of SLE findings and specific biopsy features make this less likely.

 

Option D. Anti-Scl-70 antibodies: Specific for diffuse systemic sclerosis, but do not correlate with muscle involvement or biopsy-proven inflammation. Presence of muscle weakness and biopsy findings favor anti-PM-Scl.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

  • Anti-PM-Scl antibodies are strongly associated with systemic sclerosis–polymyositis overlap syndrome, presenting with skin fibrosis, muscle weakness, and specific histological muscle changes like perifascicular infiltration.

questions.text: Indicators of the quality of proteins include all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Protein energy ratio 

 

  • Indicators of the quality are 
    • DIAAS (Best)
    • PDCAAS (2nd Best)
    • NPU
    • AAS
    • BV
    • Protein efficiency ratio
  • The Protein Energy Ratio (PER) is not a standard indicator of protein quality. 
  • It is used more generally to assess the contribution of protein to total energy intake, rather than evaluating the digestibility or biological value of the protein itself. 
  • It does not account for amino acid composition or utilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PDCAAS (Protein Digestibility-Corrected Amino Acid Score): This is a widely used method that evaluates protein quality based on human amino acid requirements and digestibility. It has been a global standard for measuring protein quality.

 

Option C. Protein Efficiency Ratio (PER): PER measures the weight gain of a test subject per unit of protein consumed and is commonly used in animal studies to assess protein quality.

 

Option D. DIAAS (Digestible Indispensable Amino Acid Score): This is a newer, more accurate method recommended by FAO, which evaluates the digestibility of each essential amino acid at the end of the small intestine rather than the whole tract, providing a more precise measure of protein quality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Protein quality is measured using indicators such as PDCAAS, PER, and DIAAS, which assess digestibility and amino acid composition. 
  • The Protein Energy Ratio reflects caloric contribution rather than protein quality, and thus is not an appropriate indicator for protein evaluation.

choices.text: Low-dose aspirin increases uric acid synthesis via xanthine oxidase
Low-dose aspirin decreases renal excretion of uric acid
Aspirin enhances renal tubular reabsorption of uric acid at high doses
Aspirin inhibits uric acid transporters at all doses

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with chronic gout is advised to take low-dose aspirin (75 mg/day) for secondary prevention after a stroke. He later presents with acute gouty arthritis. Which of the following best explains this association?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low-dose aspirin decreases renal excretion of uric acid

 

  • Low-dose aspirin (<325 mg/day) inhibits the secretion of uric acid in the proximal renal tubules. 
  • This reduces uric acid excretion, leading to increased serum uric acid levels and a higher risk of gout flares, particularly in patients with pre-existing hyperuricemia or gout.
  • In contrast, high doses of aspirin (>3 g/day) can actually have a uricosuric effect, increasing uric acid excretion—but such high doses are not used due to toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low-dose aspirin increases uric acid synthesis via xanthine oxidase: Incorrect. Aspirin has no significant effect on xanthine oxidase, the enzyme inhibited by allopurinol.

 

Option C. Aspirin enhances renal tubular reabsorption of uric acid at high doses: Incorrect. At high doses, aspirin reduces uric acid reabsorption and increases excretion (uricosuric effect). It is low-dose aspirin that causes uric acid retention.

 

Option D. Aspirin inhibits uric acid transporters at all doses: Incorrect. Aspirin has dose-dependent effects; it does not uniformly inhibit uric acid transporters across all doses. Low doses impair secretion, while high doses promote excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low-dose aspirin decreases renal uric acid excretion, predisposing to hyperuricemia and gout flares. It should be used cautiously in patients with a history of gout.

 

  • Low-dose aspirin (<325 mg/day) → ↓ uric acid excretion → ↑ risk of gout
  • High-dose aspirin (>3 g/day) → ↑ uric acid excretion (but poorly tolerated)
  • Be cautious when prescribing aspirin for CV prevention in gout patients

choices.text: Initiate sulfasalazine and high dose Ibuprofen.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with low back pain and stiffness for 1 year, worse in the mornings. He has tried Naproxen without much benefit. He has a history of recurrent uveitis. and ESR is 45 mm/hr. Pelvic X-ray is shown below. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prescribe adalimumab and physical therapy

 

  • Inflammatory back pain in a young male with B/L sacroiliitis in imaging suggest ankylosing spondylitis (AS).
  • Uveitis is a common extra-articular manifestation of AS.
  • TNF inhibitors (e.g., adalimumab) are indicated for active AS unresponsive to NSAIDs or those who have significant extra-articular manifestations.
  • Physical therapy maintains spinal mobility and posture.
  • Steroids and conventional DMARDs are ineffective for axial disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start oral prednisolone and colchicine: Prednisolone/colchicine are not indicated for AS.

 

Option B. Initiate sulfasalazine and high dose Ibuprofen: Sulfasalazine is ineffective for axial AS and this patient has already experienced an NSAID failure and it is not a good rationale to try a different NSAID.

 

Option D. Begin methotrexate and low-dose steroids: Methotrexate and other conventional synthetic DMARDs are for peripheral arthritis, not axial AS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TNF inhibitors are effective for active ankylosing spondylitis with axial involvement – especially for those who have failed NSAIDs and/or for those who have severe extra-articular manifestations.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child from an endemic region presents with prolonged fever, weight loss, pallor, and massive splenomegaly. Laboratory studies reveal pancytopenia. A rapid serological test using recombinant antigens is performed to support the diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most useful in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) rk39 test

 

  • The rk39 test is a serological immunochromatographic test used for the diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis (also known as kala-azar).
  • It detects IgG antibodies against the recombinant kinesin antigen (rk39) derived from Leishmania chagasi/donovani.
  • The test is rapid, non-invasive, and field-deployable, making it especially valuable in endemic regions like India, Sudan, and Brazil.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LAM test (Lipoarabinomannan test): Used in the diagnosis of tuberculosis, especially in HIV-positive patients. Not related to leishmaniasis.

 

Option B. CrAg test (Cryptococcal antigen test): Used to detect Cryptococcus neoformans antigen, particularly in CSF and serum. Not applicable to kala-azar.

 

Option D. Montenegro test: It is hypersensitivity test.  A leishmanin skin test, similar to tuberculin test, used to detect cutaneous or mucocutaneous leishmaniasis based on delayed hypersensitivity — not helpful in visceral leishmaniasis as patients are often anergic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The rk39 test is a rapid and specific serological tool for diagnosing visceral leishmaniasis, based on antibody detection against recombinant Leishmania kinesin antigen.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the quadruple test used in second-trimester aneuploidy screening?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)

 

  • The quadruple test includes the following four serum markers:
    1. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
    2. Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
    3. Free β-hCG
    4. Inhibin A

 

These are measured between 15–22 weeks, optimally 16–18 weeks, to assess the risk of chromosomal abnormalities such as trisomy 21 and trisomy 18.

 

  • PAPP-A is not a part of the quadruple test; it is used in first-trimester screening (part of the dual marker test along with free β-hCG and NT measurement).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The quadruple test is a second-trimester screening tool composed of AFP, uE3, β-hCG, and Inhibin A. 
  • PAPP-A is exclusive to first-trimester screening and is not included in the quadruple test.

questions.text: A 23 year primi presents in labor. She is an unbooked patient and by her LMP, she is 42 weeks and 4 days. On examination, she is 6 cm dilated, well effaced and the vertex is at 0 station. A CTG taken is as shown below. What could be the reason for the findings in the CTG shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oligohydramnios

 

  • The patient is post term, in labor and the CTG is showing variable decelerations (as there is no relation between the decelerations and the uterine contractions)
  • Variable decelerations occur because of cord compression which is seen in oligohydramnios which is seen in post term pregnancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cord prolapse: Will usually present with prolonged deceleration/ fetal bradycardia/ fetal death.

 

Option B. Meconium: If associated with fetal hypoxia will present with later decelerations.

 

Option D. Uteroplacental insufficiency: Will present as late decelerations

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Types of Decelerations in a CTG:

questions.text: Match the following malnutrition-related conditions with their definitions:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D

 

1-C. Stunting → Height-for-age < -2 SD: Defined as height-for-age below -2 SD.

 

2-A. Severe Stunting → Height-for-age < -3 SD: Defined as height-for-age below -3 SD.

 

3-B. Wasting → Weight-for-height < -2 SD: Defined as weight-for-height below -2 SD.

 

4-D. Severe Wasting → Weight-for-height < -3 SD: Defined as weight-for-height below -3 SD.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
An 11-month-old infant presents with an abdominal mass and features such as macroglossia and umbilical hernia. Genetic testing confirms Wilms' tumor. Which of the following statements are true regarding the underlying syndrome?

 

  1. The syndrome is associated with hemihypertrophy.
  2. It involves an overgrowth disorder caused by IGF-2 dysregulation.
  3. The risk of Wilms’ tumor decreases after 8 years of age.
  4. The most likely diagnosis is Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Statement 1. The syndrome is associated with hemihypertrophy: True. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is associated with hemihypertrophy.

 

Statement 2. It involves an overgrowth disorder caused by IGF-2 dysregulation: True. It is caused by IGF-2 dysregulation, leading to overgrowth.

 

Statement 3. The risk of Wilms’ tumor decreases after 8 years of age: True. The risk of Wilms’ tumor significantly decreases after 8 years.

 

Statement 4. The most likely diagnosis is Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome: True. The clinical presentation strongly suggests Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth disorder associated with hemihypertrophy and Wilms’ tumor.
  • The risk of Wilms’ tumor decreases after 8 years of age.

choices.text: Bacillus anthracis shows a “Medusa head” colony appearance on blood agar.
Its vegetative cells appear as “bamboo sticks” due to central spores when stained.
The “String of Pearls” reaction is observed on solid media in the presence of penicillin.
Mc’Fadyean’s reaction uses India ink to highlight the capsule.

questions.text: A microbiology student reviews the key features used to identify Bacillus anthracis in the lab. Which of the following statements regarding its culture and staining characteristics is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mc’Fadyean’s reaction uses India ink to highlight the capsule.

 

  • Mc’Fadyean’s reaction uses polychrome methylene blue, not India ink, to stain the capsule of B. anthracis.
  • India ink is used for visualizing the capsule of Cryptococcus neoformans, not Bacillus anthracis.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Bacillus anthracis shows a “Medusa head” colony appearance on blood agar: True. Bacillus anthracis produces Medusa head colonies on blood agar due to filamentous outgrowths at colony margins. Medusa head colonies is snake like appearance.

 

 

Option B. Its vegetative cells appear as “bamboo sticks” due to central spores when stained: True. The bacterium appears as Gram-positive rods resembling bamboo sticks due to the presence of central, non-bulging spores.

 

 

Option C. The “String of Pearls” reaction is observed on solid media in the presence of penicillin: True. The String of Pearls reaction occurs when B. anthracis is cultured on solid medium with penicillin — small spherical cells align like pearls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacillus anthracis can be identified by its bamboo stick morphology, Medusa head colonies, Mc’Fadyean’s capsular stain (using polychrome methylene blue), inverted fir tree pattern in gelatin, and String of Pearls reaction in the presence of penicillin.

choices.text: It lies lateral to the midline
It causes difficulty in swallowing and speech
It may present with bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall on examination
It is present beneath the vertebral fascia

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding retropharyngeal abscess is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is present beneath the vertebral fascia

 

  • A retropharyngeal abscess is a deep space neck infection that commonly affects children under 5 years of age. 
  • It arises due to infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes following an upper respiratory infection.
  • The retropharyngeal space is anterior to the vertebral fascia, not beneath it.

 

Anatomical Location

  • The abscess is located in the retropharyngeal space, which lies:
    • Anteriorly: Buccopharyngeal fascia (on constrictor muscles)
    • Posteriorly: Prevertebral fascia
  • Therefore, it lies in front of, not beneath, the vertebral fascia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It lies lateral to the midline: True. The retropharyngeal space is bilateral and located paramedian (lateral to midline), more prominent in young children. It differentiates it from prevertebral abscess. There are 2 retropharyngeal spaces which are separated by midline raphe

 

Option B. It causes difficulty in swallowing and speech: True. Due to mass effect, patients often present with dysphagia, odynophagia, muffled voice, and sometimes stridor.

 

Option C. It may present with bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall on examination: True. A smooth, soft swelling on posterior pharyngeal wall may be seen in <50% of cases, but its presence supports the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A retropharyngeal abscess lies anterior to the vertebral fascia, not beneath it. 
  • It typically presents with dysphagia, fever, and posterior pharyngeal wall bulge, and is a pediatric emergency due to its risk of airway compromise.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with chronic kidney disease stage 4 is being evaluated for blood pressure control. The physician plans to start a beta-blocker but is concerned about the patient’s reduced renal clearance and potential drug accumulation. Which of the following beta-adrenoceptor blocking agents should be avoided in patients with renal failure due to predominant renal excretion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atenolol

 

  • Drugs avoided in renal failure are atenolol, Nadolol and Sotalol
  • Atenolol is a hydrophilic beta-1 selective blocker that is primarily eliminated via the kidneys. 
  • In patients with renal impairment, its clearance is significantly reduced, leading to drug accumulation and increased risk of bradycardia, hypotension, and heart block.
  • Therefore, it should be avoided or used with caution in patients with renal failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metoprolol: Metabolized primarily by the liver (CYP2D6). Safe to use in renal impairment.

 

Option C. Propranolol: A lipophilic non-selective beta-blocker extensively metabolized hepatically. Also safe in renal failure.

 

Option D. Esmolol: An ultrashort-acting beta-1 blocker metabolized by red blood cell esterases, independent of kidney function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atenolol is renally excreted and should be avoided or dose-adjusted in patients with renal failure. Beta-blockers with hepatic metabolism (e.g., metoprolol, propranolol) or ester metabolism (e.g., esmolol) are preferred in such cases.

choices.text: Spherical error correction through automated methods

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the purpose of the optical procedure being demonstrated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subjective adjustment of cylinder

 

  • The image demonstrates the Jackson Cross Cylinder (JCC) test, which is used in the subjective refinement of cylindrical power and axis in astigmatism. 
  • The JCC lens has equal and opposite cylindrical powers (+0.25 and –0.25 D) and is flipped in front of the patient’s eye to determine which orientation gives clearer vision.
  • This patient-guided procedure helps fine-tune the astigmatic component of the prescription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Determination of visual axis alignment: Incorrect. Visual axis alignment is typically assessed via cover-uncover test or Maddox rod — not with JCC.

 

Option C. Binocular balancing of accommodation: Incorrect. This is done to balance the accommodation between eyes after monocular refraction, but JCC is a monocular test done during cylinder refinement.

 

Option D. Spherical error correction through automated methods: Incorrect. JCC is not used for spherical power and is not an automated procedure. This description fits autorefraction more closely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jackson Cross Cylinder is a subjective test used to refine both the cylindrical axis and power in astigmatism correction during refractive evaluation.

choices.text: A is seen in Blount’s disease
B exceed the normal 7–10-degree femorotibialvalugus angulation
A is malalignment which doesn't reach normal 7–10-degree femorotibialvalugus angulation
Surgery is the main stay treatment of both A and B in childhood

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the images given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Surgery is the main stay treatment of both A and B in childhood

 

  • This statement claims surgery is the mainstay treatment for both conditions in childhood. This is generally FALSE.
  • Physiological Genu Varum (bowlegs) and Genu Valgum (knock-knees) are very common in young children and are often part of normal development.
    • Most infants are born with some degree of genu varum, which typically straightens out by 2 years of age.
    • Many toddlers then develop physiological genu valgum, which usually corrects spontaneously by 7-8 years of age.
  • Observation and non-surgical management (like watchful waiting, bracing in some cases) are the primary treatments for physiological varum and valgum in childhood.
  • Surgery is reserved for: 
    • Cases where the deformity is severe.
    • Cases that persist beyond the age of spontaneous correction.
    • Cases that are pathological (e.g., Blount's disease, rickets) and not correcting naturally, or are progressive.
    • Cases causing pain or functional impairment.
  • Therefore, stating that surgery is the mainstay (primary or most common) treatment for both conditions in childhood is incorrect, as most cases resolve spontaneously or are managed conservatively

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A is seen in Blount's disease:

 

  • Blount's disease (also known as tibia vara) is a growth disorder of the shin bone (tibia) that causes the lower leg to angle inward, resulting in bowlegs (genu varum). 
  • It often affects children and can be unilateral or bilateral.
  • Blount's disease is a specific cause of pathological genu varum.

 

Option B. B exceed the normal 7–10-degree femorotibial valgus angulation:

 

  • Normally, in adults, there is a slight physiological valgus angulation at the knee, meaning the femur and tibia form an angle where the knees are slightly closer together than the ankles. This normal angulation is typically around 7-10 degrees.
  • Genu valgum (knock-knees) occurs when this normal valgus angulation is exaggerated and exceeds the physiological range. The knees are excessively angled inward.
  • It indicates an abnormal increase in the valgus angle.

 

Option C. A is malalignment which doesn't reach normal 7–10-degree femorotibial valgus angulation:

 

  • As established, the normal knee has a 7–10-degree valgus angulation.
  • Genu varum (bowlegs), represented by A, is a condition where the knees are bowed outwards. This means the normal valgus angulation is reduced or even reversed into a varus angle (where the legs angle inward from the knee).
  • Therefore, if A represents genu varum, it means the knee alignment is less than the normal 7-10 degrees of valgus, or even in varus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Most cases of physiological genu varum and valgum in childhood resolve on their own and do not require surgery. Surgery is reserved for severe or pathological cases.

choices.text: The mean will increase, shifting the distribution to the right
The mean will decrease more than the median, creating left skewness
The mode will increase, indicating improved population health

questions.text:
A pediatric epidemiologist is analyzing a dataset of neonatal birth weights. The current summary statistics are as follows: 

  • Mean: 2.8 kg
  • Median: 3.0 kg
  • Mode: 3.2 kg

After data entry from a remote neonatal unit, several infants with extremely low birth weights (e.g., <1.5 kg) are added to the dataset. Which of the following is the most likely consequence on the distribution of birth weights?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The mean will decrease more than the median, creating left skewness

 

  • When extreme low values (outliers) are added to a dataset, they pull the mean more than the median, because the mean is sensitive to outliers, while the median is not.
  • Given that several extremely low birth weights are introduced, the mean birth weight will fall, while the median will be less affected. 
  • This causes the mean < median < mode—a characteristic of a left-skewed (negatively skewed) distribution.
  • This skewness indicates that the tail of the distribution lies to the left, which is consistent with the introduction of low-value outliers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The mean will increase, shifting the distribution to the right: Incorrect. Extremely low values are being added, which will lower the mean, not increase it.

 

Option B. The distribution will remain symmetric: Incorrect. Adding extreme low outliers disrupts symmetry and creates left skewness.

 

Option D. The mode will increase, indicating improved population health: Incorrect. The mode is unaffected by outliers and depends on the most frequently occurring value, which is unlikely to change significantly. Additionally, an increase in mode does not necessarily imply improved health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In skewed distributions, the mean is pulled in the direction of the tail. 
  • When extremely low values are added to a dataset, the mean decreases more than the median, resulting in a left-skewed (negatively skewed) distribution.
  • Outliers affect the mean more than the median. 
  • The presence of extreme low values causes left skewness, where mean < median < mode. This pattern helps in identifying data distortion due to outliers.

questions.text: A public health laboratory is performing water quality testing to assess the level of organic pollutants in a sample from a polluted river. The method chosen involves estimating the chemical oxygen demand (COD), which reflects the total amount of oxygen required to oxidize organic matter chemically. Which of the following agents is most appropriate for oxidizing organic matter during COD testing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Potassium dichromate

 

  • Strength of sewage is based on 3 methods – Biological oxygen demand, chemical oxygen demand and suspended solute 
  • Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD) is a critical water quality parameter that quantifies the total oxygen required to chemically oxidize both biodegradable and non-biodegradable organic matter in water. 
  • It is widely used for monitoring industrial wastewater and polluted surface waters.
  • In COD testing, potassium dichromate (K₂Cr₂O₇) is used as a strong oxidizing agent in an acidic medium (typically sulfuric acid). 
  • It oxidizes nearly all types of organic compounds present in the sample. 
  • The amount of dichromate consumed correlates with the quantity of oxidizable organic matter, and this is expressed in terms of mg/L of oxygen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylene blue: Incorrect. Methylene blue is not an oxidizing agent; it is commonly used in biological staining and redox indicator tests (e.g., MBRT for milk quality), not in COD estimation.

 

Option B. Potassium permanganate: Incorrect. Although it is an oxidizing agent, potassium permanganate is typically used in Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD) or other selective oxidizing tests. It is less efficient than dichromate for COD due to incomplete oxidation of some organic compounds.

 

Option D. Ferric chloride: Incorrect. Ferric chloride is used as a coagulant in water treatment, not as an oxidizing agent in COD testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Potassium dichromate is the standard oxidizing agent used in COD testing because it can oxidize a wide range of organic compounds in water, providing a reliable measure of total organic pollution.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about epistaxis are correct? 

 

  1. Kiesselbach’s plexus is the source of bleeding in majority of epistaxis cases.
  2. Prophylactic antibiotics are indicated if anterior nasal packing is retained for prolonged period.
  3. Anterior nasal pack is easier to insert and less traumatic compared to balloon tamponade.
  4. Trotter’s method involves sitting with head bent forward and mouth open.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Statement 1. Kiesselbach’s plexus is the source of bleeding in majority of epistaxis cases:  True. Kiesselbach’s plexus (Little’s area) is responsible for ~90% of anterior epistaxis cases.

 

Statement 2. Prophylactic antibiotics are indicated if anterior nasal packing is retained for prolonged period: True. Prophylactic antibiotics are recommended if anterior nasal packing is retained for more than 24 hours, not 48 hours.

 

Statement 3. Anterior nasal pack is easier to insert and less traumatic compared to balloon tamponade: True. Anterior nasal packing is easier to apply and less traumatic than balloon tamponade, which may be used when there's coagulopathy or difficult access.

 

Statement 4. Trotter’s method involves sitting with head bent forward and mouth open: True. Trotter’s method is a first-aid technique where the patient is made to sit upright, bend the head forward, and breathe through an open mouth — this prevents blood aspiration and allows clotting.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • In managing epistaxis, most anterior bleeds originate from Kiesselbach’s plexus. 
  • First aid includes the Trotter’s method, and anterior nasal packing is commonly used, with antibiotics if retained beyond 24 hours. 
  • Balloon tamponade is reserved for coagulopathic or posterior bleeds.

questions.text: Occlusion of the artery supply to the marked  area (blue circle) will cause all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stereognosis

 

  • The structure marked in the image is the paracentral lobule, located on the medial surface of the cerebral hemisphere.
  • It includes parts of the precentral (motor) and postcentral (sensory) gyri, specifically representing the contralateral lower limb and perineum.

 

Arterial Supply

 

  • The anterior cerebral artery (ACA), particularly its pericallosal branch, supplies the paracentral lobule.

 

Clinical Features of Paracentral Lobule Infarct (ACA Stroke)

 

  • Infarction or occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery, affecting the paracentral lobule, may result in:
  • Contralateral lower limb motor and sensory loss
  • Urinary and fecal incontinence
  • Perianal and perineal anesthesia
  • Abulia, akinetic mutism (if medial frontal lobe more extensively involved)

 

Why Stereognosis is Incorrect

 

  • Stereognosis is the inability to recognize objects by touch alone, without visual input.
  • It results from a lesion in the parietal lobe, particularly the superior parietal lobule (somatosensory association cortex), not the paracentral lobule.
  • Hence, it is not caused by ACA occlusion affecting the paracentral lobule.
  • False: This is due to parietal lobe lesion, not ACA territory.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Urinary incontinence: True. Paracentral lobule is involved in the cortical control of micturition.

 

Option B. Rectal incontinence : True. Same as above; cortical control of defecation.

 

Option D. Perianal anesthesia: True. Sensory area for perineum and lower limb lies in the paracentral lobule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The paracentral lobule, supplied by the anterior cerebral artery, controls motor and sensory function of the contralateral lower limb and perineum, and is involved in voluntary micturition and defecation. 
  • Occlusion may cause urinary/fecal incontinence and perianal anesthesia, but not stereognosis, which is a function of the parietal association cortex.

choices.text: Administer IV alteplase and start aspirin
Perform CT Angiography and CT Perfusion

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with acute-onset weakness in the right arm and leg for 5 hours. She has a history of smoking and oral contraceptive use. BP is 160/95 mmHg, and CT brain is shown below. NIHSS score is 8. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Perform CT Angiography Only

 

  • Acute focal weakness suggest ischemic stroke (MCA infarct). CT scan suggest MCA territory hypodensity and there is no evidence of ICH.
  • Smoking and OCPs increase ischemic stroke risk in young women.
  • IV alteplase is indicated only within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. Patient has presented outside the window period for thrombolysis.
  • Patient is presenting within 6 hours and hence CT angiography should be the next step to look for large vessel occlusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer IV alteplase and start aspirin: Thrombolysis is C/I as patient is presenting outside the thrombolytic window.

 

Option B. Perform CT Angiography and CT Perfusion: Preferred in patients presenting between 6-24h to look for the size of penumbra. Not required in this case presenting < 6h.

 

Option C. Give Aspirin only: Aspirin alone is insufficient for acute stroke. One needs to check the eligibility for thrombolysis and Endovascular therapy before opting for conservative options.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Do not forget these - IV Alteplase < 4.5h if no contraindications. CTA to look for large vessel occlusion if presenting < 6h and CTA + CTP if presenting > 6h (6-24h) to look for the extent of penumbra.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements regarding opioids as True (T) or False (F):

 

  1. Norpethidine accumulation can cause seizures in renal failure.
  2. Loperamide is centrally acting and used in opioid withdrawal.
  3. Buprenorphine shows ceiling effect to respiratory depression
  4. Pentazocine may increase myocardial oxygen demand.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T, F, T, T

 

Statement 1. Norpethidine accumulation can cause seizures in renal failure: True. Norpethidine (normeperidine) is a neurotoxic metabolite of pethidine (meperidine).

 

  • In renal failure, it accumulates due to reduced clearance.
  • This can lead to central nervous system toxicity, including tremors, myoclonus, and seizures.

 

Statement 2. Loperamide is centrally acting and used in opioid withdrawal: False. Loperamide is a peripherally acting opioid.

 

  • It does not cross the blood-brain barrier significantly.
  • It is not used in opioid withdrawal.
  • It is an antidiarrheal agent acting on μ-opioid receptors in the GI tract.

 

Statement 3. Buprenorphine shows ceiling effect to respiratory depression: True. Buprenorphine is a partial μ-opioid receptor agonist.

 

  • It exhibits a ceiling effect on respiratory depression, making it safer in overdose.
  • It is used in opioid dependence and pain management.

 

Statement 4. Pentazocine may increase myocardial oxygen demand: True. Pentazocine is a κ-agonist and weak μ-antagonist/partial agonist.

 

  • It can cause sympathomimetic effects, such as increased heart rate and blood pressure.
  • This may increase myocardial oxygen demand, which is undesirable in ischemic heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pethidine is avoided in renal failure due to norpethidine-induced neurotoxicity.
  • Loperamide acts peripherally and is used in diarrhea, not withdrawal.
  • Buprenorphine offers respiratory safety via a ceiling effect.
  • Pentazocine and other κ-agonists with cardiostimulant properties should be avoided in ischemic heart disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored stools to the OPD. After undergoing endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper GI bleed. Which of the following is not included in upper GI bleed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meckel’s diverticulitis

 

  • Meckel’s diverticulitis is not a cause of upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.
  • Meckel’s diverticulum arises from the distal ileum, making it part of the lower GI tract.
  • While it can cause painless bleeding, especially in children, it's anatomically not part of the upper GI (which ends at the ligament of Treitz). 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. GAVE: GAVE (Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia) is a vascular lesion in the antrum of the stomach, sometimes called "watermelon stomach". It can cause chronic or acute upper GI bleeding, often leading to iron-deficiency anemia.

 

Option C. Duodenal Adenocarcinoma: The duodenum is part of the upper GI tract, and tumors here may ulcerate or erode vessels, causing bleeding. Although rare, duodenal cancers can present with melena or anemia due to occult or overt bleeding.

 

Option D. Mallory-Weiss Tear: Its is a mucosal laceration at the gastroesophageal junction, often caused by forceful vomiting. It leads to hematemesis and is a classic cause of acute upper GI bleed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Upper GI bleeding sources lie proximal to the ligament of Treitz — includes esophagus, stomach, and duodenum.

questions.text: A 40 years old chronic smoker was scheduled for cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. He was induced with propofol and vecuronium and started on isoflurane for maintenance of anesthesia. During the procedure, the following capnograph plot was observed. What is the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Entry into the right-sided bronchus

 

  • Capnography is a graphical depiction of the CO2 exhaled into the ventilator. A normal capnogram is shown below:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Several conditions can lead to a biphasic capnogram, including:

 

  • Single-lung transplantation: Different emptying rates of the transplanted and native lungs can cause two distinct peaks in CO2 exhalation. 
  • Endobronchial intubation: Misplacement of the endotracheal tube, such as into the right main bronchus, can lead to uneven ventilation and two peaks. 
  • Severe kyphoscoliosis: In severe cases, uneven lung compression can cause different emptying patterns in each lung, resulting in a biphasic waveform. 
  • Sample tube leaks or other equipment issues: In some instances, leaks in the sampling tube or other equipment malfunctions can create a biphasic pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders can be managed by the HOLEP procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Benign enlargement of the prostate

 

  • HOLEP: Holmium laser enucleation of the prostate
  • Laser prostatectomy: Laser can be used to ablate or vaporise (e.g. green light laser) or enucleate (e.g. HOLEP) the prostate. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fistula in ano: Surgeries for fistula include fistulectomy, fistulotomy, LIFT and VAAFT.

 

Option B. Fissure in ano: Surgeries for fissure include anal dilation, lateral sphincterotomy of Notoras

 

Option D. Zenker’s diverticulum: Surgeries for Zenker’s include Dohlman procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Laser can be used to ablate or vaporise (e.g. green light laser) or enucleate (e.g. HOLEP) the prostate. 
  • Photoselective vaporisation of the prostate or green light laser has the advantage that vaporisation is haemostatic and this procedure can be performed even while patients are anticoagulated; however, it is unsuitable for a very large gland.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with jaundice, weight loss, and epigastric pain for 2 months. He has a history of chronic alcohol use. Serum bilirubin is 15.8 mg/dL, ALP 1280 IU/L, AST 120 U/L, and ALT 80 U/L. CT scan shows a pancreatic head mass with dilated CBD. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform ERCP

 

  • Jaundice, weight loss, and pancreatic mass suggest pancreatic adenocarcinoma.
  • Cholestatic Jaundice with biliary dilatation indicates obstruction, likely from the mass.
  • ERCP with stenting relieves obstructive jaundice and confirms diagnosis via brushings.
  • Chronic alcohol use is a risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
  • Tissue diagnosis via ERCP or EUS is needed before chemotherapy.
  • Staging (CT/PET) guides resectability and further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start gemcitabine and paclitaxel: Chemotherapy is premature without tissue confirmation or staging.

 

Option C. Do CA 19-9 levels: Elevated CA 19-9 in such cases may support malignancy but is not specific.

 

Option D. Prescribe ursodeoxycholic acid and observation: Ursodeoxycholic acid is for cholestasis, not malignancy; observation delays care

 

Educational Objective:

 

ERCP is critical for relieving biliary obstruction and obtaining a diagnosis in suspected pancreatic cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following hypotheses proposes that the physical and functional status of a specific chromatin region is determined by the patterns of histone posttranslational modifications (PTMs) and/or DNA methylation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epigenetic code

 

  • The epigenetic code hypothesis states that specific combinations and patterns of histone modifications—such as acetylation, methylation, phosphorylation, and ubiquitination—along with DNA methylation status, influence the chromatin’s structural configuration and its transcriptional activity.
  • These chemical modifications regulate whether chromatin is:
    • Open (euchromatin) – transcriptionally active
    • Condensed (heterochromatin) – transcriptionally silent
  • The epigenetic code operates without altering the DNA sequence and can be heritable, yet remains reversible, playing a key role in gene regulation, cell differentiation, and development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Genetic code: Incorrect. Refers to the triplet codon system that dictates how sequences of nucleotides in DNA or RNA are translated into amino acids in proteins. It does not involve chromatin regulation.

 

Option C. Nuclear body hypothesis: Incorrect. Involves the role of nuclear substructures like nucleoli and Cajal bodies, mainly associated with RNA synthesis and processing, not with chromatin state regulation.

 

Option D. PTM hypothesis: Incorrect. This term is not a formally established hypothesis. While posttranslational modifications are crucial, the term “epigenetic code” comprehensively describes their role in chromatin function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epigenetic code describes how specific histone modifications and DNA methylation patterns regulate chromatin structure and gene expression without altering DNA sequence.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with lobar pneumonia. A sputum sample was sent for culture, and the image below shows the growth observed on nutrient agar. Which of the following is the most probable organism based on the culture appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serratia marcescens

 

  • Serratia marcescens is a Gram-negative bacillus and member of the Enterobacteriaceae family.
  • It is known for producing prodigiosin, a red pigment, giving colonies a distinctive red color on culture media like nutrient agar.
  • It can cause nosocomial infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and wound infections, especially in immunocompromised patients or those with indwelling devices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Typically forms blue-green or metallic colonies due to pyocyanin and pyoverdine, not red.

 

Option C. Klebsiella pneumoniae: Forms large, mucoid colonies due to a thick capsule, but not red pigment-producing.

 

Option D. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Forms alpha-hemolytic (greenish) colonies on blood agar, and is Gram-positive, not a red pigment producer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serratia marcescens is identified by its characteristic red pigment production on culture media and can cause opportunistic infections including lobar pneumonia.

choices.text: Hormonal contraception should be delayed for 5 days after Ulipristal use
It can interfere with the efficacy of progestin-containing contraceptives if taken concurrently
It is approved for regular contraceptive use
It is used as a single dose for emergency contraception

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct clinical considerations when prescribing Ulipristal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is approved for regular contraceptive use.

 

  • Ulipristal acetate is a selective progesterone receptor modulator approved only for emergency contraception—in a single 30 mg dose taken within 120 hours after unprotected intercourse. 
  • It is not licensed for regular, ongoing contraception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hormonal contraception should be delayed for 5 days after ulipristal use: True. Ulipristal’s mechanism can be antagonized by progestins, so combined hormonal methods should be postponed for at least 5 days and a barrier method used in the interim.

 

Option B. It can interfere with the efficacy of progestin-containing contraceptives if taken concurrently: True. Ulipristal binds progesterone receptors and may reduce the action of concurrently administered progestins, compromising regular hormonal contraceptive effectiveness.

 

Option D. It is used as a single dose for emergency contraception: True. as ulipristal is specifically indicated for single-dose emergency contraception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulipristal is a selective progesterone receptor modulator used for single-dose emergency contraception, and is not approved for continuous contraceptive use.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with fatigue, joint pain, and progressive skin darkening despite limited sun exposure. On examination, he has hepatomegaly and bronze-colored skin. Laboratory findings reveal: ↑ Serum ferritin and ↑ Transferrin saturation. A liver biopsy is performed, and the histologic image is given below. Which type of cardiomyopathy is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dilated cardiomyopathy           

 

  • The patient has hereditary hemochromatosis, characterized by excessive iron absorption and deposition in multiple organs, including the liver, skin, pancreas, joints, and heart.
  • Iron overload in the myocardium leads to:
    • Early: Diastolic dysfunction
    • Late: Dilated cardiomyopathy with systolic heart failure
  • The biopsy image shows Perls Prussian blue stain, which detects iron in tissues (positive blue granules).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: Can occur in iron overload but is less common than the dilated form.

 

Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: Usually genetic (e.g., sarcomere mutations); not linked to iron overload.

 

Option D. Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC):  Involves fibrofatty replacement of right ventricle, unrelated to iron deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hereditary hemochromatosis can lead to iron deposition in the myocardium, most commonly resulting in dilated cardiomyopathy and heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the Triangle of Auscultation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serratus anterior

 

  • The Triangle of Auscultation is a small, relatively thin muscular region on the back, where respiratory sounds can be heard clearly with a stethoscope due to minimal muscular covering.

 

Boundaries of the Triangle of Auscultation:

 

  • Medial (superior): Trapezius muscle
  • Inferior: Latissimus dorsi muscle
  • Lateral: Medial border of the scapula

 

Floor:

 

  • Formed by the rhomboideus major and 7th rib
  • Deep to this triangle lies the cardiac end of the stomach, making this an acoustically favorable site for auscultation, especially for sounds like swallowed fluids.

 

Why Serratus anterior is incorrect:

 

  • Serratus anterior is inserted on the medial border of the scapula but lies anterior to it.
  • Therefore, it is not part of the triangle’s posterior boundaries and does not contribute to the triangle of auscultation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Boundaries of the Triangle of Auscultation:

 

  • Medial (superior): Trapezius muscle
  • Inferior: Latissimus dorsi muscle
  • Lateral: Medial border of the scapula

questions.text: A researcher is studying the relationship between physical activity levels and resting heart rate in a group of 150 adults. The analysis yields a Pearson correlation coefficient (r) of -0.83. Which of the following best describes the relationship between the two variables?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strong negative correlation

 

  • Correlation coefficient (r) is depicted by scattered diagram – Relationship between 2 quantitative variables 
  • The Pearson correlation coefficient (r) quantifies the linear relationship between two continuous variables. It ranges from -1 to +1:
    • r = 0 - +1 → Perfect positive linear relationship. Smoking lung cancer 
    • r = -1 - 0 → Perfect negative linear relationship. Smoking ulcerative colitis 
    • r = 0 → No linear correlation
  • General interpretation of r:
    • to ±0.3 → Weak correlation
    • 0.4 to 0.6 → Moderate correlation
    • ≥0.7→ Strong correlation
  • In this case, r = -0.83, which falls in the strong negative range, indicating that as physical activity increases, resting heart rate tends to decrease significantly—a biologically plausible and expected relationship.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Correlation coefficients (r) near -1 or +1 indicate strong relationships. An r of -0.83 suggests a strong inverse correlation—important in interpreting epidemiologic and research data.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with human babesiosis. The vector responsible is identified to have a scutum and is incapable of surviving without a host for more than a few days. Identify the vector?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hard tick

 

  • The vector responsible for human babesiosis is the hard tick, specifically Ixodes scapularis (also known as the deer tick or blacklegged tick).
  • It transmits Lyme disease, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and tick-borne relapsing fever.
  • Key identifying features that support this include:
    • Presence of a scutum: A hard dorsal shield, characteristic of hard ticks (Ixodidae), which soft ticks (Argasidae) lack.
    • Short survival without host: Hard ticks are obligate blood feeders, especially in the nymph and adult stages, and cannot survive long without a host.
    • Transmission of Babesia microti, the causative agent of babesiosis in humans, is via the bite of infected Ixodes scapularis, which is also a vector for Lyme disease and anaplasmosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft tick: Soft ticks lack a scutum, have a leathery body, and are typically vectors for relapsing fever (e.g., Borrelia species). They are not responsible for transmission of babesiosis. It transmits  diseases like – Q fever, relapsing fever.

 

Option C. Louse: Lice are ectoparasites of humans but do not transmit Babesia. They are involved in the spread of epidemic typhus (Rickettsia prowazekii), trench fever, and relapsing fever, not babesiosis.

 

Option D. Mite: Mites can transmit rickettsial pox or cause scabies, but do not serve as vectors for Babesia microti. Mites lack a scutum and have different feeding and transmission mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Babesiosis is transmitted to humans by the Ixodes scapularis (hard tick), which has a scutum and is unable to survive long without a host. The scutum is a key morphological feature distinguishing hard ticks from soft ticks.

questions.text: A sexually active male presented with warts on his penis as shown below. Which of these strains of HPV is most commonly the cause of these lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HPV 6 and 11

 

  • The clinical image shows classic genital warts (condyloma acuminata) — soft, fleshy, cauliflower-like papules on the penile shaft and foreskin. 
  • These are caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection, commonly types 6 and 11.
  • Etiology and Virology:
    1. HPV Types 6 and 11:
      • Cause 90% of genital warts
      • Have low oncogenic potential
      • Are responsible for condyloma acuminata — soft, pink, pedunculated or sessile warts
    2. HPV Types 16, 18, 31, 33:
      • High-risk oncogenic strains
      • Cause cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) and anogenital cancers
    3. HPV Types 1, 2, 3, 5:
      • Cause non-genital (cutaneous) warts like common warts (verruca vulgaris) and flat warts
      • Not typically found in the genital area
  • Histological Features:
    • Koilocytosis (hallmark of HPV infection): Squamous epithelial cells with perinuclear halo and hyperchromatic nuclei
    • Other findings: Papillomatosis, acanthosis, parakeratosis, fibrovascular cores
  • Management:
    • Topical Therapy:
      • Podophyllin 15%, podophyllotoxin 0.5%
      • Imiquimod, 5-fluorouracil
      • Cryotherapy or electrosurgery for larger lesions
    • Vaccination (Quadrivalent HPV Vaccine – Gardasil):
      • Protects against HPV 6, 11, 16, 18
      • Recommended for males and females aged 9–26 years
      • Prevents genital warts, cervical cancer, anal cancer

 

Educational Objective:

 

Condyloma acuminata (genital warts) are most commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11, which are low-risk but highly contagious. Early treatment and HPV vaccination are key to prevention and control.

choices.text: Useful in situations where PO2 is low

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient with severe respiratory distress and diagnosed with Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is admitted to the ICU. The medical team decides to initiate mechanical ventilation with Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) to improve her oxygenation and reduce the workload on her lungs. Which of the following statements about Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decreases intracranial tension (ICT)

 

  • PEEP does not decrease intracranial tension; it actually has the potential to increase intracranial pressure (ICP). 
  • PEEP can elevate intrathoracic pressure, which may reduce venous return from the brain, leading to increased intracranial pressure, particularly in patients at risk for increased ICP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Useful in situations where PO2 is low: This statement is true. PEEP can help improve oxygenation in patients with compromised lung function by preventing alveolar collapse and maintaining functional residual capacity.

 

Option B. Decreases cardiac output: This is true. By increasing intrathoracic pressure, PEEP can reduce venous return to the heart, potentially leading to decreased cardiac output, especially if not properly managed.

 

Option C. Causes impairment in renal function: True. The increase in intrathoracic pressure due to PEEP can also decrease renal blood flow, which may impair renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognizing that PEEP, while beneficial for oxygenation, can increase intracranial pressure and adversely affect cardiac and renal functions, is crucial for managing patients on mechanical ventilation safely. 
  • This knowledge assists healthcare providers in balancing the benefits and risks of ventilatory support in critically ill patients.

choices.text: To suspect secondary hyperaldosteronism and start IV steroids
To suspect gram-negative sepsis and start IV antibiotics
To suspect adrenocortical insufficiency and start IV steroids
To suspect massive pulmonary thromboembolism and start IV heparin

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with long-standing disseminated tuberculosis presents to the emergency department in an emaciated state. He is hypotensive (BP: 85/60 mmHg), tachycardic (pulse: 100 bpm), and has diffuse hyperpigmentation, especially in the palmar creases. Labs reveal serum sodium of 120 mEq/L and potassium of 6.6 mEq/L. What is the most appropriate immediate management step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To suspect adrenocortical insufficiency and start IV steroids

 

  • This patient presents with classic signs of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease), likely due to adrenal destruction from tuberculosis, which is still a common cause in endemic areas.
  • Key features include:
    • Hypotension and tachycardia → Suggestive of hypovolemic or shock state
    • Hyponatremia and hyperkalemia → Due to aldosterone deficiency
    • Hyperpigmentation → Due to excess ACTH (which shares precursor with MSH)
    • Known risk factor (disseminated TB)
  • These features are hallmarks of primary adrenal failure, and immediate IV hydrocortisone (100 mg bolus, followed by IV fluids and maintenance steroids) is life-saving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To suspect secondary hyperaldosteronism and start IV steroids: Incorrect. Secondary hyperaldosteronism usually presents with hypokalemia and hypertension, not hyperkalemia or hypotension. Also, ACTH is not elevated, and there's no hyperpigmentation.

 

Option B. To suspect gram-negative sepsis and start IV antibiotics: While hypotension and hyponatremia may occur in sepsis, the hyperpigmentation and hyperkalemia point to Addison’s disease, not infection alone.

 

Option D. To suspect massive pulmonary thromboembolism and start IV heparin: Presents with sudden dyspnea, chest pain, and may cause hypotension, but does not cause electrolyte abnormalities or hyperpigmentation. This patient lacks any signs of acute PE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with disseminated TB, hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hyperpigmentation, primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) should be strongly suspected. The most urgent intervention is IV hydrocortisone, along with fluid resuscitation.

choices.text: The foot and ankle show pigmentation
Sclerotherapy is used in the treatment of smaller lesions
The laser ablation of the vein can begin below the knee
Presence of corona phlebectatica is clinical stage 4B

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the pathology shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Presence of corona phlebectatica is clinical stage 4B

 

  • According to the 2020 revision of CEAP, corona phlebectatica has been given a new designation: C4c.
  • It represents a distinct finding, separate from C4a (eczema/pigmentation) and C4b (lipodermatosclerosis/atrophie blanche).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. The foot and ankle show pigmentation: 

 

  • This is due to hemosiderin deposition caused by chronic venous hypertension and red blood cell breakdown.
  • It's typically seen in CEAP clinical class C4a, which includes pigmentation and eczema.

 

Option B. Sclerotherapy is used in the treatment of smaller lesions: 

 

  • Sclerotherapy is primarily used for reticular veins and telangiectasias, not major refluxing trunks.
  • It involves injecting a sclerosing agent into the vein, causing fibrosis and eventual obliteration.

 

Option C. The laser ablation of the vein can begin below the knee:

 

  • Improved laser technology now supports below-knee EVLA in selected patients, particularly with radial fiber lasers and ultrasound guidance, minimizing complications.
  • Stripping of GSV is avoided below knee due to risk of Saphenous nerve damage

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has been on a prolonged fasting regimen for 24 hours as part of a detox program. During this time, his body has shifted metabolic priorities to maintain glucose homeostasis and provide alternate fuel sources. Which of the following enzyme activities is expected to decrease in this fasting state?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1)

 

  • Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) is a rate-limiting enzyme in glycolysis, activated in the fed state when glucose is abundant.
  • In fasting, insulin levels fall, and glucagon rises, leading to inhibition of PFK-1 (via decreased fructose-2,6-bisphosphate), reducing glycolysis in liver to conserve glucose for vital organs like the brain.
  • Hormone-sensitive lipase is activated in fasting, promoting lipolysis for energy.
  • Glycogen phosphorylase increases in early fasting to mobilize glycogen stores.
  • Pyruvate carboxylase is increased, as it helps in gluconeogenesis by converting pyruvate to oxaloacetate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hormone-sensitive lipase: Incorrect. This enzyme increases during fasting due to elevated glucagon and epinephrine. It mobilizes stored triacylglycerols in adipose tissue into free fatty acids and glycerol for energy.

 

Option B. Glycogen phosphorylase: Incorrect. This enzyme is activated in the early fasting state (first 16–18 hours) to break down liver glycogen. At 24 hours of fasting, glycogen stores are mostly depleted, but its activity is initially increased, not decreased.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase: Incorrect. This is a key enzyme in gluconeogenesis, converting pyruvate to oxaloacetate. During fasting, gluconeogenesis increases, so pyruvate carboxylase activity is upregulated, not decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the fasting state, glycolysis is downregulated in the liver to conserve glucose. As a result, the activity of Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1), a key enzyme in glycolysis, is decreased.

choices.text: Instantaneous death due to high-voltage injury

questions.text: A medical officer at a hospital is evaluating a patient with electrocution. The individual has no detectable pulse or breathing, but their body is warm, and pupils are reactive to light. Which of the following best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suspended animation
