  • Suspended animation is a temporary cessation of visible life signs, often seen in electrocution victims. 
  • Despite appearing lifeless, the individual may still have minimal biological activity, which allows for reversibility with prompt medical intervention. 
  • Signs such as warm body temperature and pupillary response indicate that brainstem function is still intact, favoring suspended animation over actual death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rigor mortis: Rigor mortis develops hours after death and is characterized by stiffening of muscles, which is absent here.

 

Option C. Instantaneous death due to high-voltage injury: While high-voltage shocks can be fatal, many cases exhibit transient arrest (suspended animation) rather than immediate death.

 

Option D. Irreversible brain death: Brain death is confirmed by absent brainstem reflexes and apnea testing, not just by lack of visible breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Suspended animation is a state where vital functions (like heart rate and breathing) are significantly reduced or seemingly absent, but life is still present, and the individual can potentially be resuscitated. 
  • Electrocution is a known cause where this can occur, as the electrical current can disrupt the heart's rhythm and breathing without immediately causing irreversible cellular death, especially if the body remains warm and the brain still shows some reflexes (like pupillary reactivity).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, P2L2, gave birth to a healthy baby girl. She is breastfeeding and is concerned about her postpartum contraception options. What is the most suitable method for postpartum contraception during lactation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Progestin-only contraceptives

 

During lactation, progestin-only contraceptives are generally the most suitable method as they do not interfere with breastfeeding and have a lower risk of side effects compared to combined oral contraceptives.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Combined oral contraceptives: Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) contain both estrogen and progestin. These are not typically recommended for breastfeeding women, especially in the immediate postpartum period, because estrogen can reduce milk supply. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends avoiding these during the first six months postpartum for women who are breast feeding

 

Option B. Withdrawal method: It is a natural method with very high failure rate and hence not preferred.

 

Option D. Barrier methods: Barrier methods include condoms, diaphragms, and cervical caps. These do not interfere with breastfeeding. However, they are generally less effective at preventing pregnancy than hormonal methods or IUDs. Thus, while breastfeeding, progestin-only contraceptives are considered the most appropriate option due to their minimal impact on milk production and safety for the infant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contraceptives in breast feeding women:

 

  • Prefer Progesterone containing contraceptives as they do not interfere with lactation and do not increase the risk of thrombo-embolism.
  • Intra-uterine devices can also be used. These are to be inserted either within 48h of birth or after 6 weeks of delivery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman undergoes routine serological screening. Her TORCH panel reveals a recent exposure to a protozoal infection known to cross the placenta and cause congenital abnormalities. To confirm the diagnosis, the clinician requests a highly specific reference test that uses live tachyzoites and methylene blue dye to detect antibodies in the patient’s serum. Which of the following infections is most accurately diagnosed using this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasmosis

 

  • TORCH is a panel used to detect organisms that lead to congenital diseases. 
  • TORCH – Toxoplasma, others (syphilis), Rubella, CMV and Herpes 
  • The Sabin-Feldman dye test is the gold standard serological test for toxoplasmosis, caused by Toxoplasma gondii.
  • They also causes congenital malformation
  • It works by mixing live tachyzoites with patient serum and methylene blue; if antibodies are present, they neutralize the parasite, allowing uptake of dye, confirming infection.
  • This test is rarely used today in routine labs due to biosafety concerns but is still referenced as the most specific confirmatory test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Balantidiasis: Caused by Balantidium coli, diagnosed via stool microscopy, not via antibody or dye-based tests.

 

Option B. Trichomoniasis: A sexually transmitted infection by Trichomonas vaginalis, diagnosed using wet mounts or NAAT, not antibody-based tests.

 

Option C. Echinococcosis:  Caused by Echinococcus granulosus, identified via imaging (e.g., liver cysts) and ELISA, not dye-based serology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sabin-Feldman dye test detects antibodies against Toxoplasma gondii using live organisms and methylene blue, and serves as a specific test in diagnosing toxoplasmosis, especially in pregnant women at risk for congenital transmission.

choices.text: It enhances the growth of organisms that are lactose fermenters.
It selectively enriches Vibrio cholerae by using an alkaline pH that inhibits other intestinal flora.
It promotes the growth of Shigella species by using bile salts to inhibit gram-positive organisms.
It is a differential medium that distinguishes between Salmonella and Vibrio using hydrogen sulfide production.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the hospital with acute onset of profuse, watery diarrhea after returning from a rural area with poor sanitation. He shows signs of severe dehydration. The clinical team suspects cholera, and a stool sample is sent for microbiologic evaluation. The microbiology lab chooses to inoculate the sample into Venkatraman Ramakrishnan (VR) medium, rather than using other selective broths. Which of the following best explains why VR medium is preferred in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It selectively enriches Vibrio cholerae by using an alkaline pH that inhibits other intestinal flora.

 

  • Venkatraman Ramakrishnan (VR) medium is a selective enrichment broth used specifically for culturing Vibrio cholerae. It is transport media as well as an enrichment media
  • It contains alkaline peptone water (high pH ~8.5–9.0), which inhibits the growth of normal enteric flora like E. coli, Shigella, and Salmonella.
  • Vibrio cholerae, being an alkaliphilic organism, thrives in this environment, allowing its selective growth and detection in stool samples.
  • Other media like Selenite F or Tetrathionate broth are designed for Salmonella and Shigella, not Vibrio.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It enhances the growth of organisms that are lactose fermenters:  Incorrect. VR medium is not intended for lactose fermenters like E. coli; it actually inhibits them.

 

Option C. It promotes the growth of Shigella species by using bile salts to inhibit gram-positive organisms: Incorrect. This describes media like XLD or SS agar, not VR medium. It promotes growth of Vibrio not Shigella 

 

Option D. It is a differential medium that distinguishes between Salmonella and Vibrio using hydrogen sulfide production: Incorrect. This describes XLD agar or HE agar, not enrichment media like VR. It is for TSI agar 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Venkatraman Ramakrishnan medium is an alkaline enrichment broth specifically designed to promote the selective growth of Vibrio cholerae by inhibiting normal gut flora through its high pH.
  •  It is preferred over other selective media when cholera is suspected.

choices.text: Type C (Distal TEF with proximal esophageal atresia)
Type A (Pure esophageal atresia without TEF)
Type D (TEF with both proximal and distal fistulas)
Type E (H-type TEF without esophageal atresia)

questions.text: A newborn developed excessive frothing and bubbling from the mouth and nose immediately after birth. On attempting to pass a nasogastric tube, there is resistance at 10cm. The following observations are noted on the chest X-ray. Mother's antenatal scan had shown polyhydramnios. Which type of tracheoesophageal fistula is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type A (Pure esophageal atresia without TEF)

 

  • This is a case of TEF as the patient is having frothing and bubbling immediately after birth
  • They are of 5 types – Type A, B, C, D and E
  • Type C, D and E will have gas in the abdomen and type A and B does not produce gas in the abdomen.
  • The newborn shows excessive frothing and bubbling from the mouth and nose immediately after birth, and a nasogastric tube meets resistance at 10 cm, indicating esophageal obstruction. 
  • Maternal polyhydramnios suggests impaired fetal swallowing. On chest X-ray, a coiled tube in the proximal pouch with a gasless abdomen confirms pure esophageal atresia without distal tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF), classified as Type A (Gross/Vogt Type II). 
  • Absence of gas below the diaphragm is the key radiographic feature distinguishing it from variants with a distal fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type C (Distal TEF with proximal esophageal atresia): The commonest variant (~85 %) has gas in the stomach and intestines due to the distal fistula; the abdomen would not be gas-free on X-ray, so this choice is inconsistent with the described findings.

 

Option C. Type D (TEF with both proximal and distal fistulas): Extremely rare; both upper and lower pouches communicate with the trachea, producing mixed radiologic signs, typically with some distal gas—again unlike the presented gasless abdomen.

 

Option D. Type E (H-type TEF without esophageal atresia): Characterized by a fistulous tract without esophageal interruption; a nasogastric tube passes freely into the stomach, so resistance at 10 cm would not occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A gasless abdomen with inability to pass an NG tube in a frothing neonate signifies Type A pure esophageal atresia (no tracheoesophageal fistula).

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is false, but R is true
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Attitudes are permanent and resistant to change because they are inherited from elders.


Reason (R): Attitudes are acquired, organized beliefs that predispose behavior and are objective in nature.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A is false, but R is true

 

  • Assertion (A) Is False:
    • Attitudes are not inherited traits. Unlike genetic characteristics, attitudes form through interaction with the environment, not via biological transmission from elders. Although parents, teachers, and peers influence attitudes, these influences occur through socialization—modeling, reinforcement, persuasion—not genetic inheritance.
    • Attitudes can and do change over time. Life experiences (e.g., new information, cultural shifts, personal reflection) can reshape attitudes, demonstrating they are neither permanent nor wholly resistant to change.
  • On the other hand, the Reason (R) is true:
    • Attitudes are “acquired.” We develop attitudes by processing information, observing others, and integrating cultural norms. This learning process occurs throughout life.
    • They are “organized beliefs” that cluster around an object, issue, or behavior (for example, attitudes toward health care or environmental conservation). These beliefs form a coherent mental framework.
    • They “predispose behavior.” Attitudes guide how we interpret situations and decide to act—someone with a positive attitude toward exercise is more likely to work out regularly.
    • They are “objective in nature.” While influenced by personal values, well-formed attitudes rest on reasoned evaluation of evidence (e.g., scientific data) rather than pure emotion or whim.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: A is false, but R is true.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Attitudes aren’t fixed inheritances—they’re learned, organized belief systems shaped by experience and evidence, and remain open to change as new information or perspectives emerge.

 

Definitions: 

 

  • Opinion – Temporary provisional views on any point of can change easily. We can influence others 
  • Belief – It is permanent, more or less stable views on any point of debate 
  • Attitude – It is type of behaviour more or less permanent. It is based on organization of belief

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman with a history of gallstones presents with progressive right upper quadrant discomfort and unintended weight loss. Imaging shows a thickened gallbladder wall with irregular mucosal enhancement. She undergoes cholecystectomy. The gross specimen is shown in the image. Histopathology reveals glandular structures with cellular atypia invading the muscular wall of the gallbladder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gallbladder carcinoma

 

  • The gross image reveals a nodular, infiltrative mass arising from the gallbladder wall. While gallbladder carcinoma can mimic chronic cholecystitis, it typically presents with:
    • Mass replacing or infiltrating the gallbladder wall
    • Irregular thickening or ulceration
    • Often associated with long-standing cholelithiasis (gallstones)
    • Most commonly adenocarcinoma
  • This malignancy is frequently discovered incidentally during cholecystectomy for presumed benign disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic cholecystitis:  Can cause thickened gallbladder wall and fibrosis, but not the mass-forming lesion seen here.

 

Option C. Gallbladder polyp: Usually small and pedunculated, without invasive growth.

 

Option D. Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis: Rare, with yellow nodules and foamy histiocytes, not the irregular tumor mass shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gallbladder carcinoma often mimics chronic cholecystitis grossly but presents as a mass-forming lesion with wall infiltration and is strongly associated with gallstones.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered an adverse effect of carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blurred vision

 

  • Carbamazepine causes side effects like
    • Allergy 
    • ADH →↓Na+
    • Agranulocytosis
    • Autoinducer
  • Blurred vision is more typical of drugs like phenytoin or topiramate.
  • While carbamazepine may cause diplopia and nystagmus, frank blurred vision is not a hallmark adverse effect.
  • Hence, this is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rash: True adverse effect

 

  • Carbamazepine is well known to cause cutaneous hypersensitivity reactions, including maculopapular rash.
  • Can range from mild to severe.

 

Option B. Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS): True adverse effect.

 

  • A serious and potentially life-threatening skin reaction.
  • Associated particularly in patients with HLA-B*1502 allele, more common in Asian populations.
  • This is a well-established severe adverse effect of carbamazepine.

 

Option D. Agranulocytosis: True adverse effect.

 

  • A rare but serious hematologic adverse effect of carbamazepine.
  • It necessitates monitoring of complete blood count (CBC) during therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carbamazepine is associated with serious adverse effects like rash, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, and agranulocytosis, but blurred vision is not a classical or prominent side effect of this drug.

questions.text: Identify the monitoring tool:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiotocogram (CTG)

 

  • A cardiotocogram (CTG) records fetal heart rate and uterine contractions simultaneously.
  •  It is used during labor to monitor fetal well-being and detect any signs of distress. 
  • The FHR is displayed on one graph, while uterine contractions are recorded on a separate but aligned graph.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Non-Stress Test (NST): An NST only records fetal heart rate and does not monitor uterine contractions. It is typically used in the antepartum period.

 

Option C. Doppler Ultrasound: Doppler ultrasound measures blood flow but does not provide continuous monitoring or graphical output.

 

Option D. Fetal Scalp Electrode: This is an internal monitoring tool for FHR during labor but does not produce a graph combining FHR and uterine contractions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A cardiotocogram (CTG) is used to monitor fetal heart rate and uterine contractions during labor, providing crucial information for fetal surveillance.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman is diagnosed with Cushing syndrome due to an ACTH-independent adrenal adenoma. Surgery is scheduled, but preoperative control of hypercortisolism is needed. An antifungal drug is considered for this. Which of the following antifungal agents is most appropriate in this setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ketoconazole

 

  • Ketoconazole, though originally developed as an antifungal agent, is also a potent inhibitor of adrenal and gonadal steroid synthesis.
  • It inhibits multiple cytochrome P450 enzymes, especially 17α-hydroxylase and 11β-hydroxylase, which are involved in cortisol and androgen biosynthesis.
  • Ketaconazole is enzyme inhibitor. It inhibits CYP enzyme which help in formation of steroids.
  • This makes it useful for medical management of Cushing syndrome, especially when surgery is delayed or contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fluconazole: Primarily inhibits fungal 14-α-demethylase; has minimal effect on human steroidogenesis.

 

Option C. Itraconazole: Antifungal with some inhibitory action on steroidogenesis but much weaker than ketoconazole and not typically used in Cushing's management.

 

Option D. Miconazole: Used topically; not systemically absorbed well; not relevant for treating systemic endocrine disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ketoconazole inhibits adrenal steroidogenesis and can be used off-label for medical management of Cushing syndrome. Its use is limited by hepatotoxicity, so monitoring of liver enzymes is essential during therapy.

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the karyotype given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cri-du-chat syndrome

 

  • Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by a deletion on chromosome 5p and presents with:
    • Cat-like cry
    • Microcephaly
    • Intellectual disability
    • Distinctive facial features

       

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bloom Syndrome:

 

  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive
  • Gene: Mutation in BLM gene (codes for a RecQ DNA helicase)
  • Chromosomal abnormality: Chromosomal instability syndrome with frequent chromosomal breaks and rearrangements
  • Clinical features:
    • Growth retardation
    • Sun-sensitive facial rash (telangiectatic erythema)
    • Immunodeficiency (low IgM and IgA)
    • Increased risk of leukemias and solid tumors due to genomic instability
  • Mnemonic: “Blooming DNA damage”

 

Option C. Angelman Syndrome:

  • Inheritance: Typically due to maternal deletion of 15q11–q13
  • Mechanism: Imprinting disorder — maternal allele missing or silenced, and paternal allele is imprinted (inactive)
  • Gene: UBE3A (Ubiquitin-protein ligase E3A)
  • Clinical features:
    • Male child
    • Severe intellectual disability
    • Seizures
    • Happy demeanor, frequent laughing and smiling (“happy puppet”)
    • Ataxia and jerky movements
    • Macrocephaly
  • Mnemonic: “Angelman is always smiling and clapping”

 

Option D. Fragile X Syndrome:

  • Inheritance: X-linked dominant
  • Gene: FMR1 gene on X chromosome with CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion
  • Pathophysiology: Hypermethylation → gene silencing
  • Clinical features:
    • Intellectual disability (second most common genetic cause after Down syndrome)
    • Long face with large ears
    • Macroorchidism (enlarged testes after puberty)
    • Autism features, hyperactivity
  • Mnemonic: “Fragile chin, fragile testicles”

     

Educational Objective:


Cri-du-chat is characterized by 5p deletion and cat-like cry; confirmed on karyotyping.

questions.text: A law of population genetics states that the genotype frequencies in a population remain constant or are in equilibrium from generation to generation unless specific disturbing influences are introduced. In which of the following situations, it is applicable?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Random mating populations

 

  • The law referred to in the question is the Hardy-Weinberg Principle. It states that allele and genotype frequencies in a large, randomly mating population will remain constant across generations in the absence of evolutionary pressures, such as:
    • Mutation
    • Migration (gene flow)
    • Genetic drift
    • Non-random mating
    • Natural selection
  • The Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium only holds true in an ideal population, which includes random mating as one of the essential criteria. Therefore, the principle is applicable to random mating populations, making Option C the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Natural selection: Incorrect. Natural selection is a disturbing influence that causes changes in allele frequencies over time by favoring advantageous traits. Thus, it violates Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.

 

Option B. Dynamic populations: Incorrect. The term "dynamic" implies ongoing changes in population structure, migration, birth/death rates, or allele frequency, which contradicts the conditions required for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.

 

Option D. Small populations: Incorrect. Small populations are more susceptible to genetic drift, which leads to random fluctuations in allele frequencies and disrupts Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hardy-Weinberg Principle applies to random mating populations where no disturbing evolutionary influences (e.g., selection, mutation, migration, drift) are present, allowing genotype frequencies to remain constant across generations.

questions.text: All of the following are features of Brown-Séquard syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contralateral dorsal column loss

 

  • Dorsal column fibers do not decussate at the level of entry. They ascend ipsilaterally and cross over in the medulla. Thus, loss is ipsilateral, not contralateral.
  • Brown-Séquard syndrome is a neurological condition resulting from hemisection (one-sided injury) of the spinal cord, affecting both ascending and descending tracts.
  • Tracts Involved and Their Features:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ipsilateral pyramidal tract features: True. Corticospinal tract lesion → weakness and UMN signs on same side.

 

Option C. Contralateral spinothalamic tract loss: True. Spinothalamic fibers cross 1–2 levels above entry, so a unilateral lesion causes opposite-sided pain and temperature loss.

 

Option D. Ipsilateral extensor plantar response: True. Due to UMN lesion in the corticospinal tract, the Babinski sign is positive on the same side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Brown-Séquard syndrome is characterized by:
    • Ipsilateral loss of motor function and proprioception (corticospinal and dorsal column)
    • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation (spinothalamic tract)

choices.text: Hypoperfusion of kidneys causing increased BUN reabsorption
Necrotic tubular epithelial cell obstruction reducing GFR

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man is hospitalized for treatment of sepsis and receives intravenous antibiotics and fluids. Two days later, he develops oliguria. Labs reveal:

 

  • BUN: 42 mg/dL
  • Creatinine: 3.0 mg/dL
  • BUN:Cr ratio < 15
  • FENa > 2%
  • Urine osmolality < 500 mOsm/kg
  • Urine microscopy shows brown granular casts.

 

Which of the following best explains the mechanism of his renal dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Necrotic tubular epithelial cell obstruction reducing GFR

 

  • This patient has acute tubular necrosis (ATN) — a classic cause of intrarenal azotemia — often secondary to ischemia or nephrotoxins (e.g., antibiotics, contrast agents). 

 

Key findings:

 

  • Necrotic cells slough off and plug tubules, increasing tubular pressure and decreasing GFR
  • Brown granular casts (muddy casts) in urine = sloughed necrotic epithelial cells
  • ↓ BUN:Cr ratio (<15): BUN reabsorption impaired
  • ↑ FENa (>2%): Sodium-wasting due to tubular dysfunction
  • ↓ Urine osmolality (<500 mOsm/kg): Inability to concentrate urine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoperfusion of kidneys causing increased BUN reabsorption: Seen in pre-renal azotemia, not intrarenal. BUN:Cr ratio would be >20.

 

Option B. Immune complex deposition in glomeruli: Describes glomerulonephritis, not ATN. Would see RBC casts, not brown granular casts.

 

Option D. Tubulointerstitial inflammation with eosinophils: Seen in acute interstitial nephritis (AIN), often drug-induced. Presents with fever, rash, and eosinophiluria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is an intrarenal cause of acute kidney injury, characterized by necrotic tubular cells obstructing the nephron, leading to decreased GFR, muddy brown casts, low BUN:Cr ratio, and impaired urine concentrating ability.

choices.text: Both galactose and glucose are present in the medium.
Intracellular cAMP concentration is reduced due to high energy status.
A mutation prevents the repressor protein from binding to the operator sequence.
A mutation prevents the allolactose-like inducer from binding the repressor protein.

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios will result in high-level (efficient) transcription of the ZYA region of the lac operon?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A mutation prevents the repressor protein from binding to the operator sequence.

 

  • The lac operon is an inducible operon in E. coli that allows for the metabolism of lactose. 
  • Transcription of the ZYA genes (lacZ, lacY, lacA) is controlled by two main mechanisms:
    1. Negative control:
      • The repressor protein (encoded by lacI) binds the operator to block transcription.
      • In the presence of lactose (converted to allolactose), the repressor is inactivated, allowing transcription.
    2. Positive control:
      • When glucose is low, cAMP levels rise.
      • cAMP-CAP complex binds to the promoter to enhance RNA polymerase binding, increasing transcription.
  • If the operator is mutated and cannot bind the repressor, transcription will proceed regardless of lactose presence, leading to constitutive expression of the lac genes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Both galactose and glucose are present in the medium: Incorrect. Galactose is not the inducer of the lac operon, and glucose represses cAMP formation, reducing transcription efficiency.

 

Option B. Intracellular cAMP concentration is reduced due to high energy status: Incorrect. Low cAMP (high glucose) results in poor activation of the lac operon due to lack of CAP binding, leading to inefficient transcription.

 

Option D. A mutation prevents the allolactose-like inducer from binding the repressor protein: Incorrect. If the inducer cannot bind, the repressor remains active and stays bound to the operator, blocking transcription.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A mutation that disables repressor binding to the lac operator leads to unregulated transcription of the lac ZYA genes, regardless of the presence or absence of lactose.

questions.text: A young adult female presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of food over several weeks. She has a known history of iron deficiency anemia diagnosed 3 months ago. A barium swallow study is performed to investigate her symptoms. The radiologic image is given below. Based on the clinical features and imaging, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Plummer-Vinson syndrome

 

  • Plummer-Vinson syndrome (PVS) is characterized by the triad of:
    • Dysphagia (usually for solids)
    • Iron deficiency anemia
    • Esophageal web (typically in the cervical esophagus)
  • The image provided shows a thin, shelf-like filling defect in the upper esophagus on barium swallow, which is consistent with an esophageal web — a hallmark finding in PVS. 
  • This condition primarily affects middle-aged women, often with a nutritional deficiency background, particularly iron. 
  • The dysphagia in PVS is non-progressive and intermittent, improving with iron supplementation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schatzki ring: Incorrect. This refers to a lower esophageal mucosal ring seen near the gastroesophageal junction, typically associated with intermittent solid food dysphagia. It does not present in the cervical esophagus nor is it associated with iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option C. Mid-esophageal web: Incorrect. While esophageal webs can occur in various locations, Plummer-Vinson syndrome specifically involves the upper cervical esophagus, and the patient’s iron deficiency anemia and demographics support a syndromic diagnosis.

 

Option D. Cervical esophageal diverticulum: Incorrect. Such as Zenker’s diverticulum, which shows a posterior outpouching and causes regurgitation and halitosis. The image does not show a diverticulum, and the patient has iron deficiency anemia, not typically seen in diverticular disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Plummer-Vinson syndrome presents in young to middle-aged women with iron deficiency anemia and solid food dysphagia due to a cervical esophageal web. 
  • A barium swallow is the imaging modality of choice, and early recognition is essential due to its association with increased risk of esophageal carcinoma.

choices.text: Patchy cortical necrosis from acute ischemia
Glomerular hypercellularity with immune complex deposition
Progressive vascular narrowing with chronic ischemic parenchymal loss

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a 15-year history of poorly controlled hypertension dies from a myocardial infarction. At autopsy, examination of the kidneys reveals symmetrically shrunken organs with finely granular surfaces, as shown in the image. Which of the following best explains the pathologic appearance of his kidneys?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Progressive vascular narrowing with chronic ischemic parenchymal loss

 

  • The gross image shows a kidney with a finely granular surface, characteristic of benign nephrosclerosis, which is:
    • Most commonly associated with longstanding "essential" hypertension
    • Caused by hyaline arteriolosclerosis—deposition of pink, glassy hyaline material in the walls of small renal vessels
    • Leads to gradual narrowing of lumens, causing:
      • Chronic ischemia
      • Patchy tubular atrophy
      • Interstitial fibrosis
      • Resulting in the granular contracted kidney
  • This process is typically slow and progressive, and renal failure is either absent or mild unless superimposed damage occurs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patchy cortical necrosis from acute ischemia: Seen in severe acute vascular compromise, e.g., DIC or obstetric emergencies—not a feature of benign nephrosclerosis.

 

Option B. Glomerular hypercellularity with immune complex deposition: Suggests glomerulonephritis (e.g., post-streptococcal GN), which presents with different histology and clinical course.

 

Option D. Corticomedullary abscesses from ascending bacterial infection: Seen in acute pyelonephritis, would show abscesses and not uniform granularity or vascular changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benign nephrosclerosis results from hyaline arteriolosclerosis due to chronic hypertension or diabetes, leading to progressive parenchymal ischemia and granular kidney morphology.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with dyspnea and peripheral edema. Examination reveals S3 and S4 with hepatomegaly and Jugular venous distension. ECG and Echocardiogram is shown below. EF is 50%. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiac amyloidosis

 

  • Patient presents with right heart failure features with clinical signs of myocardial involvement (presence of S3/S4). ECG shows low voltage complexes.
  • Echo shows thickened ventricles with granular texture suggest amyloid deposition.
  • Restrictive filling indicates diastolic dysfunction.
  • Abnormal light chain ratio supports AL amyloidosis.
  • Endomyocardial biopsy or Tc-PYP scan confirms diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: HCM in echo shows asymmetric hypertrophy, not granular texture. Also, in ECG one would expect high amplitude deflections due to LVH (not low voltage).

 

Option C. Constrictive pericarditis: Constrictive pericarditis involves pericardial thickening, not myocardial changes. Presents with pericardial knock and not S3/S4.

 

Option D. Dilated cardiomyopathy: Dilated cardiomyopathy features systolic dysfunction with a low EF (< 40%) and dilated chambers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac amyloidosis presents with restrictive cardiomyopathy which in turn presents with right heart failure and S3/S4 on examination. Do not forget the paradox – Low voltage complexes in ECG with thickened ventricles in echo.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is shown in the surgical procedure to repair the hernia with the help of a mesh and what type of mesh is generally used here?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IPOM, Dual mesh

 

  • Image shows IPOM repair with visible bowel and mesh fixation above.
  • Dual mesh is specially designed for intraperitoneal placement, with one side being non-adhesive (e.g., PTFE or a hydrogel coating) to prevent visceral adhesions, and the other promoting tissue integration. This is the mesh of choice in IPOM procedures.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. IPOM, Polypropylene mesh: Standard polypropylene mesh is not suitable for intraperitoneal use because it can adhere to and damage intra-abdominal organs like intestines and omentum. It's typically used in open hernia repairs or laparoscopic placements outside the peritoneal cavity.

 

Option C. TAPP repair, Polypropylene mesh and Option D. TAPP repair, Dual mesh: Image is showing an IPOM mesh repair. In TAPP, the peritoneum lies downwards and fascia transversalis lies upwards. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IPOM requires dual mesh to prevent complications like adhesions and fistula formation due to direct intra-abdominal contact.
  • Polypropylene mesh is safe only when kept away from intra-abdominal organs, such as in TAPP or other extraperitoneal approaches.

choices.text: Primary goal was to determine the sequence of chemical base pairs which make up DNA and to identify the genes of the human genome
Total number of genes found in human genome is approx. 19000-20000
The Sanger method became the dominant technique for the project for gene sequencing

questions.text: Look at the logo given below. Which of the following statements is not correct about this project?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Project started in 1995

 

  • The statement "Project started in 1995" is not correct. The Human Genome Project (HGP) officially began in 1990, not in 1995. 
  • It started on 1 oct 1990 – 14th April 2003
  • It was a collaborative international research initiative with the primary aim to map and understand all the genes of the human species. 
  • The project was completed in 2003, ahead of schedule and under budget.
  • Thus, option B is factually incorrect and is the right answer to the question asking for the incorrect statement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The primary goal was to determine the sequence of chemical base pairs that make up DNA and to identify the genes of the human genome: Correct; This was the central aim of the Human Genome Project: to sequence all 3 billion DNA base pairs in the human genome and identify all human genes to support medical and genetic research.

 

Option C. The total number of genes found in the human genome is approximately 19,000–20,000: Correct; The final estimates from the Human Genome Project identified approximately 19,000 to 20,000 protein-coding genes in the human genome, which was much fewer than initially expected.

 

Option D. The Sanger method became the dominant technique for the project for gene sequencing: Correct; The Sanger sequencing method, developed by Frederick Sanger, was the primary sequencing technique used during the Human Genome Project. It was chosen for its accuracy, despite being more labor-intensive than next-generation methods that emerged later.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Human Genome Project officially started in 1990, not 1995. Its goals were to sequence the entire human genome, identify all genes, and utilize this data for advancing medical and genetic knowledge. 
  • The project used the Sanger sequencing method and revealed that humans have approximately 19,000–20,000 protein-coding genes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman on warfarin therapy for stroke presents with prolonged, heavy menstruation. Which category of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) does this belong to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AUB-I 

 

  • The FIGO PALM-COEIN classification system is the standard for categorizing causes of abnormal uterine bleeding in nonpregnant women of reproductive age.
  • It divides causes into structural (PALM) and non-structural (COEIN) categories.

 

Breakdown of FIGO Classification:

 

 

  • Warfarin, an oral anticoagulant, affects the coagulation cascade by antagonizing vitamin K–dependent factors (II, VII, IX, X).
  • Its use can lead to excessive bleeding, including heavy menstrual bleeding.
  • Since this is due to drug effect, it falls under Iatrogenic (AUB-I).
  • Iatrogenic causes include:
    • Anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin, heparin)
    • Hormonal medications (e.g., HRT, contraceptives)
    • Other medications affecting endometrial hemostasis

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. AUB-N ("Not yet classified"): This is a diagnosis of exclusion used when a case doesn't fit into any other category, which doesn't apply here.

 

Option C. AUB-C (Coagulopathy): Refers to inherited bleeding disorders, such as:

 

  • Von Willebrand disease
  • Platelet function disorders

 

Warfarin-induced bleeding is not congenital, so this category does not apply.

 

Option D. AUB-O (Ovulatory dysfunction): Refers to anovulatory cycles, seen in:

 

  • PCOS
  • Thyroid disorders
  • Adolescents and perimenopausal women

 

There is no evidence of ovulatory dysfunction in this case; the cause is pharmacological.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to the FIGO PALM-COEIN classification, drug-induced bleeding, such as heavy menstruation caused by warfarin or other anticoagulants, is classified as AUB-I (Iatrogenic). 
  • This emphasizes the need to evaluate medication history in women presenting with abnormal bleeding.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man undergoes renal transplantation for end-stage diabetic nephropathy. As part of induction immunosuppression, he is administered a monoclonal antibody that binds to CD25. Which of the following monoclonal antibodies was most likely used?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Basiliximab

 

  • The drugs which bind to interleukin 2 receptors are Daclizumab and Basiliximab
  • Basiliximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody that targets the α‐chain of the interleukin-2 receptor (CD25) on activated T lymphocytes. 
  • By blocking IL-2 binding, it prevents T-cell proliferation and reduces acute rejection risk when used for induction in organ transplantation. 
  • Its specificity for CD25 makes it the agent of choice for transplant induction protocols.
  • They tend to lower immunity

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trastuzumab: Trastuzumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the HER2/neu receptor, used in HER2-positive breast and gastric cancers; it has no role in transplant immunosuppression or CD25 blockade.

 

Option C. Denosumab: Denosumab is a fully human monoclonal antibody against RANKL, used to inhibit osteoclast-mediated bone resorption in osteoporosis and bone metastases; it does not target immune cells.

 

Option D. Eptinezumab: Eptinezumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP), approved for migraine prophylaxis; it neither binds CD25 nor modulates transplant rejection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basiliximab—anti-CD25—blocks IL-2 signaling in activated T cells to prevent acute rejection during transplant induction, distinguishing it from cancer- or bone-targeted monoclonals.

choices.text: Beger procedure, dilated pancreatic duct with stones
Puestow procedure, dilated pancreatic duct with stones

questions.text: What is the name of the procedure performed in the image given below and its indication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Puestow procedure, dilated pancreatic duct with stones

 

  • The image shows the Puestow procedure, or longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy, indicated for chronic pancreatitis in patients with a dilated pancreatic duct (usually >7 mm). 
  • This technique allows direct drainage of pancreatic secretions into a Roux-en-Y jejunal loop, relieving ductal hypertension and associated abdominal pain.

 

The Procedure:

 

  • Involves longitudinal opening of the pancreatic duct
  • Preserves the pancreatic head (rules out option D)
  • Is effective in non-calcific, obstructive chronic pancreatitis
  • Avoids major pancreatic resection, unlike other alternatives

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Beger procedure, dilated pancreatic duct with stones and Option B. Beger procedure, inflamed pancreatic head: A duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection, used in chronic pancreatitis involving the head of the pancreas. It involves removal of inflammatory tissue but not a longitudinal ductal drainage like in Puestow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Puestow procedure is a surgical technique used in chronic pancreatitis with a dilated pancreatic duct, providing ductal decompression through a longitudinal pancreatico-jejunostomy, preserving pancreatic tissue while relieving symptoms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with joint pain, morning stiffness, and fatigue for 6 months. She has a history of dry eyes and mouth. RF is positive, anti-CCP is elevated, and ESR is 60 mm/hr. Hand X-ray is shown below. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Initiate methotrexate and folic acid

 

  • Joint pain, RF, anti-CCP, and erosions confirm rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
  • Dry eyes/mouth suggest secondary Sjögren’s syndrome, common in RA.
  • Methotrexate is first-line for RA, reducing disease activity and erosions.
  • Folic acid mitigates methotrexate toxicity.
  • ESR elevation reflects active inflammation, supporting DMARD use.
  • Low-dose steroids are adjunctive, not primary therapy.
  • Biologics (e.g., rituximab) are for methotrexate failure or in patients who have contraindications for the use of methotrexate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start hydroxychloroquine and low-dose prednisolone: Hydroxychloroquine is for mild RA or lupus, not erosive disease.

 

Option C. Prescribe rituximab and cyclophosphamide: Rituximab is for severe, refractory RA. Cyclophosphamide is rarely used in RA unless severe extra-articular manifestations like severe ILD.

 

Option D. Begin tofacitinib and NSAIDs: Tofacitinib is second-line and requires DMARD failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate is the cornerstone of therapy for erosive rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding T cell-independent antigens is/are incorrect?

 

  1. These antigens include lipids, nucleic acids, and polysaccharides.
  2. They require MHC class II presentation for B cell activation.
  3. They can directly stimulate B cells without the help of T helper cells.
  4. They generally produce a strong immunologic memory.
  5. IgM is the predominant antibody class produced in response to these antigens.
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Only statements 2 and 4 are incorrect

 

Statement 2. They require MHC class II presentation for B cell activation: Incorrect. T cell-independent antigens do not require antigen presentation via MHC class II, because T helper cells are not involved. Class II MHC presentation activates the T cells 

 

Statement 4. They generally produce a strong immunologic memory: Incorrect. They generally do not produce immunologic memory effectively, as T cell help is crucial for class switching and memory formation. T dependent pathway produces memory.

 

Correct Statements:


Statement 1. These antigens include lipids, nucleic acids, and polysaccharides: Correct. T cell-independent antigens are typically non-protein antigens, such as polysaccharides, lipids, and nucleic acids.

 

Statement 3. They can directly stimulate B cells without the help of T helper cells: Correct. These antigens can directly stimulate B cells, especially marginal zone B cells and B-1 cells, without T cell help.

 

Statement 5. IgM is the predominant antibody class produced in response to these antigens: Correct. The response to T cell-independent antigens is primarily IgM, with little or no class switching.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • T cell-independent antigens (like polysaccharides and lipids) activate B cells without T cell help, leading to IgM production without immunologic memory or class switching.
  • They do not require MHC class II antigen presentation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man in the ICU is found to have a systemic vascular resistance (SVR) twice the normal level, with associated hypertension and signs of reduced tissue perfusion. Cardiac output is borderline low. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacologic intervention to reduce afterload and improve tissue perfusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sodium nitroprusside

 

  • An elevated SVR indicates marked vasoconstriction, often seen in conditions like hypertensive crises or vasoconstricted shock states (e.g., cardiogenic shock with preserved BP).
  • Sodium nitroprusside is a potent arterial and venous vasodilator. 
  • It reduces both preload and afterload, making it especially useful in severe hypertension or high SVR states where improved peripheral perfusion and afterload reduction are needed

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenaline (epinephrine): Increases heart rate and alpha-mediated vasoconstriction, which may further raise SVR—not appropriate here.

 

Option B. Noradrenaline (norepinephrine): Primarily an alpha-1 agonist, causing potent vasoconstriction and increased SVR—used in vasodilatory shock, not in high-SVR states.

 

Option D. High dose dopamine: At high doses, dopamine stimulates α1 receptors, increasing SVR. Again, inappropriate in a patient with already elevated afterload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with markedly elevated systemic vascular resistance, sodium nitroprusside is an effective agent to rapidly reduce afterload, improve perfusion, and lower blood pressure. It acts via nitric oxide-mediated vasodilation.

questions.text: A mutation affecting the Gs alpha subunit leads to continuous stimulation of its downstream signaling pathway, even in the absence of ligand binding. Which of the following is the most likely intracellular consequence of this gain-of-function mutation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased cAMP

 

  • The Gs alpha subunit (Gαs) activates adenylyl cyclase, which increases cyclic AMP (cAMP) production from ATP. 
  • In conditions like McCune-Albright syndrome, a gain-of-function mutation keeps Gαs in its active GTP-bound state, continuously stimulating adenylyl cyclase and leading to persistently elevated intracellular cAMP levels, even in the absence of receptor stimulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased cAMP: Would occur with a loss-of-function in Gαs or an overactive Gi protein.

 

Option B. Decreased IP₃: IP₃ is part of the Gq pathway, not Gs; unrelated to cAMP levels.

 

Option C. Increased GTPase activity: Gs gain-of-function mutations actually impair GTPase activity, leading to prolonged activation rather than increased deactivation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A gain-of-function mutation in Gs alpha subunit leads to constitutive activation of adenylyl cyclase and a persistent increase in intracellular cAMP, causing dysregulated cellular signaling and manifestations such as those seen in McCune-Albright syndrome.

questions.text: A middle-aged female attending the psychiatry OPD for treatment shows the sign depicted in the image. This sign is present in which psychiatric disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Depression

 

  • The image shows an omega-shaped (Ω) fold on the forehead above the root of the nose, known as the "Omega sign".
  • This is a classical physical sign seen in patients with depression, particularly those with melancholic features. 
  • Along with Veraguth's fold (a triangular fold on the nasal side of the upper eyelid), the omega sign is one of the characteristic physical signs that may be observed in depressed patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schizophrenia: While schizophrenia can present with various physical manifestations, the omega sign is not a characteristic feature. Schizophrenia typically presents with positive symptoms (delusions, hallucinations), negative symptoms, and cognitive symptoms.

 

Option C. Generalised Anxiety Disorder: GAD presents with excessive worry and anxiety symptoms but does not have specific facial signs like the omega sign. Physical manifestations in GAD are usually related to autonomic arousal.

 

Option D. Dementia: While dementia can affect facial expression, the omega sign is not a characteristic feature. Dementia presents with cognitive decline, memory impairment, and functional deterioration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The omega sign, an omega-shaped fold on the forehead above the nose, is a classical physical sign of depression, particularly seen in patients with melancholic features.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Atopic Keratoconjunctivitis (AKC) is incorrect?

 

  1. AKC is commonly seen in elderly patients and is unrelated to any dermatologic condition.
  2. Itching, soreness, and mucoid discharge are common presenting symptoms.
  3. The tarsal conjunctiva in AKC has a milky appearance with fine papillae and possible scarring.
  4. The condition is associated with male predominance and is considered the adult counterpart of vernal keratoconjunctivitis.
  5. Corneal findings may include punctate epithelial keratitis, most prominent in the upper cornea, with risk of vascularization and thinning.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 5

 

AKC is often associated with atopic conditions like history of atopic dermatitis, eczema, asthma, and allergic rhinitis.

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Intense itching
  • Redness and watering of the eyes
  • Burning sensation
  • Blurred vision
  • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)

 

Signs:

 

  • Eyelid thickening and inflammation
  • Conjunctival papillae (cobblestone appearance)
  • Corneal involvement (keratitis, ulceration)
  • Potential scarring leading to visual impairment

 

Statement 1. AKC is commonly seen in elderly patients and is unrelated to any dermatologic condition: Incorrect.  AKC is typically seen in young atopic adults, not elderly, and is strongly associated with atopic dermatitis.

 

Statement 5. Corneal findings may include punctate epithelial keratitis, most prominent in the upper cornea, with risk of vascularization and thinning: Incorrect. Corneal involvement, including punctate epithelial keratitis, is more severe in the lower half, not the upper. Additional findings like vascularization, thinning, and plaques may also occur.

 

Correct Statements: 

 

Statement 2. Itching, soreness, and mucoid discharge are common presenting symptoms: Correct. Itching, soreness, dry sensation, and mucoid discharge are classic symptoms.

 

Statement 3. The tarsal conjunctiva in AKC has a milky appearance with fine papillae and possible scarring: Correct. The tarsal conjunctiva often appears milky, with fine papillae, hyperaemia, scarring, and shrinkage.

 

Statement 4. The condition is associated with male predominance and is considered the adult counterpart of vernal keratoconjunctivitis: Correct.  AKC shows male predominance and is often referred to as the adult equivalent of vernal keratoconjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Atopic keratoconjunctivitis is a chronic, sight-threatening allergic condition seen in young atopic males.
  •  It involves both conjunctival and corneal pathology, with characteristic symptoms and signs, including lower corneal involvement and tarsal scarring.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about breastfeeding are true? 

 

  1. Colostrum is rich in immunoglobulins and essential nutrients.
  2. Breast milk reduces the risk of infections and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS).
  3. Formula milk provides equivalent immune protection as breast milk.
  4. Breastfeeding lowers the risk of maternal postpartum depression.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

 

Statement 1. Colostrum is rich in immunoglobulins and essential nutrients: It is the first milk secreted post-birth, rich in IgA and proteins that protect against infections.

 

Statement 2. Breast milk reduces the risk of infections and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS): Breastfeeding has been linked to lower rates of gastroenteritis, respiratory infections, and SIDS.

 

Statement 4. Breastfeeding lowers the risk of maternal postpartum depression: Breastfeeding stimulates oxytocin release, which helps maternal bonding and mental health.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Formula milk provides equivalent immune protection as breast milk: False. Because formula milk lacks the immune components present in breast milk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Colostrum is rich in IgA & nutrients → True
  • Breastfeeding reduces infection risk & SIDS → True
  • Formula milk provides equal immunity → False
  • Breastfeeding lowers postpartum depression risk → True

choices.text: If both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A
If both A and R are correct, and R is not the correct explanation of A
If A is correct but R is wrong
If A is wrong but R is correct

questions.text:
Assertion: The skin lesions of incontinentia pigmenti are seen in an S-shaped pattern over the chest, abdomen, and flanks.

 

Reason: Incontinentia pigmenti follows Langer’s lines.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) If A is correct but R is wrong

 

Assertion. The skin lesions of incontinentia pigmenti are seen in an S-shaped pattern over the chest, abdomen, and flanks: Correct. The skin lesions of incontinentia pigmenti follow an S-shaped pattern over the chest, abdomen, and flanks. This follows Blaschko’s lines, which represent the lines of embryologic development of the skin.

 

Reason. Incontinentia pigmenti follows Langer’s lines: Incorrect. Incontinentia pigmenti does not follow Langer’s lines. Langer’s lines represent cleavage lines of tension in the skin, which are oriented along collagen fibre alignment in the dermis.

 

  • Blaschko’s lines do not correspond to arteries, veins, nerves, or lymphatics and have specific arrangements:
    • S-shaped whorls: Chest, abdomen, and flanks
    • V-shaped patterns: Back
    • Spiral: Scalp
  • Diseases following Blaschko’s lines include:
    • Incontinentia pigmenti (X-linked dominant)
    • Epidermal nevus

 

Educational Objective:

 

Skin lesions of incontinentia pigmenti follow Blaschko’s lines (embryologic skin development lines) and not Langer’s lines, which are cleavage lines of dermal collagen orientation.

questions.text: During which stage of embryonic development does implantation occur in the uterine wall?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blastocyst

 

  • Implantation occurs during the blastocyst stage of embryonic development. 
  • The blastocyst, a hollow structure, attaches to the uterine wall, beginning the process of pregnancy. 
  • Implantation begins on the 5th day (corresponds to the 20th day of a regular menstrual cycle) and is completed by the 10th- 11th day.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Implantation occurs at blastocyst stage 
  • Begins on the 5th day; complete by 11th day

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is commonly used in which of the following procedures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dilatation and evacuation

 

  • Instruments: Karman Cannula

 

 

  • Advantages: Less traumatic, transparent & disposable 
  • Sizes: 4–12 mm (number of cannula corresponds to diameter of cannula in millimeters)
  • Parts: 
    • Distal end: Double whistle at the terminal end; Proximal end: Fixes  into syringe. 
    • Superior overhanging edge acts as a curette. 
  • Used for:
  • Endometrial aspiration; Dilatation & curettage 
  • To remove retained products of conception in missed abortion 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dye instillation in hysterosalpingography: Incorrect. That procedure uses Leech Wilkinson's cannula or Rubin's cannula, not Karman cannula.

 

Option B. Fractional curettage: Incorrect. This involves separate curettage of endocervix and endometrium using sharp metal curettes, not Karman.

 

Option D. Endometrial biopsy: Incorrect. While Karman can be used for aspiration biopsy, its primary and common use is in D&C, especially for uterine evacuation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Karman Cannula is a disposable, flexible instrument used primarily in dilatation and curettage and manual vacuum aspiration procedures due to its safety and reduced risk of uterine injury compared to traditional metal curettes.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is evaluated for recurrent muscle cramps, fatigue, and dark-colored urine following intense physical activity. He also has a history of chronic hemolytic anemia. Laboratory findings show elevated creatine kinase (CK) and myoglobinuria after exercise. Further workup reveals accumulation of glycogen in muscle tissue and a deficiency of a key glycolytic enzyme active in both erythrocytes and skeletal muscle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tarui’s disease

 

  • Tarui’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type VII) is caused by a deficiency of phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) in muscle and erythrocytes.
  • Key features include:
    • Impaired glycolysis in skeletal muscle → exercise intolerance, muscle cramps
    • Inability to use glycogen for energy, leading to myoglobinuria after exercise
    • ATP deficiency in red blood cells → chronic hemolytic anemia
    • Typically presents in childhood or adolescence
  • The defective enzyme blocks glycolysis at the step converting fructose-6-phosphate → fructose-1,6-bisphosphate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. McArdle disease (GSD V): Incorrect. Caused by muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency. Also presents with exercise intolerance and myoglobinuria, but no hemolytic anemia, as erythrocytes are not affected.

 

Option B. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD): Incorrect. Causes hemolytic anemia, especially under oxidative stress, but does not affect muscles or cause myoglobinuria. Lactate level is increased in this condition.

 

Option D. Pyruvate kinase deficiency: Incorrect. Causes nonspherocytic hemolytic anemia but not associated with muscle anemia but myoglobinuria. In this, lactate level is decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tarui’s disease (GSD VII) is a rare glycogen storage disorder caused by phosphofructokinase-1 deficiency in both muscle and erythrocytes, leading to poor exercise tolerance, myoglobinuria, and hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with acute cholecystitis develops a sudden increase in pain. The abdomen shows cardboard rigidity on palpation. Imaging reveals free fluid around the liver. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gallbladder perforation

 

Gallbladder perforation is a complication of acute cholecystitis and presents with peritonitis and free fluid on imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gallstone ileus: Causes small bowel obstruction, not peritonitis.

 

Option B. Mirizzi syndrome: Involves obstruction of the bile duct by a gallstone without free fluid, leading to jaundice.

 

Option D. Biliary pancreatitis: Though this is likely, it is unrelated to the scenario of cholecystitis. It presents with epigastric pain radiating to the back. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gallbladder perforation is a surgical emergency in patients with acute cholecystitis and peritonitis, requiring immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with advanced liver disease presents with confusion and asterixis, suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy. Lab work reveals elevated serum ammonia levels. The body attempts to detoxify ammonia by incorporating it into amino acids via transamination reactions. One such reaction involves glutamate donating its amino group to oxaloacetate, forming two products (X and Y). Which of the following correctly identifies products X and Y?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspartate, α-ketoglutarate

 

  • The transamination reaction described is:
    Glutamate + Oxaloacetate ⇌ α-Ketoglutarate + Aspartate
    (Catalyzed by aspartate aminotransferase or AST)
  • This is important in the urea cycle, where aspartate donates a nitrogen for urea synthesis.
  • Glutamate transfers its amino group to oxaloacetate, forming aspartate and α-ketoglutarate.
  • This reaction is reversible and a key part of nitrogen metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alanine, α-ketoglutarate: Incorrect. This option incorrectly identifies alanine instead of aspartate. Alanine is produced when pyruvate accepts an amino group (not oxaloacetate). This occurs in muscle and is part of the glucose-alanine cycle, not directly relevant to the reaction described here.

 

Option C. Glutamate, alanine: Incorrect. This combination is incorrect because it suggests that glutamate is formed, when in this scenario, glutamate is actually the donor of the amino group, not a product. Also, alanine is not formed from oxaloacetate but from pyruvate.

 

Option D. Pyruvate, aspartate: Incorrect. This is an incorrect pairing. While aspartate is correctly identified, pyruvate is not a product of this reaction. Pyruvate results from transamination of alanine, not oxaloacetate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ammonia detoxification, glutamate donates its amino group to oxaloacetate to form aspartate and α-ketoglutarate—an essential transamination reaction that links amino acid metabolism with the urea cycle.

choices.text: School children proportion with enlarged thyroid
Proportion of houses consuming adequately iodised salt

questions.text: A state public health department reviews its surveillance data on iodine deficiency disorders (IDD). IDD Elimination criteria are based on all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adolescents’ proportion with enlarged thyroid

 

  • The IDD elimination criteria, as defined by WHO and adopted in India, focus on specific population groups and measurable indicators to evaluate iodine sufficiency at the population level. These criteria include:
    1. Prevalence of goiter (enlarged thyroid) in school-age children (6–12 years) being less than 5%.
    2. Median Urinary Iodine Excretion (UIE) level in school-age children should be ≥100 µg/L. It is measured in pregnant women over a 24 hour period (<100 mcg/L <50%; <50 mcg/L <20%)
    3. Proportion of households consuming adequately iodised salt should be >90%.
  • These indicators are used because school-age children (6–12 years) are considered the most sensitive and representative group for monitoring iodine status in a population.
  • IDD elimination criteria are based on indicators in school-age children, not adolescents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IDD elimination criteria are based on indicators in school-age children, not adolescents. Core criteria include goiter prevalence in children, urinary iodine excretion, and adequate iodised salt consumption in households.

questions.text: Match the following subcutaneous mycoses with their characteristic histopathological features:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B


1-D. Mycetoma → Granules (microcolonies of fungi or bacteria seen in draining sinuses)

 

 

2-C. Sporotrichosis → Asteroid bodies (Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon surrounding yeast cells) Asteroid bodies look like flower

 

 

3-A. Rhinosporidiosis → Spherules (large thick-walled sporangia filled with endospores)

 

 

4-B. Chromoblastomycosis → Sclerotic bodies (also called Medlar bodies or Copper penny bodies due to brown, thick-walled appearance)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subcutaneous mycoses have distinct microscopic features: Mycetoma shows granules, Sporotrichosis shows asteroid bodies, Rhinosporidiosis shows spherules, and Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by sclerotic (Medlar) bodies.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Woods corkscrew maneuver

 

The Woods corkscrew maneuver is an obstetric technique used to relieve shoulder dystocia by rotating the posterior shoulder in a corkscrew fashion to dislodge the impacted anterior shoulder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Piper's maneuver: This is used to deliver the fetal head in breech presentations, but involves guiding the head with forceps, not by hand support.

 

 

Option C. McRoberts maneuver: This maneuver involves flexing the mother’s thighs to her abdomen to alleviate shoulder dystocia and is unrelated to breech delivery or head flexion.

 

 

Option D. Ritgen's maneuver: It is used to control the delivery of the fetal head, especially in breech or vaginal deliveries, by placing a hand on the perineum and supporting the fetal chin to allow controlled head flexion. This maneuver helps minimize perineal trauma by controlling the descent and speed of head delivery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Woods corkscrew maneuver is an obstetric technique used to relieve shoulder dystocia by rotating the posterior shoulder in a corkscrew fashion to dislodge the impacted anterior shoulder.

questions.text: A 17-year-old adolescent presents with fever, sore throat, generalized lymphadenopathy, and fatigue. Physical exam reveals splenomegaly, and a Monospot test is ordered. This test detects heterophile antibodies that agglutinate sheep red blood cells. Which of the following tests is being performed, and what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paul-Bunnell test; Infectious mononucleosis

 

  • The Paul-Bunnell test (also referred to as the Monospot test → infectious mononucleosis → EBV) is a heterophile antibody agglutination test.
  • It detects IgM heterophile antibodies that agglutinate sheep or horse red blood cells.
  • Heterophile antibodies are non-specific antibodies (non-neutralising antibodies) 
  • These antibodies are produced in response to Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), the causative agent of infectious mononucleosis.
  • It is a rapid, screening test, typically positive in the first week of illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weil-Felix test; Rickettsial infection: Uses heterophile antibodies too, but these react with Proteus species antigens — not related to EBV or mononucleosis.

 

Option C. VDRL test; Syphilis: A non-treponemal test detecting reagin antibodies (not heterophile antibodies). Syphilis produces ulcers

 

Option D. Widal test; Typhoid fever: Detects O and H antibodies against Salmonella typhi — not heterophile antibodies. It is used in 2nd week to detect the enteric fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Paul-Bunnell (Monospot) test detects heterophile antibodies specific for EBV infection and is commonly used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with polyuria, polydipsia, and weight loss for 2 months. He has a history of hypertension and smoking. HbA1c is 9.2%, fasting glucose 180 mg/dL, and serum potassium 3.6 mmol/L. Fundoscopy is shown below. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Initiate metformin and lisinopril

 

  • HbA1c 9.2% and symptoms confirm type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
  • Fundoscopy findings indicate diabetic retinopathy, suggesting chronicity.
  • Metformin is first-line for T2DM per current guidelines, reducing hepatic glucose production.
  • Lisinopril (ACE inhibitor) is indicated for retinopathy and microalbuminuria prevention.
  • Lifestyle modification is critical but insufficient alone.
  • Statins are added based on cardiovascular risk, not retinopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start insulin glargine and aspirin: Insulin is reserved for severe hyperglycemia or metformin failure.

 

Option C. Prescribe gliclazide and atorvastatin: Sulfonylureas (gliclazide) increase hypoglycemia risk in new T2DM.

 

Option D. Begin dapagliflozin and lifestyle modification: SGLT2 inhibitors (dapagliflozin) are second-line generally (or can be first line in patients with high CV risk or Heart Failure) and require eGFR monitoring

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin and ACE inhibitors are foundational for managing type 2 diabetes with early complications.

questions.text: A laboratory researcher is analysing a purified protein sample to determine its molecular weight and obtain information about its primary amino acid sequence. The chosen method must provide both qualitative identification and quantitative mass data for peptides and proteins at high sensitivity. Which of the following techniques is best suited for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mass spectrometry

 

  • Mass spectrometry (MS) is a powerful analytical technique used in molecular biology and biochemistry to:
    • Determine molecular mass of proteins and peptides with high precision
    • Identify amino acid sequences through peptide fragmentation (e.g., tandem MS or MS/MS)
    • Provide both qualitative (what is it?) and quantitative (how much?) data
    • Detect post-translational modifications (e.g., phosphorylation, glycosylation)
  • Modern methods such as MALDI-TOF and Electrospray Ionization (ESI) have made MS indispensable in proteomics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colorimetry: Incorrect. Used for estimating concentration of a solution based on color intensity, not for determining molecular mass or sequence.

 

Option B. Edman degradation technique: Edman degradation is a classical sequencing method that works by sequentially removing N-terminal amino acids of a peptide. While it does provide sequence data for a short polypeptide, it does not determine molecular weight with quantitative mass data, and is relatively insensitive and labor-intensive compared to mass spectrometry. It cannot comprehensively analyze purified protein samples at high sensitivity like mass spectrometry.

 

Option C. X-ray Crystallography: Incorrect. Determines the 3D structure of crystallized proteins, not molecular mass or amino acid sequence. It is structural, not compositional. It is used to detect secondary, tertiary or quaternary structure of protein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mass spectrometry is the most accurate method for determining molecular weight and primary amino acid sequence of proteins and peptides.

questions.text: During a surgical procedure for endolymphatic sac decompression, it is crucial to identify a specific anatomical landmark to guide the surgery. Which structure, based on the provided diagram, is the appropriate surgical landmark?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

  • The cavity which can be seen is post mastoid cavity
  • The correct surgical landmark for endolymphatic sac decompression is C. 
  • This is due to Donaldson's line, which passes through the horizontal semicircular canal and bisects the posterior semicircular canal. 
  • The endolymphatic sac lies below this line on the floor, making it an essential reference point during surgery.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In endolymphatic sac decompression, Donald’s line is used as a landmark to locate the endolymphatic sac, as it passes through the horizontal and posterior semicircular canals

questions.text: Which of the following viral families is characterized by having two complete copies of single-stranded positive-sense RNA in their genome and contains the enzyme reverse transcriptase required for replication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retroviruses

 

  • Retroviruses (e.g., HIV) are enveloped viruses that contain:
    • Two identical copies of positive-sense single-stranded RNA
    • Reverse transcriptase, an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase that synthesizes a DNA copy from the RNA genome
  • After entry into the host cell, the viral RNA is reverse transcribed into double-stranded DNA, which integrates into the host genome for transcription and replication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Togaviruses: These are positive-sense ssRNA viruses (e.g., rubella virus), but they do not carry reverse transcriptase and have only one copy of their genome.

 

Option B. Rhabdoviruses: These are negative-sense ssRNA viruses (e.g., rabies virus), and they do not use reverse transcription in their replication cycle.

 

Option D. Reoviruses: These are double-stranded RNA viruses with segmented genomes, such as rotavirus. They do not carry reverse transcriptase and are not diploid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retroviruses are unique in that they contain two identical copies of positive-sense RNA and use reverse transcriptase to integrate into the host genome, a hallmark of their replication cycle.

questions.text: The testis is derived from which of the following embryological structures labeled in the diagram?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

The testes (and ovaries) are derived from the intermediate mesoderm, which is labeled as B in the image.

 

Embryological Origins:

 

  • Gives rise to the urogenital system:
    • Gonads (testes and ovaries)
    • Kidneys and ureters
    • Reproductive ducts (e.g., mesonephric and paramesonephric ducts)
  • The genital ridge, from which the testis develops, arises from this layer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A: Notochord

 

Paraxial Mesoderm

 

  • Forms somites, which differentiate into:
    • Sclerotome → Vertebrae and ribs
    • Myotome → Skeletal muscles
    • Dermatome → Dermis of the skin
  • Has no role in gonadal development

 

Option C. C: Somatopleuric Layer of Lateral Plate Mesoderm

 

  • Part of lateral plate mesoderm that gives rise to:
    • Parietal layer of serous membranes (e.g., pericardium, pleura, peritoneum)
    • Dermis and connective tissue of limbs and body wall
  • Not involved in forming testes

 

Option D. D: Splanchnopleuric Layer of Lateral Plate Mesoderm

 

  • Forms the visceral layer of serous membranes
  • Contributes to the muscles and connective tissue of gut wall
  • Again, not involved in testicular development

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The testis originates from the intermediate mesoderm, specifically the genital ridge. 
  • This ridge also contributes to the formation of the internal genital ducts. Knowing the origin of embryonic tissues is crucial for understanding developmental anomalies and the organization of the urogenital system.

choices.text: Traumatic cardiac tamponade with Beck’s triad
Hemothorax with spontaneous ICD output of 1000 ml of blood

questions.text: All of these are indications for surgical exploration in trauma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemothorax with spontaneous ICD output of 1000 ml of blood

 

  • This is the exception.
  • While hemothorax is significant, immediate exploration isn’t always mandatory at 1000 mL drainage. 
  • Current thresholds often recommend surgery if: 
    • Immediate output >1500 mL 
    • Ongoing bleeding >200 mL/hour for 3+ hours 
  • At 1000 mL, clinical judgment and monitoring often guide next steps rather than automatic surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penetrating trauma with evisceration: Indication for surgery. This is a classic surgical emergency. Evisceration (protrusion of internal organs) after penetrating trauma strongly suggests peritoneal violation and potential intra-abdominal injuries. Exploration is usually performed even if the patient is hemodynamically stable.

 

Option B. Retroperitoneal hematoma in Zone 1: Indication for surgery. Zone 1 retroperitoneal hematomas (central area—great vessels, pancreas, duodenum) are highly suspicious for major vascular or visceral injury, especially in penetrating trauma.  These generally require exploration regardless of stability.

 

Option C. Traumatic cardiac tamponade with Beck’s triad: Indication for surgery. Beck’s triad (hypotension, muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins) is a hallmark of cardiac tamponade—a life-threatening condition.  Surgical intervention (like thoracotomy) is urgently needed.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Not all internal bleeding mandates immediate surgery—thresholds and ongoing trends matter, as seen in hemothorax management.
  • Evisceration, cardiac tamponade, and Zone 1 hematomas are red flags that typically mandate urgent surgical exploration.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a single anesthetic patch on his right forearm. On examination, there is a thickened radial cutaneous nerve palpable at the wrist. He does not report any systemic symptoms or similar lesions elsewhere on the body. A skin biopsy was performed, as shown below which shows well-defined epithelioid cell granulomas without any acid-fast bacilli (AFB). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculoid leprosy (TT)

 

  • A single anesthetic skin patch with nerve thickening suggests tuberculoid leprosy.
  • Histopathology shows well-defined epithelioid cell granulomas, which is a hallmark of TT.
  • The absence of acid-fast bacilli (AFB) confirms the paucibacillary nature of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Borderline Tuberculoid Leprosy (BT):

 

  • BT leprosy typically presents with multiple plaques with satellite lesions.
  • Nerve involvement in BT is asymmetrical with thickening of multiple nerves.
  • Histology may show epithelioid granulomas, but some AFB may also be present.
  • Acid-fast bacilli are present in BT leprosy.

 

Option C. Histiocytosis:

 

  • Histiocytosis does not present with anesthetic patches or nerve thickening.
  • Histopathology findings would not show epithelioid granulomas.

 

Option D. Lymphoma:

 

  • Lymphoma typically presents with systemic symptoms such as weight loss, fever, and lymphadenopathy.
  • The biopsy would show lymphocytic infiltration instead of granulomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tuberculoid leprosy is characterized by single or few anesthetic skin patches and nerve thickening. 
  • Histological findings include well-defined epithelioid granulomas with no acid-fast bacilli.

choices.text: It is first line of treatment in women seeking fertility issues in PCOS
It is performed less often than wedge resection
It may lead to a reduction in ovarian reserve

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the procedure being shown here?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It may lead to a reduction in ovarian reserve

 

  • Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is used as an alternative to wedge resection in patients with severe PCOS resistant to clomiphene and have even tried ovulation with gonadotropins.
  • Procedure involves use of electrocautery needle inserted at a cutting current of 100 W for entry and 40 W coagulation to treat stroma for a time period of 4 seconds.
