  • In each ovary 4 punctures are done to reduce adhesion formation.
  • Most of the studies report reduction in both androgen and LH concentration and an increase in FSH concentration.
  • However, there is risk of reduction in ovarian reserve (reduced AMH) and adhesion formation in patient and should be discussed with the patient.
  • The beneficial effects are sustained for upto 5 years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is first-line treatment in women seeking fertility in PCOS: Incorrect. First-line treatment is medical ovulation induction, not surgery.

 

Option B. It is performed less often than wedge resection: Incorrect. It is performed more often than wedge resection.

 

Option C. It mainly treats hirsutism: Incorrect. While LOD may reduce androgen levels, its primary role is ovulation induction, not cosmetic or hormonal symptom relief like hirsutism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is a second-line treatment for ovulation induction in clomiphene-resistant PCOS, working by decreasing androgens and LH and increasing FSH.
  • It is not first-line, and its main indication is fertility improvement, not treatment of hirsutism.

choices.text: Inhibition of PD-1 receptor on T-cells

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is undergoing evaluation for progressive unintentional weight loss, fatigue, and persistent hoarseness. Imaging reveals a non-small cell carcinoma located in the upper lobe of the right lung with mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Biopsy confirms malignancy, and immunohistochemical staining demonstrates increased expression of immune regulatory ligands. Which of the following mechanisms is least likely to explain how this tumor is evading immune surveillance?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inhibition of PD-1 receptor on T-cells

 

  • In this clinical scenario, the lung tumor demonstrates classic features of immune evasion. Tumor cells commonly evade the host immune response through several well-defined pathways. 
  • These include:
    • Upregulating PD-L1, a ligand that binds to the PD-1 receptor on activated T-cells, leading to T-cell anergy or apoptosis.
    • Inducing regulatory T-cells (Tregs), which suppress effector T-cell function and contribute to an immunosuppressive microenvironment.
    • Producing galectin, particularly galectin-1, which promotes apoptosis of activated CD8+ cytotoxic T-cells and supports tumor immune tolerance.
  • In contrast, inhibition of the PD-1 receptor on T-cells is not a mechanism used by tumor cells for immune evasion. In fact, inhibiting PD-1 is the therapeutic basis of several immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., pembrolizumab, nivolumab), which aim to restore T-cell function by blocking the PD-1/PD-L1 interaction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upregulation of expression of PD-L1: This is a common tumor immune evasion mechanism. PD-L1 binds to PD-1 on T-cells, suppressing their cytotoxic activity.

 

Option B. Induction of regulatory T-cells: Tumors often increase Treg populations, which inhibit the immune response by releasing immunosuppressive cytokines (e.g., IL-10, TGF-β). They cause hypo functioning of T cells 

 

Option C. Induction of galectin: Tumors produce galectin to eliminate cytotoxic T-cells and promote immune escape.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tumor cells evade immune detection through PD-L1 upregulation, regulatory T-cell recruitment, and galectin production—but they do not evade immunity by inhibiting the PD-1 receptor on T-cells. 
  • In fact, inhibition of PD-1 is a therapeutic mechanism used to enhance immune activity against tumors.

choices.text: It presents with marked ptosis and miosis on attempted lateral gaze
There is limitation of abduction with globe retraction on adduction
It is associated with congenital trochlear nerve hypoplasia
Causes hypertropia more frequently than horizontal misalignment

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Duane Retraction Syndrome Type 1?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) There is limitation of abduction with globe retraction on adduction

 

  • Duane Retraction Syndrome (DRS) Type 1 is characterized by:
    • Marked limitation of abduction
    • Normal or mildly limited adduction
    • Globe retraction and narrowing of the palpebral fissure on attempted adduction
    • Females more common
    • Left eye in 60%, bilateral in 20%
  • It results from aberrant innervation—specifically, absence or hypoplasia of the abducens nerve (CN VI) and anomalous innervation of the lateral rectus by CN III.
  • This leads to co-contraction of medial and lateral rectus, causing globe retraction during adduction.
  • Classification
    • Type 1 – Limitation in abduction
    • Type 2 - Limitation in adduction 
    • Type 3 – Limitation in both abduction and adduction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It presents with marked ptosis and miosis on attempted lateral gaze: This describes Horner’s syndrome, not Duane retraction syndrome.

 

Option C. It is associated with congenital trochlear nerve hypoplasia: Trochlear nerve (CN IV) involvement relates to superior oblique palsy, not DRS.

 

Option D. Causes hypertropia more frequently than horizontal misalignment: Horizontal gaze deficits (abduction/adduction limitation) are hallmark in DRS, not vertical misalignment like hypertropia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duane Retraction Syndrome Type 1 is characterized by limited abduction, normal to mildly limited adduction, and globe retraction on attempted adduction, due to sixth nerve hypoplasia with aberrant innervation of the lateral rectus by the oculomotor nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the sterilization procedure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pomeroy procedure

 

This is a commonly used method where a loop of the fallopian tube is tied and a segment is excised. It is also reversible but involves cutting the tube.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fimbriectomy: In this procedure, the fimbriae (the finger-like projections at the end of the fallopian tubes) are removed, which is a permanent and non-reversible sterilization method.

 

 

Option C. Irwing procedure: This technique involves folding the tube back on itself and tying it off, making it more easily reversible compared to other methods like fimbriectomy or hysteroscopic sterilization.

 

 

Option D. Hysteroscopic sterilization: This method involves placing a device in the fallopian tubes through the uterus, leading to tubal occlusion. It is considered a permanent sterilization method and is not easily reversible.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Pomeroy procedure is a common sterilization technique where a loop of the fallopian tube is tied and a segment is excised. 
  • It is also reversible but involves cutting the tube.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man presents with complaints of glare and visual disturbances in both eyes. Slit-lamp examination reveals whorl-like opacities in the corneal epithelium. He has a history of long-term amiodarone use for arrhythmia management. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cornea verticillata

 

  • Cornea verticillata (also known as vortex keratopathy) is characterized by bilateral, whorl-like opacities in the corneal epithelium.
  • It is associated with systemic drugs such as:
    • Amiodarone
    • Chloroquine
    • Indomethacin
    • Tamoxifen
  • Despite its distinct appearance, vision is usually preserved, though some patients may report glare or halos.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Terrien's marginal degeneration:  A rare peripheral corneal thinning disorder, not associated with drug use or whorl opacities.

 

Option C. Band-shaped keratopathy:  Presents as horizontal, calcific band-like opacities in the interpalpebral zone, not whorl patterns.

 

Option D. Arcus juvenilis:  A lipid deposition in the peripheral cornea; usually seen in younger patients with hyperlipidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cornea verticillata (vortex keratopathy) presents with whorl-like epithelial opacities and is commonly associated with amiodarone use. 
  • It is typically asymptomatic but may cause glare.

questions.text: A 42-year-old sheep farmer from Central Europe presents with right upper quadrant discomfort and mild hepatomegaly. Imaging reveals a multiloculated, infiltrative hepatic cyst with no clear capsule and invasion into surrounding liver tissue, resembling a malignant tumor. Which of the following organisms is the most likely causative agent of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Echinococcus multilocularis

 

  • Echinococcus multilocularis causes alveolar echinococcosis, a life-threatening parasitic infection.
  • They contain multiple locules. 
  • Unlike Echinococcus granulosus, which forms a well-defined hydatid cyst, E. multilocularis leads to multivesicular, infiltrative lesions in the liver.
  • Echinococcus produces single cyst but multilocularis produces multiple cysts 
  • These cysts lack a limiting capsule and mimic hepatic malignancy both radiologically and histologically.
  • Transmission occurs through ingestion of eggs from foxes or dogs, and the disease has an endemic presence in Europe, North America, and Asia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Echinococcus granulosus: They can cause hepatic cyst. Causes cystic echinococcosis (hydatid disease), forming well-encapsulated, unilocular cysts with daughter cysts. No invasive behavior like E. multilocularis.

 

Option B. Taenia solium: They can also cause hepatic cyst (+/-). Causes cysticercosis (larvae in CNS, muscles), not alveolar liver lesions.

 

Option D. Fasciola hepatica: They can also cause hepatic cyst (+/-). A liver fluke causing biliary tract inflammation, but does not form cystic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Echinococcus multilocularis causes alveolar echinococcosis, presenting as invasive, multiloculated hepatic cysts that mimic malignancy and are distinguished from the encapsulated hydatid cysts of Echinococcus granulosus.

choices.text: Burden of proof lies on the surgeon to demonstrate absence of negligence in performing surgery on the wrong eye
Burden of proof lies on the patient to establish that surgeon’s actions caused vision loss
Burden of proof lies on both the patient and surgeon equally as contributory negligence applies
Burden of proof lies solely on the patient to show that the wrong eye was operated on

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after experiencing sudden vision loss in his right eye shortly following an elective eye procedure. Investigation confirms that the intervention was mistakenly performed on the right eye instead of the scheduled left eye. As legal proceedings are initiated for medical negligence, the court applies the doctrine of res ipsa loquitur due to the nature of the error. In such a scenario, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the burden of proof?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burden of proof lies on the surgeon to demonstrate absence of negligence in performing surgery on the wrong eye

 

  • In cases involving obvious errors such as wrong-site surgery, the legal doctrine of res ipsa loquitur (“the thing speaks for itself”) is often applied.
  • This doctrine allows the court to infer negligence based solely on the nature of the incident, even without direct proof of the negligent act.
  • In such instances, the burden of proof shifts from the patient to the healthcare provider. 
  • The surgeon is expected to demonstrate that the mistake (operating on the wrong eye) was not due to negligence, as this type of error typically does not occur without some deviation from the standard of care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Burden of proof lies on the patient to establish that surgeon’s actions caused vision loss: Incorrect. Under res ipsa loquitur, it is presumed that such an event (wrong eye surgery) implies negligence, and therefore the patient is not required to prove causation or breach of duty.

 

Option C. Burden of proof lies on both the patient and surgeon equally as contributory negligence applies: Incorrect. Contributory negligence applies when both parties share fault, which is not applicable here since the patient is not responsible for the surgery error.

 

Option D. Burden of proof lies solely on the patient to show that the wrong eye was operated on: Incorrect. The error is already established through investigation; thus, the onus is on the surgeon to justify the actions, not on the patient to prove the error.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In obvious medical errors such as wrong-site surgery, the doctrine of res ipsa loquitur applies, shifting the burden of proof onto the healthcare provider to demonstrate lack of negligence.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about the deep inguinal ring are correct? 

 

  1. It is a defect in the transversalis fascia.
  2. It is located midway between the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and the symphysis pubis.
  3. It lies below the inguinal ligament.
  4. It is situated lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. It is a defect in the transversalis fascia: Correct. The deep inguinal ring is a defect in the transversalis fascia.

 

Statement 2. It is located midway between the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and the symphysis pubis: Correct. It is located midway between ASIS and the symphysis pubis.

 

Statement 4. It is situated lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels: Correct. It lies lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 3. It lies below the inguinal ligament: Incorrect. It lies approximately 1.2 cm above the inguinal ligament, not below it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The deep inguinal ring is an anatomical opening in the transversalis fascia. 
  • It is located above the inguinal ligament, midway between ASIS and pubic symphysis, and lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels, making it an important landmark for differentiating direct vs indirect inguinal hernias.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy and night sweats for 3 months. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Lymph node biopsy is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perform PET-CT

 

  • Reed-Sternberg cells confirm Hodgkin lymphoma (HL).
  • Painless cervical lymphadenopathy, night sweats, and Reed-Sternberg cells on biopsy confirm classical Hodgkin lymphoma (HL).
  • The next step is staging with PET-CT (C) to assess disease extent (e.g., nodal and extranodal involvement), which guides treatment (e.g., ABVD chemotherapy ± radiotherapy) and prognosis using the Ann Arbor staging system.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis increases lymphoma risk, but treatment is based on HL staging, not RA management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start rituximab and methotrexate: Rituximab is used in B-cell lymphomas (e.g., DLBCL), not HL; methotrexate is for RA, not lymphoma.

 

Option B. Initiate ABVD chemotherapy: Appropriate for HL but premature without staging to determine extent and tailor therapy.

 

Option D. Perform radiotherapy alone: Used in early-stage HL post-staging, not as the initial step without assessing disease spread.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PET-CT is essential for staging HL after biopsy confirmation to guide therapy.
  • HL treatment (e.g., ABVD) depends on stage; early intervention without staging risks overtreatment or undertreatment.
  • Consider RA as a risk factor but base management on HL diagnosis.

questions.text: In this cut section through the ischioanal fossa, which labelled structure is the pelvic diaphragm.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

 

The pelvic diaphragm is the muscular partition that forms the floor of the pelvic cavity and separates it from the perineum below. It consists of:

 

  • Levator ani muscles:
    • Pubococcygeus
    • Iliococcygeus
    • Puborectalis
    • Coccygeus muscle

 

These muscles originate from the lateral pelvic wall, sweep downward and medially, and form a funnel-shaped sling around the pelvic organs.

 

Identification in Image:

 

  • Label B shows a muscle layer forming the medial wall of the ischioanal fossa, sloping downward medially, which is characteristic of the levator ani muscle (part of the pelvic diaphragm).
  • Label A indicates the obturator internus muscle, which forms the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa.
  • Label C indicates the internal anal sphincter.
  • Label D points to the external anal sphincter.

 

Boundaries of the Ischioanal Fossa:

 

  • Lateral: Obturator internus (covered by obturator fascia)
  • Medial: Levator ani + external anal sphincter
  • Posterior: Sacrotuberous ligament, gluteus maximus
  • Anterior: Posterior border of perineal membrane
  • Roof: Inferior fascia of pelvic diaphragm
  • Floor: Perineal skin

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The pelvic diaphragm, formed by the levator ani and coccygeus muscles, supports the pelvic organs and forms the roof of the perineum. 
  • In cross-sections like the ischioanal fossa, it appears as a medially sloping muscular wall and is essential for continence and pelvic stability.

choices.text: Oral aspirin, ticagrelor, and transfer for PCI
IV streptokinase, aspirin, clopidogrel, and transfer
IV heparin, nitroglycerin, and ICU admission
Oral metoprolol, aspirin, and angiography within 48 hours

questions.text: A 62-year-old male from Mumbai presents with central chest pain for 4 hours, radiating to the left arm, associated with diaphoresis and dyspnea. He has a history of diabetes mellitus and smoking BP is 150/90 mmHg, pulse 92/min. The ECG is shown below. Troponin T is 1.8 ng/mL (normal < 0.04). The nearest PCI-capable center is 4 hours away. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV streptokinase, aspirin, clopidogrel, and transfer

 

  • ST-elevation in V1-V4 indicates anterior wall STEMI, likely due to LAD occlusion.
  • Troponin elevation confirms myocardial injury.
  • When PCI is >120 minutes away, thrombolytic therapy (streptokinase) is indicated.
  • Aspirin and clopidogrel reduce platelet aggregation and prevent re-occlusion.
  • Transfer for PCI post-thrombolysis is part of a pharmacoinvasive strategy.
  • Streptokinase is cost-effective in India, aligning with resource-limited settings.
  • Monitoring for reperfusion arrhythmias is critical post-thrombolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral aspirin, ticagrelor, and transfer for PCI: Delays reperfusion as PCI is not immediately accessible, risking further myocardial damage.

 

Option C. IV heparin, nitroglycerin, and ICU admission: Heparin and nitroglycerin are adjuncts but do not address the acute occlusion requiring thrombolysis.

 

Option D. Oral metoprolol, aspirin, and angiography within 48 hours: Metoprolol and delayed angiography neglect urgent reperfusion, increasing mortality risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrombolytic therapy is the cornerstone of STEMI management when PCI is delayed in resource-limited settings.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not pass through both the greater and lesser sciatic foramen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tendon of obturator internus

 

  • The greater and lesser sciatic foramina are two openings formed by the sacrospinous and sacrotuberous ligaments, acting as passageways between the pelvic cavity and the gluteal region/perineum.

 

Structures Passing Through Both Foramina:

 

  • The mnemonic "PIN" helps remember the three structures that pass through both the greater and lesser sciatic foramina:
    • P – Pudendal nerve
    • I – Internal pudendal vessels (artery and vein)
    • N – Nerve to obturator internus

 

These structures:

 

  1. Exit the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen
  2. Loop around the ischial spine
  3. Re-enter the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen to supply the perineum and obturator internus

 

Why Option D is Incorrect:

 

  • The tendon of obturator internus passes only through the lesser sciatic foramen to reach the greater trochanter of femur.
  • It does not exit and re-enter via both foramina like the PIN structures do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pudendal nerve, internal pudendal vessels, and nerve to obturator internus pass through both the greater and lesser sciatic foramina, while the tendon of obturator internus passes only through the lesser sciatic foramen.

choices.text: Administer two doses of Td, 4 weeks apart
Administer one dose of Td immediately and a booster dose 6 months postpartum
Administer one dose of Tdap (tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis) between 27 and 36 weeks
No vaccination is needed as she received Td 3 years ago

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman presents at 28 weeks of gestation for antenatal care. She has received one dose of Td (tetanus-diphtheria) vaccine 4 years ago. According to current immunization guidelines, what is the most appropriate vaccination plan for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Administer two doses of Td, 4 weeks apart

 

  • As per the MOHFW guidelines, 2 doses of Td at an interval of 1 month is recommended
  • As per the ACOG, the 2nd dose of Td can be replaced with Tdap at 27-36 weeks

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Administer one dose of Td immediately and a booster dose 6 months postpartum: Incorrect. A single dose of Tdap is not sufficient and postpartum prophylaxis will not prevent the neonate against infections.

 

Option C. Administer one dose of Tdap (tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis) between 27 and 36 weeks: Incorrect. A single dose of Tdap is insufficient if she’s not been vaccinated in the last 3 years.

 

Option D. No vaccination is needed as she received Td 3 years ago: Incorrect. A dose of Tdap is required during every pregnancy to protect the newborn from pertussis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • As per the MOHFW guidelines, 2 doses of Td at an interval of 1 month is recommended
  • If she’s been completely immunized in the last 3 years, then only a single booster dose is enough.

questions.text: A 45-year-old renal transplant recipient is receiving immunosuppressive therapy including cyclosporin. During follow-up, he is monitored for known adverse effects of this drug. Which of the following is least likely to occur as an adverse effect of cyclosporin therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thrombocytopenia

 

  • Cyclosporin is a calcineurin inhibitor used widely in organ transplantation to prevent rejection. 
  • Its adverse effects are mainly dose-dependent and involve multiple systems:
    • Hepatotoxicity and neurotoxicity
    • Nephrotoxicity is the most common and serious adverse effect. It causes afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction leading to reduced glomerular filtration rate.
    • Hypertension occurs due to renal vasoconstriction and sodium retention.
    • Hyperglycemia may result due to β-cell toxicity or insulin resistance, especially when used with steroids.
  • However, thrombocytopenia is not a typical adverse effect of cyclosporin. Bone marrow suppression is uncommon with this drug, although mild anemia or leukopenia can occur rarely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclosporin is associated with nephrotoxicity, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, neurotoxicity, hyperglycemia, and gum hypertrophy, but does not typically cause thrombocytopenia, distinguishing it from other immunosuppressants like azathioprine.

questions.text: What is the ideal time for the test performed below during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 11-14 weeks 

 

Nuchal Translucency (NT):

 

  • Component of first trimester aneuploidy screening
  • Represents maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck.
  • If NT increased, risk for 
    • Fetal aneuploidy
    • Various structural anomalies: CVS, hydrops, cystic hygroma
  • Measured between 11 weeks – 13 weeks 6 days (or 11- 14 weeks)
  • Criteria to measure the NT:
    • CRL between 45 – 84 mm
    • Fetus in mid sagittal plane
    • Fetus in neutral position
    • Image must be magnified
    • Widest space should be measured
    • The amnion must be seen separately
    • The ‘+’ calipers must be placed on the inner borders of the nuchal space

 

 

  • NT alone of used: 65% detection rate for Down Syndrome
  • Combined test: NT + Dual marker (beta hCG + PAPP-A): 80% Detection rate

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nuchal translucency is ideally measured between 11 weeks – 13 weeks 6 days (or 11- 14 weeks)

questions.text: K-complex is seen in which stage of the sleep cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage 2 NREM

 

  • Sleep is divided into REM (Rapid Eye Movement) and NREM (Non-Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. 
  • NREM sleep has three stages: N1, N2, and N3. Each stage has characteristic EEG waveforms.
  • Stage 2 NREM Sleep:
    • Makes up ~45% of total sleep (the largest portion)
    • Represents intermediate-depth sleep
    • Key EEG features:
      • Sleep spindles: bursts of high-frequency waves
      • K-complexes: high-amplitude, biphasic waves triggered by external stimuli (e.g., sound)
    • Associated with bruxism (teeth grinding)

 

EEG features by sleep stage:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • K-complexes are seen exclusively in Stage 2 of NREM sleep and serve as markers of sensory processing and memory consolidation. 
  • Recognition of EEG waveforms like K-complexes and sleep spindles is essential in understanding sleep physiology and disorders like insomnia, sleep apnea, and parasomnias.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with periorbital puffiness that is worse in the morning, along with generalized edema for the past week. On physical examination, an unusual finding was noticed by the mother which is shown below. Initial laboratory results show 4+ proteinuria, a serum albumin level of 1.8 g/dL, and a serum cholesterol level of 320 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral prednisolone 2 mg/kg/day

 

  • The 4-year-old boy’s periorbital puffiness that is worse in the morning, generalized edema, 4+ proteinuria, serum albumin 1.8 g/dL, and serum cholesterol 320 mg/dL fulfill the classic triad of pediatric idiopathic (minimal-change) nephrotic syndrome: heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hypercholesterolemia. 
  • International pediatric nephrology guidelines recommend high-dose daily corticosteroids (prednisolone 2 mg/kg/day, maximum 60 mg) for 6 weeks as the first-line “initial therapy,” because >90 % of children with minimal-change disease achieve complete remission with this regimen.
  • The 2 mg/kg/day dose for 6 week then  1.5 mg/kg alternate days for next 6 weeks. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclosporine: A calcineurin inhibitor reserved for steroid-resistant or frequently relapsing/steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome after failure of prolonged steroid or alkylating-agent therapy. It is not appropriate as the initial treatment.

 

Option C. Intravenous methylprednisolone: Intravenous methylprednisolone are used for severe steroid-resistant cases or life-threatening relapses with acute renal impairment, not for routine first presentation.

 

Option D. Cyclophosphamide: An alkylating agent indicated for frequent relapses or steroid dependence nephrotic syndrome, to achieve long-term remission and steroid-sparing; it is inappropriate at onset.

 

Educational Objective:

 

First-episode childhood minimal-change nephrotic syndrome is treated initially with oral prednisolone 2 mg/kg/day, reserving cyclosporine, IV methylprednisolone, or cyclophosphamide for steroid-resistant or relapsing disease.

choices.text: Administer steroid cover, monitor with Doppler and biophysical profile (BPP), and plan delivery
Administer steroid cover and proceed with emergency cesarean section
Allow vaginal delivery as the baby is preterm and small

questions.text: A 28-week pregnant woman presents with signs of an umbilical artery Doppler study reveals the below picture. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer steroid cover, monitor with Doppler and biophysical profile (BPP), and plan delivery

 

  • Absent diastolic flow in the umbilical artery indicates severe fetal distress. 
  • Immediate delivery at 28 weeks increases neonatal risks, including respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), and neonatal death. 
  • Administering corticosteroids such as dexamethasone accelerates fetal lung maturity, reducing RDS risk. 
  • Monitoring the fetus with Doppler and BPP allows time for optimal preparation for delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate termination of pregnancy: Immediate termination at 28 weeks would result in significant neonatal morbidity and mortality.

 

Option C. Administer steroid cover and proceed with emergency cesarean section: Emergency cesarean without steroid administration would fail to optimize neonatal outcomes.

 

Option D. Allow vaginal delivery as the baby is preterm and small: Vaginal delivery is inappropriate in severe fetal distress and absent MCA diastolic flow.

 

Key Doppler Interpretation:

 

  • Normal umbilical flow: High resistance, minimal antegrade diastolic flow.
  • Reduced diastolic flow in the umbilical artery flow: Low resistance flow suggests head-sparing in response to fetal hypoxia.
  • Absent/reversed diastolic flow: Severe hypoxia and poor prognosis if not promptly addressed. Indication for delivery. If > 34 weeks – immediate delivery; if < 34 weeks: Steroids followed by delivery. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of fetal distress with absent umbilical diastolic flow at 28 weeks, the immediate priority is administering corticosteroids to enhance fetal lung maturity, monitoring with Doppler and BPP, and planning timely delivery to balance neonatal survival and morbidity risks.

choices.text: Start with PEEP of 5 cm H2O and adjust tidal volume to 6 mL/kg

questions.text: A 60-year-old female is admitted to the ICU with severe dyspnea and hypoxemia. She has a history of COPD and was having fever and increased cough for the last 3 days. ABG shows pH 7.28, PaCO2 60 mmHg, PaO2 50 mmHg. Patient was intubated and ventilated in view of severe hypoxemia and the CXR is shown below. Which of the following is not recommended as the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prone ventilation

 

  • Prone ventilation is not routinely recommended as the first step in mechanically ventilated ARDS patients.
  • Prone positioning is indicated for severe ARDS (PaO2/FiO2 <150 mmHg despite optimal PEEP) after initial stabilization with lung-protective ventilation, not as an immediate intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start IV methylprednisolone: Recommended in ARDS with a clear inflammatory trigger (e.g., pneumonia) after 72 hours if no improvement, or in COPD exacerbation with steroids.

 

Option B. Initiate piperacillin-tazobactam and azithromycin: Appropriate for suspected bacterial pneumonia (e.g., COPD exacerbation with new infiltrates); covers gramnegatives and atypicals (e.g., Legionella).

 

Option D. Start with PEEP of 5 cm H2O and adjust tidal volume to 6mL/kg: Standard lung-protective ventilation for ARDS, using low tidal volume (6 mL/kg ideal body weight) and titrating PEEP based on oxygenation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS Use low tidal volume (6 mL/kg) and titrate PEEP, prone positioning if PaO2/FiO2 <150 after optimization.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, dark urine, and right upper quadrant pain for 3 weeks. He has a history of blood transfusion 20 years ago. Serum bilirubin is 3.2 mg/dL, ALT 250 U/L, and HCV RNA is positive. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start sofosbuvir/velpatasvir

 

  • The patient’s history of blood transfusion 20 years ago, positive HCV RNA, elevated bilirubin (3.2 mg/dL), and ALT (250 U/L) indicate chronic hepatitis C with possible liver inflammation or early cirrhosis.
  • Sofosbuvir/velpatasvir is a pan-genotypic direct-acting antiviral (DAA) regimen recommended as first-line treatment for all HCV genotypes, achieving >95% sustained virologic response (SVR) without requiring genotypic testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proceed with genotypic testing: Not required for sofosbuvir/velpatasvir, which is effective across all genotypes. Genotyping is optional if other regimens (e.g., sofosbuvir/ledipasvir) are considered.

 

Option C. Start tenofovir/Entecavir: Used for hepatitis B virus (HBV), not HCV. Inappropriate here given positive HCV RNA and no HBV markers.

 

Option D. Do Liver Biopsy: Not routinely needed for treatment initiation in chronic HCV with detectable RNA. Non-invasive tests (e.g., FibroScan, APRI) assess fibrosis; biopsy is reserved for unclear cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sofosbuvir/velpatasvir (12 weeks) is effective for all genotypes of HCV, so genotyping is optional. Assess SVR at 12 weeks post-treatment; evaluate fibrosis if cirrhosis suspected.

questions.text: A laboratory report shows gonadotropin and ovarian hormone levels from a blood sample taken on day 20 of a woman’s menstrual cycle. Which hormone would most reliably indicate whether her cycle was ovulatory?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Progesterone

 

  • To assess whether a menstrual cycle is ovulatory (i.e., ovulation has occurred), the best indicator is the serum progesterone level, especially when measured in the mid-luteal phase (around day 20 in a 28-day cycle).
  • Hormonal Basis:
    • Progesterone:
      • Secreted primarily by the corpus luteum, which only forms after ovulation
      • Levels rise sharply after ovulation and peak around day 20
      • If no ovulation occurs → no corpus luteum → low progesterone levels
      • Hence, it's a reliable marker for confirming ovulation
    • LH:
      • LH surge triggers ovulation (~day 14), but LH levels fall rapidly afterward
      • Not a reliable marker when measured at day 20 (it would already have declined)
    • Estradiol:
      • Peaks just before ovulation
      • Can be high in both ovulatory and anovulatory cycles, hence not specific
    • FSH:
      • Involved in follicular development
      • Does not confirm whether ovulation occurred

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Oxygen deprivation due to underwater panic and breath-holding
Reflex laryngospasm from sudden exposure to cold water
Electrolyte dilution following rapid intravascular absorption of hypotonic water

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is pulled unconscious from a freshwater lake. On arrival at the emergency department, her ECG reveals ventricular fibrillation. Considering the likely pathophysiologic events associated with freshwater drowning, which of the following is the most plausible mechanism responsible for her cardiac arrhythmia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Electrolyte dilution following rapid intravascular absorption of hypotonic water

 

  • Freshwater drowning typically results in the aspiration of large volumes of hypotonic water, which is rapidly absorbed across the alveolar-capillary membrane into the pulmonary circulation. 
  • This dilutes plasma electrolytes, particularly sodium and potassium, causing electrolyte imbalances (notably hypokalemia and hyponatremia). 
  • These shifts can disrupt the cardiac membrane potential, predisposing to ventricular arrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation, as seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxygen deprivation due to underwater panic and breath-holding: This describes asphyxia, which is common in drowning but usually leads to bradycardia, hypoxia, and apnea, not immediate ventricular fibrillation due to electrolyte derangement.

 

Option B. Reflex laryngospasm from sudden exposure to cold water: While laryngospasm may occur initially and delay water aspiration, it does not directly cause ventricular fibrillation. This is more relevant in cold water shock or dry drowning, not the predominant pathology here.

 

Option C. Hyperviscosity syndrome triggered by hemoconcentration: Hemoconcentration occurs in saltwater drowning. The opposite occurs in freshwater drowning – fluid moves into the bloodstream, not out, causing hemodilution, not hyperviscosity or clot formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In freshwater drowning, rapid absorption of hypotonic water into the circulation can cause electrolyte dilution, especially hypokalemia, leading to life-threatening arrhythmias like ventricular fibrillation.

questions.text: During the pathological examination of a lung from a patient who had lobar pneumonia, a stage was identified in which the lung appeared firm, dry, and gray on gross inspection as shown in the image below. This stage, is characterized by which of the following primary histopathological findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Accumulation of fibrin

 

  • Grey hepatization is the third stage in the classic progression of lobar pneumonia:
    1. Congestion – Vascular engorgement; many RBCs
    2. Red hepatization – Alveoli packed with RBCs, neutrophils, and fibrin
    3. Grey hepatization – RBCs disintegrate, and fibrin becomes the dominant component along with neutrophils
    4. Resolution – Enzymatic digestion of exudates and lung architecture restored
  • In grey hepatization, the lung becomes dry, firm, and gray due to:
    • Dense fibrinous exudate in alveoli
    • Fewer intact RBCs
    • Continued presence of neutrophils, but fibrin dominates

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. WBCs fill the alveoli: Seen in red and grey stages, but not the dominant feature in grey hepatization

 

Option B. RBCs fill the alveoli: Characteristic of red hepatization, not grey

 

Option C. Organisms fill the alveoli: Prominent in early stages before immune clearance

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Grey hepatization in lobar pneumonia is defined by accumulation of fibrin within alveolar spaces, giving the lung a firm, dry, gray appearance.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child can ride a tricycle, climb upstairs with alternate feet, say their name, and knows own gender but cannot narrate a story. What is the developmental age?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 years

 

  • Developmental milestones like:
    • Climbing stairs with alternate feet → 3 years
    • Riding tricycle → 3 years
    • Knowing name and gender → 3 years
    • Narrating stories → 4 years
  • Thus, the child is at a 3-year developmental level.

 

Educational Objective:


A child who climbs stairs alternating feet and rides a tricycle has a developmental age of ~3 years.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man stabilized on warfarin is started on erythromycin for community-acquired pneumonia. Four days later, he develops hematuria and INR is 6.0. Inhibition of which CYP enzyme is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CYP2C9

 

  • Warfarin is a narrow therapeutic index drug primarily metabolized by CYP2C9, especially the more potent S-enantiomer. 
  • Erythromycin is a known CYP enzyme inhibitor, but it primarily inhibits CYP3A4, not CYP2C9. 
  • However, the interaction observed here is more likely due to inhibition of hepatic clearance of warfarin via multiple mechanisms, including some cross-inhibition of CYP2C9, resulting in elevated INR and increased bleeding risk.
  • That said, CYP2C9 is the key enzyme responsible for the metabolism of the S-enantiomer of warfarin, and its inhibition is most closely associated with elevated warfarin levels and bleeding complications. 
  • Therefore, despite erythromycin not being the most potent CYP2C9 inhibitor, the clinical outcome is a result of reduced CYP2C9 activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CYP2C19: Incorrect. This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of drugs like clopidogrel, omeprazole, and diazepam, not significantly involved in warfarin metabolism.

 

Option C. CYP1A2: Incorrect. This enzyme metabolizes drugs like theophylline, clozapine, and caffeine, not warfarin.

 

Option D. CYP3A4: Incorrect. While erythromycin is a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor, CYP3A4 predominantly metabolizes the R-enantiomer of warfarin, which is less potent. Therefore, CYP2C9 inhibition leads to more clinically significant effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin is primarily metabolized by CYP2C9 (especially its active S-isomer). Inhibitors of CYP2C9 can significantly increase warfarin levels and lead to elevated INR and bleeding complications. Careful monitoring is required when initiating medications that may interfere with CYP2C9 activity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male from Uttar Pradesh presents with hemoptysis. He has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis (treated) 5 years ago. Sputum AFB and CB-NAAT for M. tuberculosis is negative, and the CT scan is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic pulmonary aspergillosis

 

  • There are several forms of chronic pulmonary aspergillosis which are summarized below:

 

 

Coming to this case:

 

  • Cavitary lesion and hemoptysis in a patient with prior TB suggest a post-TB sequelae.
  • Negative AFB and CB-NAAT rules out active TB.
  • Chronic pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA) often complicates old TB cavities in endemic areas like India.
  • CPA presents with cavitary lesions and patients can be asymptomatic (as in aspergilloma) or they may have symptoms (in other forms).
  • TB prevalence in India increases CPA risk due to lung scarring.
  • CT scan is suggestive of aspergilloma (fungal ball in a Tb cavity). A ‘Monod sign’ is usually seen in aspergillomas (crescentic air shadow surrounding a fungal ball).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reactivation pulmonary tuberculosis: Negative AFB and CB-NAAT make TB less likely.

 

Option C. Lung adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma rarely cause cavitation (squamous cell carcinoma does) and the presentation and imaging is more in favour of Aspergilloma.

 

Option D. Necrotizing bacterial pneumonia: Bacterial pneumonia is acute and lacks chronicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic pulmonary aspergillosis is a common complication of prior tuberculosis in endemic regions.

questions.text: A 39-year-old patient recently diagnosed with HIV is being evaluated for antiretroviral therapy initiation. Laboratory testing reveals chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) co-infection. The treatment plan aims to address both HIV and HBV infections with a single agent if possible. Which of the following medications would provide activity against both HIV reverse transcriptase and the hepatitis B virus polymerase?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lamivudine

 

  • Drugs for treating HIV and HBV are 
    • Lamivudine
    • Emtricitabine
    • Tenofovir
  • Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that is effective against HIV reverse transcriptase, and it also inhibits HBV DNA polymerase. 
  • Because HBV uses a reverse transcription step during replication, lamivudine can block HBV replication in co-infected patients. 
  • For this reason, it is commonly included in combination regimens for HIV-positive patients with chronic hepatitis B infection. 
  • Lamivudine’s dual mechanism offers convenient coverage for both viruses with a single agent, though resistance can emerge if HBV monotherapy is given.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Efavirenz: Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) specific for HIV, with no activity against hepatitis B virus polymerase.

 

Option C. Indinavir: Indinavir is an HIV protease inhibitor that blocks HIV protease enzymes critical for viral protein cleavage and maturation but has no activity against hepatitis B virus.

 

Option D. Didanosine: Didanosine is another nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor active against HIV but does not inhibit HBV polymerase, so it does not help treat hepatitis B co-infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor with dual activity against both HIV reverse transcriptase and HBV DNA polymerase, making it a valuable treatment option in patients co-infected with HIV and chronic hepatitis B.

questions.text: Identify the accessory protein marked in the diagram below (white line with star).
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alpha actinin

 

  • The diagram shows a sarcomere under electron microscopy with visible Z-lines, A-bands, I-bands, and M-lines. The white line with the star is located at the Z-line, connecting thin actin filaments.
  • Alpha-actinin is the structural protein found in the Z-disc of sarcomeres that anchors actin (thin) filaments from adjacent sarcomeres by cross-linking, contributing to muscle structure and mechanics.
  • It is critical for maintaining the transverse alignment of actin filaments and overall sarcomere integrity.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulin: It is a much larger protein and a key component of the thin filament in skeletal muscles. It is a thin filament–associated protein that wraps around actin and helps regulate its length, and stabilize the thin filament structures. It does not anchor actin to the Z-disc.

 

Option B. Titin: A giant elastic protein that spans from the Z-line to the M-line, anchoring the myosin (thick) filament and maintaining sarcomere elasticity and structure. It is not the primary Z-disc anchor for actin.

 

Option D. Tropomyosin: A regulatory protein that runs along the groove of the actin filament and blocks the myosin binding site on actin in the resting state. It plays no role in sarcomere anchoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Types of Proteins in Myofibrils

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of Vaccine derived polio virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) m

 

  • The correct answer is “m”, because “m” is not a recognized classification of vaccine-derived poliovirus (VDPV). 
  • VDPVs are rare poliovirus strains that have genetically mutated from the original strain contained in the oral polio vaccine (OPV). 
  • OPV is associated with 2 types of paralysis – VAPP (MCC: P3) and VDPV (MCC: P2)
  • While OPV is safe and effective, in under-immunized populations, the virus can circulate and mutate over time, potentially regaining neurovirulence.
  • There are three well-established types of vaccine-derived polioviruses:
    1. cVDPV (Community VDPV) – Spreads in communities with low vaccination coverage
    2. iVDPV (immunodeficiency-associated VDPV) – Occurs in individuals with primary immunodeficiencies
    3. aVDPV (ambiguous VDPV) – Isolated from individuals or the environment with no known source or evidence of transmission
  • There is no type “m” among these categories, making it the correct answer to a question that asks which is not a type of VDPV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. i: This refers to immunodeficiency-associated vaccine-derived poliovirus (iVDPV). It occurs in individuals with primary immune deficiencies who cannot clear the attenuated vaccine virus, allowing it to mutate. Therefore, this is a valid type of VDPV and not the correct answer.

 

Option B. a: This refers to ambiguous vaccine-derived poliovirus (aVDPV), detected in individuals or the environment where the source of the virus is unclear and there is no evidence of sustained circulation. Hence, “a” is a recognized VDPV type.

 

Option C. c: This refers to community vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV), the most clinically significant form, which can spread person-to-person in areas with low vaccine coverage, leading to outbreaks. Therefore, “c” is a legitimate type and not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The three recognized types of vaccine-derived poliovirus (VDPV) are: cVDPV (Community), iVDPV (immunodeficiency-associated), and aVDPV (ambiguous).
  • There is no VDPV type designated as “m”, making it important to remember only the valid classification types.

questions.text: A patient has a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 12 breaths/min, and a dead space volume of 150 mL. What is their alveolar ventilation rate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4.2 L/min

 

  • Alveolar ventilation is the volume of fresh air reaching the alveoli per minute, i.e., the air available for gas exchange.
  • It is different from minute ventilation, which includes both alveolar and dead space ventilation.
  • Alveolar Ventilation Rate (AVR) = (Tidal Volume – Dead Space) × Respiratory Rate = (500 – 150) × 12 = 350 × 12 = 4200 mL/min = 4.2 L/min

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alveolar ventilation is more important than total minute ventilation because only alveolar air participates in gas exchange.
  • Dead space increases in conditions like:
    • Pulmonary embolism (ventilation without perfusion)
    • Mechanical ventilation with long tubing
  • Low alveolar ventilation leads to hypercapnia and hypoxia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is undergoing renal function testing. Her plasma inulin concentration is 0.5 mg/mL, and urine inulin concentration is 60 mg/mL. Her urine flow rate is 1.5 mL/min. What is her glomerular filtration rate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 180 mL/min

 

  • GFR is measured using inulin clearance, because inulin is freely filtered and neither secreted nor reabsorbed.
  • The formula for renal clearance is:

 


 

Where,

  • U = Urine concentration of the substance (mg/mL)
  • V = Urine flow rate (mL/min)
  • P = Plasma concentration of the substance (mg/mL)
  • Given:
    • U = 60 mg/mL
    • V = 1.5 mL/min
    • P = 0.5 mg/mL

Therefore,

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Normal GFR is around 125 mL/min in adults.
  • GFR is reduced in chronic kidney disease, glomerulonephritis, or hypoperfusion states.
  • Inulin clearance is gold standard but rarely used clinically; creatinine clearance is more practical.
    • GFR = (Urine concentration × Urine flow) / Plasma concentration

choices.text: The presence of symptoms like cough, asthma, and laryngitis

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is being evaluated for a potential surgical intervention. He reports persistent heartburn and occasional regurgitation. Which of these is not an indication for performing the test shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Good relief with PPI

 

  • Ambulatory pH recording (with or without impedance measurement) are justified to establish the diagnosis and guide management in patients with:
    • Atypical symptoms (Extra-esophageal symptoms like chronic cough, laryngitis, asthma, and dental erosions, especially on the lingual and palatal tooth surfaces) 
    • Persistent symptoms despite PPI therapy
  • In patients considered for surgery, it is also prudent to have objective proof of significant reflux 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients who show good relief with PPI do not warrant a 24-hour pH study.

questions.text: The likely bone lesion to produce the given pattern of calcification on x-ray is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chondrogenic tumors

 

  • These are tumors that produce cartilage matrix. Examples include osteochondroma (benign), enchondroma (benign), and chondrosarcoma (malignant).
  • Chondrogenic tumors are the most likely to produce a pattern of calcification that is described as "punctate," "ring-and-arc," "flocculent," or "popcorn-like." 
  • This is because cartilage, especially hyaline cartilage, often calcifies in an irregular, stippled fashion as it ages or undergoes pathological changes. 
  • The calcification is within the cartilaginous matrix produced by the tumor cells. This distinctive pattern is a hallmark of cartilaginous lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteogenic Tumors:

 

  • These are tumors that produce bone matrix. The most common malignant osteogenic tumor is osteosarcoma.
  • Osteogenic tumors typically show ossification (formation of true bone) rather than calcification of cartilage. 
  • On X-ray, this often appears as dense, irregular, cloud-like, or "sunburst" patterns of new bone formation. 
  • The calcification seen is the direct result of tumor osteoid production, which then mineralizes into bone. It's an active process of bone formation by the tumor cells themselves.

 

Option C. Giant Cell Tumors (GCTs):

 

  • These are typically benign but locally aggressive tumors composed of neoplastic mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-like giant cells. They most commonly occur in the epiphysis of long bones.
  • GCTs are classically lytic lesions, meaning they destroy bone. 
  • They typically appear as purely radiolucent (darker on X-ray, indicating bone destruction) areas with well-defined but non-sclerotic margins, often described as "soap bubble" or "bubbly" lesions. 
  • They do not typically produce calcification within the tumor itself. Any calcification seen would be reactive new bone formation at the periphery or secondary to pathological fracture, not intrinsic tumor calcification.

 

Option D. Chronic Osteomyelitis:

 

  • This is a persistent infection of the bone and bone marrow, often caused by bacteria.
  • Chronic osteomyelitis leads to a complex array of bone changes, including both bone destruction (lucency) and reactive new bone formation (sclerosis). 
  • One might see thickened cortex, periosteal reaction, sequestra (dead bone fragments), and involucrum (new bone formation around a sequestrum). 
  • While there is new bone formation, it's a reactive process by the host bone in response to infection, not calcification of a tumor matrix. 
  • The pattern of mineralization is typically broad-based sclerosis and thickening, not the distinct "punctate" or "ring-and-arc" calcification characteristic of cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chondrogenic tumors produce cartilage, which often calcifies in specific, recognizable patterns.
  • Osteogenic tumors produce bone, leading to ossification patterns.
  • Giant cell tumors are primarily lytic and destroy bone, not produce calcification.
  • Chronic osteomyelitis causes reactive bone formation and destruction due to infection.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with lethargy and generalized edema. Physical examination reveals sparse, easily pluckable hair, skin changes with hyperpigmented patches that appear to be peeling, and a protuberant abdomen. Her weight is 8 kg. Which of the following laboratory findings would you most expect to find?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Low serum albumin

 

  • Hyperpigmented skin patches that may appear to peel easily (flaky paint dermatosis), and easily pluckable hair (flag sign) are characteristic of kwashiorkor. 
  • Low serum albumin is the primary pathophysiological defect leading to edema in Kwashiorkor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated serum albumin: Incorrect. In Kwashiorkor, serum albumin is low due to inadequate dietary protein intake.

 

Option B. Normal serum potassium: Incorrect. Hypokalemia may occur due to poor intake or diarrhea, which is common in malnourished children.

 

Option C. Elevated serum sodium: Incorrect. Hyponatremia is more common, especially dilutional due to fluid retention and low plasma proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a malnourished child with edema, skin/hair changes, and hepatomegaly, Kwashiorkor should be suspected. The expected lab finding is low serum albumin due to severe protein deficiency.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman who gave birth to her first child 4 months ago presents with complaints of sadness of mood, decreased interest in work, crying spells, decreased energy, and difficulty falling asleep. She also reports having negative thoughts about herself but denies any ideas of suicide or harming the baby. She is currently breastfeeding her child. What is the next best step in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Start Cognitive Behavioral Therapy

 

  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is the preferred treatment for lactating women with mild depression. 
  • CBT is as effective as antidepressants in mild depression and avoids the potential risk of medication exposure to the infant through breast milk. 
  • The patient's symptoms of sadness, decreased interest, crying spells, decreased energy, and sleep disturbance without suicidal ideation or thoughts of harming the baby are consistent with mild postpartum depression, making CBT the most appropriate first-line treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start Sertraline: While sertraline has the least placental exposure among SSRIs and transfers into breast milk in minimal amounts (only 0.5% of the maternal weight-adjusted dose), with infant serum levels usually undetectable, CBT is still preferred over antidepressants for mild depression in breastfeeding mothers to avoid any medication exposure to the infant.

 

Option B. Start Venlafaxine: This SNRI would not be the first choice for a breastfeeding mother with mild depression when non-pharmacological options like CBT are available and equally effective.

 

Option C. Give Benzodiazepines SOS: Benzodiazepines are not indicated for depression treatment and would only provide temporary symptomatic relief. Additionally, they can pass through breast milk and affect the infant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant and lactating women with mild depression, CBT is preferred over antidepressants as it is equally effective and avoids potential medication exposure to the fetus or infant through breast milk.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Alpha-1 antitrypsin (A1AT) deficiency is/are incorrect?

 

  1. It is an autosomal recessive condition that can cause both liver and lung disease.
  2. The PiZZ genotype in homozygous form is the most common abnormal phenotype associated with severe disease.
  3. Liver disease occurs due to accumulation of abnormal A1AT protein in hepatocyte nuclei.
  4. The pulmonary disease typically presents as restrictive lung disease due to excessive fibrotic remodeling.
  5. Patients may present with early-onset emphysema, cirrhosis, or both.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 only

 

Statement 4. The pulmonary disease typically presents as restrictive lung disease due to excessive fibrotic remodeling: A1AT deficiency causes panacinar emphysema, a type of obstructive, not restrictive, pulmonary disease. It typically affects the lower lobes of the lungs and is accelerated by smoking. Criteria for making diagnosis of obstructive pulmonary disease is with the help of spirometry

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. It is an autosomal recessive condition that can cause both liver and lung disease: A1AT deficiency is inherited in autosomal recessive manner. 

 

Statement 2. The PiZZ genotype in homozygous form is the most common abnormal phenotype associated with severe disease: PiZZ is the most severe and common disease-causing genotype, particularly in homozygotes.

 

Statement 3. Liver disease occurs due to accumulation of abnormal A1AT protein in hepatocyte nuclei: Liver damage results from intracellular accumulation of the misfolded A1AT protein in hepatocytes, leading to cirrhosis.

 

Statement 5. Patients may present with early-onset emphysema, cirrhosis, or both: Clinical presentation includes early-onset emphysema, chronic liver disease, or both.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder leading to liver cirrhosis from hepatocyte accumulation of misfolded protein and panacinar emphysema from unchecked neutrophil elastase activity. 
  • The pulmonary disease is obstructive, not restrictive.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with fatigue, hypertension, and worsening renal function for 3 months. Serum creatinine is 3.2 mg/dL, and potassium is 5.8 mmol/L. Renal ultrasound reveals bilateral renal artery stenosis. She is on amlodipine and metformin. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform renal artery angioplasty

 

  • Bilateral renal artery stenosis (RAS) causes secondary hypertension and renal dysfunction.
  • Hyperkalemia and elevated creatinine reflect reduced renal perfusion.
  • Angioplasty with stenting is indicated for significant RAS causing progressive renal failure.
  • Metformin should be stopped due to renal impairment but is not the primary intervention.
  • ACE inhibitors (lisinopril) worsen RAS and are contraindicated.
  • Ultrasound confirms RAS, guiding intervention.
  • Dialysis is reserved for end-stage renal failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start lisinopril and stop metformin: ACEi are C/I in bilateral RAS; stopping metformin is necessary but secondary.

 

Option C. Initiate furosemide and potassium citrate: Furosemide and potassium citrate do not address the underlying stenosis.

 

Option D. Prescribe hydralazine and dialysis: Hydralazine and dialysis are premature without addressing reversible causes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal artery angioplasty is the definitive treatment for bilateral renal artery stenosis causing progressive renal dysfunction.

choices.text: p53 mutation → APC mutation → K-ras activation → carcinoma
APC mutation → K-ras mutation → p53 mutation → carcinoma
K-ras mutation → COX overexpression → APC mutation → carcinoma
COX inhibition → p53 mutation → K-ras activation → carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the sequential molecular progression from normal colonic epithelium to carcinoma in the adenoma-carcinoma pathway of colorectal cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) APC mutation → K-ras mutation → p53 mutation → carcinoma

 

The adenoma-carcinoma sequence describes the stepwise accumulation of genetic mutations that drive the transformation of normal colonic epithelium into invasive carcinoma:

  1. APC gene mutation (early event):
    • Loss of tumor suppressor gene function
    • Leads to increased β-catenin activity and abnormal proliferation
    • Often the initiating event in both sporadic and familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
  2. K-ras mutation (intermediate event):
    • Activating mutation promotes growth and formation of adenomatous polyp
  3. p53 mutation and COX overexpression (late events):
    • Allow transition from adenoma to carcinoma
    • Increased COX activity promotes inflammation and tumor growth
    • Aspirin, a COX inhibitor, may reduce the risk of progression
  • Second factor which is important is that the COX enzyme is important for the formation of adenomatous polyp. If we inhibit the COX enzyme activity then it is protective in colon cancer
  • Aspirin has shown to be responsible for reducing the risk of development of colon cancer 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The adenoma-carcinoma sequence in colorectal cancer follows a defined order: APC mutation → K-ras mutation → p53 mutation. 
  • Early identification of these mutations is critical in understanding the progression and prevention of colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) is started on sacubitril therapy. Which of the following medications should be avoided concomitantly with sacubitril due to the risk of angioedema?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lisinopril

 

  • Sacubitril/valsartan is a combination of a neprilysin inhibitor (sacubitril) and an angiotensin receptor blocker (valsartan). 
  • Neprilysin inhibition increases bradykinin levels, which can predispose to angioedema.
  • ACE inhibitors like lisinopril also increase bradykinin by inhibiting its degradation. 
  • Using sacubitril with an ACE inhibitor significantly raises the risk of angioedema, which can be life-threatening. 
  • Therefore, concomitant use is contraindicated. A 36-hour washout period is required when switching from an ACE inhibitor to sacubitril/valsartan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metoprolol: Safe to use. It is a beta-1 blocker that improves survival in HFrEF.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Safe to use. It’s a loop diuretic used for volume management in heart failure.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Safe when used appropriately. It improves symptoms and reduces hospitalizations in HFrEF but does not increase mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sacubitril/valsartan must not be co-administered with ACE inhibitors due to the risk of angioedema from excessive bradykinin accumulation. Always observe a 36-hour washout when transitioning from an ACE inhibitor to this combination therapy.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient undergoes middle ear surgery for chronic otitis media. During the procedure, the surgeon identifies a depression located at the junction of the medial and posterior walls of the tympanic cavity. The surgeon notes that it is difficult to visualize and challenging to access. What is the encircled structure in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sinus tympani

 

  • The encircled structure is the sinus tympani. 
  • It is a depression in the middle ear cavity, located at the junction of the medial and posterior walls of the tympanic cavity. 
  • It is located in between the subiculum and the ponticulus
  • This area is typically challenging to visualize during middle ear surgery due to its location and surrounding anatomical structures. 
  • Cholesteatoma extending into the sinus tympani is particularly difficult to remove.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fossa incudis: The fossa incudis is an anatomical depression in the tympanic cavity that houses the incus bone, but it is located more superiorly, making this answer incorrect.

 

Option C. Facial recess: The facial recess is a space located posterior to the tympanic cavity and lateral to the facial nerve. It is often used as an entry point during middle ear surgeries but does not match the anatomical location described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Pyramidal fossa: The pyramidal fossa is a depression that houses the stapedius muscle, located on the posterior wall of the middle ear. However, this is distinct from the sinus tympani, which is located near the round window niche.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The sinus tympani is a depression located at the junction of the lateral and posterior walls of the tympanic cavity and is difficult to access and visualize during middle ear surgery.

questions.text: Match the Following – Interstitial Lung Diseases and Pneumoconiosis
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-d, 2-b, 3-c, 4-a

 

  1. Silicosis → d. Characterized by nodular opacities and interlobular septal thickening: Silicosis typically presents with upper lobe nodular opacities on imaging. High-resolution CT may show interlobular septal thickening and a “crazy-paving” appearance, particularly in complicated cases. Nodules tend to calcify over time and may coalesce, leading to progressive massive fibrosis.
  2. Mesothelioma → b. Hemorrhagic pleural effusion without midline shift: Malignant mesothelioma, associated with asbestos exposure, presents with hemorrhagic pleural effusions. These effusions are often massive but do not usually cause midline shift, which is otherwise typical of large effusions. This is because the tumor encases the lung and restricts mediastinal mobility.
  3. Caplan syndrome → c. Rheumatoid nodules in pneumoconiosis background: Caplan syndrome is a rheumatoid lung disease seen in coal workers or patients with pneumoconiosis. It features multiple peripheral lung nodules (rheumatoid nodules) superimposed on the fibrotic background of pneumoconiosis. It exemplifies the immunologic interaction between dust exposure and autoimmune disease.
  4. Asbestosis → a. Predominantly affects the lower lung zones: Asbestosis typically causes interstitial fibrosis, especially in the lower lung zones. The fibrosis starts in the subpleural regions and progresses centrally. This zonal predominance is a key diagnostic clue, especially in occupational settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Silicosis presents with nodular opacities and septal thickening.
  •  mesothelioma causes hemorrhagic pleural effusion without midline shift.
  •  Caplan syndrome involves rheumatoid nodules on pneumoconiosis background
  • And asbestosis predominantly affects the lower lobes. 
  • These hallmark features help in distinguishing occupational lung diseases and guide further evaluation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old contact lens wearer presents to the ophthalmology clinic with painful, red eyes, blurred vision, and photophobia. Slit-lamp examination reveals a ring-shaped corneal ulcer. Corneal scrapings are taken, and laboratory analysis identifies a free-living amoeba with characteristic double-walled cysts. Which of the following organisms is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acanthamoeba castellanii

 

  • Acanthamoeba castellanii is a free-living protozoan commonly found in soil, fresh water, and poorly disinfected contact lens solutions.
  • It causes Acanthamoeba keratitis, particularly in contact lens users. Key features include:
    • Severe ocular pain
    • Photophobia and tearing
    • Ring-shaped corneal ulcer
    • Double-walled cysts and trophozoites seen on microscopy
  • It can also cause granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE) in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Naegleria fowleri: They are also free living organisms. Causes primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) via nasal inhalation of contaminated water. Not associated with keratitis.

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: They are not free living organisms. Causes amoebic dysentery and liver abscesses, not keratitis or ocular disease.

 

Option D. Toxoplasma gondii: They are not free living organisms. Associated with retinochoroiditis, particularly in congenital infections, not keratitis with ring ulcer or cyst-forming amoebae in cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acanthamoeba castellanii is a free-living amoeba that causes keratitis in contact lens users and can be identified by its characteristic double-walled cysts in corneal samples.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is undergoing immunological workup following repeated respiratory infections and progressive gait instability. Clinical examination reveals telangiectatic lesions over the sclerae. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and significant immunoglobulin profile abnormalities. One immunoglobulin subtype is notably absent on testing. Which of the following immunoglobulin classes is characteristically absent in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgA

 

  • Ataxia telangiectasia (AT) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATM gene, which is essential for DNA repair. Clinically, AT presents with:
    • Cerebellar ataxia (gait abnormalities)
    • Oculocutaneous telangiectasias
    • Recurrent infections (especially respiratory tract)
  • One of the hallmark immunologic findings is the selective absence of immunoglobulin A (IgA). IgA is crucial for mucosal immunity; its deficiency in AT leads to a high risk of recurrent sinopulmonary infections.
  • The laboratory profile in AT often shows:
    • Elevated AFP
    • Decreased or absent IgA
    • Variable reduction in IgG or IgE
    • Preserved or mildly reduced IgM
  • The absence of IgA specifically is a diagnostic clue in AT and helps differentiate it from other immunodeficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgG: While IgG levels may be reduced in some AT patients, they are not characteristically absent. IgG reductions are variable and do not define the immunologic signature of AT.

 

Option B. IgD: IgD is typically present at low concentrations and its clinical relevance in AT is minimal. It is not the immunoglobulin that is characteristically absent.

 

Option D. IgM: IgM levels in AT may be normal or even elevated. It is not consistently decreased and certainly not absent in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Ataxia telangiectasia, the immunoglobulin class that is characteristically absent is IgA, contributing to recurrent mucosal infections and helping in diagnostic confirmation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with progressive cognitive decline and intermittent headaches. MRI of the brain is performed to evaluate the cause. One of the axial images is shown below. Based on the grayscale pattern of signal intensities and the structures highlighted, which of the following MRI sequences most likely corresponds to the image shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proton density weighted image

 

  • A proton density (PD) weighted image provides contrast primarily based on the concentration of hydrogen protons in tissues. On PD-weighted MRI:
    • White matter appears darker than gray matter (due to lower hydrogen content)
    • CSF appears dark or intermediate
    • There is less T1 and T2 influence, leading to fine anatomical detail
    • The overall contrast is subtle, but the signal-to-noise ratio is high, ideal for evaluating subtle pathology
  • In the provided image:
    • The gray and white matter differentiation is clearly visible with less exaggerated contrast
    • The ventricles and CSF-containing spaces are not hyperintense (as in T2) or hypointense (as in T1)
    • The cortex and subcortical white matter show intermediate signals rather than extremes, characteristic of PD weighting

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apparent diffusion coefficient map: Incorrect. ADC maps are derived from DWI and appear gray-scaled with low diffusion areas as dark. The provided image in the question lacks this pattern, and there's no restriction artifact typical of ADC maps.

 

 

Option B. Susceptibility weighted image: Incorrect. SWI is optimized to show blood products and calcifications, especially microhemorrhages. It shows veins and hemorrhagic lesions as blooming dark areas, which are not seen here.

 

 

Option D. Diffusion weighted image: Incorrect. DWI highlights areas of restricted diffusion, such as in acute stroke, with bright signal in affected areas. DWI does not show the bone (as shown in image below). The image given in the question does not show diffusion restriction or stroke pattern, and the contrast profile doesn’t match DWI.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A proton density (PD) weighted MRI provides high anatomical detail with subtle contrast, useful for identifying fine structural changes. 
  • It is recognized by clear gray-white matter distinction, minimal CSF brightness, and absence of the strong T1 or T2 signal characteristics.

questions.text: A screening test has 90% sensitivity and 90% specificity. In a population where disease prevalence is 20%, what is the Positive Predictive Value (PPV) of the test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 69.2%

 

To calculate the Positive Predictive Value (PPV), we use the following formula:

 

 

Let’s assume a population of 1000 people for easy calculation.

 

  • Prevalence = 20% → 200 people have the disease, 800 people do not.
  • Sensitivity = 90% → 90% of 200 = 180 true positives (TP).
  • So, 20 false negatives (FN) (i.e., 10% of 200).
  • Specificity = 90% → 90% of 800 = 720 true negatives (TN).
  • So, 80 false positives (FP) (i.e., 10% of 800).

 

Now calculate PPV:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Positive Predictive Value (PPV) increases with higher disease prevalence, and depends on both sensitivity and specificity.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding rheumatic heart disease is/are incorrect?

 

  1. Vegetations are small, warty, and usually located along the line of valve closure.
  2. Mitral valve is the most commonly affected, often in combination with the aortic valve.
  3. Vegetations are large, friable, and loosely attached, typically leading to septic emboli.
  4. Microscopic examination reveals fibrin and platelet thrombi with mononuclear cell infiltration.
  5. Aschoff bodies may be seen in the underlying endocardium as a feature of rheumatic carditis.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 only

 

Statement 3. Vegetations are large, friable, and loosely attached, typically leading to septic emboli: Large, friable vegetations that produce septic emboli are typical of infective endocarditis, not rheumatic disease.

 

Correct statements: 

 

Statement 1. Vegetations are small, warty, and usually located along the line of valve closure: Vegetations in rheumatic heart disease are small, multiple, warty, grey-brown, and occur along the line of valve closure, particularly on the atrial surface of AV valves and ventricular surface of semilunar valves.

 

Statement 2. Mitral valve is the most commonly affected, often in combination with the aortic valve: The mitral valve is almost always affected, and mitral-aortic combination is common.

 

Statement 4. Microscopic examination reveals fibrin and platelet thrombi with mononuclear cell infiltration: Microscopy shows fibrin with superimposed platelet thrombi, no bacteria, and mononuclear infiltrate.

 

Statement 5. Aschoff bodies may be seen in the underlying endocardium as a feature of rheumatic carditis: Aschoff bodies, which are pathognomonic for rheumatic fever, may be found in the underlying myocardium or endocardium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatic heart disease features small, firmly attached vegetations along the valve closure line, primarily affecting the mitral valve, with mononuclear infiltrates and Aschoff bodies microscopically.
  • Large, friable vegetations are characteristic of infective endocarditis, not rheumatic disease.

questions.text: A middle-aged adult undergoes evaluation for a biopsy-proven malignancy located in the lower rectum. Imaging shows no distant metastasis. The surgical team is planning a minimally invasive approach that allows for precise dissection of the rectum through a transanal route. Which of the following surgical techniques is most appropriate for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) taTME

 

  • taTME (Transanal Total Mesorectal Excision) is a minimally invasive surgical procedure specifically developed for the treatment of rectal cancers, particularly those located in the mid and low rectum. 
  • It involves a transanal approach for precise dissection of the mesorectum, allowing for better visualization of the distal rectum, especially in narrow male pelvises or obese patients where conventional laparoscopic access may be challenging.
  • This technique improves oncological clearance, minimizes positive circumferential resection margins, and allows for better preservation of pelvic nerves. It is performed using specialized platforms (e.g., transanal endoscopic surgery systems) and is now recognized as an effective technique in modern rectal cancer surgery protocols.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Dohlman procedure: This is used for the treatment of Zenker’s diverticulum, a pharyngeal pouch condition that involves the cricopharyngeal muscle. It has no role in rectal cancer surgery and is completely unrelated to the pelvic or colorectal anatomy.

 

Option B. Ripstein procedure: This is a rectopexy procedure used in patients with rectal prolapse. It involves suturing the rectum to the sacrum to prevent prolapse. It does not involve resection of malignant tissue and is not used in the management of rectal cancer.
